And so I promised myself that in the dining-room, as they began to eat and drink and as I felt the hour approach, I would put beforehand into this kiss, which was bound to be so brief and stealthy in execution, everything that my own efforts could put into it: would look out very carefully first the exact spot on her cheek where I would imprint it, and would so prepare my thoughts that I might be able, thanks to these mental preliminaries, to consecrate the whole of the minute Mamma would allow me to the sensation of her cheek against my lips, as a painter who can have his subject for short sittings only prepares his palette, and from what he remembers and from rough notes does in advance everything which he possibly can do in the sitter’s absence. But to-night, before the dinner-bell had sounded, my grandfather said with unconscious cruelty: ‘The little man looks tired; he’d better go up to bed. Besides, we are dining late to-night.’
我的目光从未离开过我的母亲。我知道，当他们坐在餐桌旁时，我不应该被允许整个晚餐时间都呆在那里，而妈妈，因为害怕惹恼我的父亲，不允许我在公共场合给她一系列的亲吻。本来就在我的房间里。所以我向自己保证，在餐厅里，当他们开始吃喝时，当我感觉到时间临近时，我会预先把我所知道的一切都融入到这个吻中，这个吻的执行过程必然如此短暂和隐秘。自己的努力可以投入其中：首先会非常仔细地观察她脸颊上我要印上它的确切位置，并准备好我的想法，以便我能够通过这些心理准备，将整个分钟奉献出来妈妈会让我感觉到她的脸颊贴在我的嘴唇上，就像一个画家，他可以短暂地坐着画他的主题，只准备他的调色板，然后根据他的记忆和粗略的笔记，提前做好他在绘画中可能做的一切。保姆缺席。但今天晚上，饭铃还没敲响，祖父就无意识地残忍地说：“这个小个子看起来很累；他看起来很疲惫。”他最好上床睡觉了。此外，我们今晚要吃晚饭。”

And my father, who was less scrupulous than my grandmother or mother in observing the letter of a treaty, went on: ‘Yes, run along; to bed with you.’
我的父亲在遵守条约的条文方面不像我的祖母或母亲那么严格，他继续说道：“是的，走吧；快走吧！”和你一起睡觉。

I would have kissed Mamma then and there, but at that moment the dinner-bell rang.
我真想当场亲吻妈妈，但就在这时，晚餐铃响了。

‘No, no, leave your mother alone. You’ve said good night quite enough. These exhibitions are absurd. Go on upstairs.’
‘不，不，别管你妈妈了。你已经说了很多晚安了。这些展览都是荒谬的。上楼去吧。

And so I must set forth without viaticum; must climb each step of the staircase ‘against my heart,’ as the saying is, climbing in opposition to my heart’s desire, which was to return to my mother, since she had not, by her kiss, given my heart leave to accompany me forth. That hateful staircase, up which I always passed with such dismay, gave out a smell of varnish which had to some extent absorbed, made definite and fixed the special quality of sorrow that I felt each evening, and made it perhaps even more cruel to my sensibility because, when it assumed this olfactory guise, my intellect was powerless to resist it. When we have gone to sleep with a maddening toothache and are conscious of it only as a little girl whom we attempt, time after time, to pull out of the water, or as a line of Molière which we repeat incessantly to ourselves, it is a great relief to wake up, so that our intelligence can disentangle the idea of toothache from any artificial semblance of heroism or rhythmic cadence. It was the precise converse of this relief which I felt when my anguish at having to go up to my room invaded my consciousness in a manner infinitely more rapid, instantaneous almost, a manner at once insidious and brutal as I breathed in—a far more poisonous thing than any moral penetration—the peculiar smell of the varnish upon that staircase.
所以我必须不带任何旅行费就出发；正如俗话所说，我必须“逆着我的心”爬上楼梯的每一步，违背我内心的愿望，那就是回到我母亲身边，因为她没有用她的吻让我的心陪伴我向前。我总是怀着沮丧的心情爬上那个可恶的楼梯，它散发出一种清漆的气味，这种气味在某种程度上被吸收了，使我每天晚上所感受到的特殊的悲伤变得明确和固定，也许对我来说更加残酷。感性，因为当它呈现出这种嗅觉的伪装时，我的理智无力抵抗它。当我们带着令人发狂的牙痛入睡时，只意识到自己是一个小女孩，一次又一次地试图把她从水里拉出来，或者是我们不断对自己重复的莫里哀的诗句，那就是醒来是一种极大的解脱，这样我们的智慧就可以将牙痛的想法与任何人为的英雄主义或有节奏的节奏分离开来。当我不得不上自己的房间时，我的痛苦以一种更加迅速、几乎是瞬间的方式侵入我的意识，当我吸气时，一种既阴险又残酷的方式，一种更加阴险和残酷的方式侵入我的意识，这正是我所感受到的轻松的反面。比任何道德渗透都有毒的东西——楼梯上清漆的特殊气味。

Once in my room I had to stop every loophole, to close the shutters, to dig my own grave as I turned down the bed-clothes, to wrap myself in the shroud of my nightshirt. But before burying myself in the iron bed which had been placed there because, on summer nights, I was too hot among the rep curtains of the four-poster, I was stirred to revolt, and attempted the desperate stratagem of a condemned prisoner. I wrote to my mother begging her to come upstairs for an important reason which I could not put in writing. My fear was that Françoise, my aunt’s cook who used to be put in charge of me when I was at Combray, might refuse to take my note. I had a suspicion that, in her eyes, to carry a message to my mother when there was a stranger in the room would appear flatly inconceivable, just as it would be for the door-keeper of a theatre to hand a letter to an actor upon the stage. For things which might or might not be done she possessed a code at once imperious, abundant, subtle, and uncompromising on points themselves imperceptible or irrelevant, which gave it a resemblance to those ancient laws which combine such cruel ordinances as the massacre of infants at the breast with prohibitions, of exaggerated refinement, against ‘seething the kid in his mother’s milk,’ or ‘eating of the sinew which is upon the hollow of the thigh.’ This code, if one could judge it by the sudden obstinacy which she would put into her refusal to carry out certain of our instructions, seemed to have foreseen such social complications and refinements of fashion as nothing in Françoise’s surroundings or in her career as a servant in a village household could have put into her head; and we were obliged to assume that there was latent in her some past existence in the ancient history of France, noble and little understood, just as there is in those manufacturing towns where old mansions still testify to their former courtly days, and chemical workers toil among delicately sculptured scenes of the Miracle of Theophilus or the Quatre Fils Aymon.
一旦进入我的房间，我就必须堵住每一个漏洞，关上百叶窗，在翻下床单时挖掘自己的坟墓，用睡衣裹住自己。但在把自己埋进铁床里之前，我被激起反抗，并尝试了一个死刑犯的绝望策略，因为在夏天的夜晚，我在四柱窗帘中太热了，所以就放在那里了。我写信给母亲恳求她上楼，原因很重要，但我无法写下来。我担心弗朗索瓦丝，我姨妈的厨师，我在贡布雷时负责管理我，可能会拒绝接受我的笔记。我怀疑，在她眼里，当房间里有陌生人的时候，给我母亲传递信息是完全不可想象的，就像剧院的门卫把一封信递给演员一样舞台上。对于那些可能做或可能不做的事情，她拥有一套专横、丰富、微妙的法典，在那些本身难以察觉或无关紧要的问题上毫不妥协，这使得它类似于那些结合了诸如屠杀婴儿等残酷法令的古代法律。乳房有禁令，有夸张的精致，反对“用母乳煮山羊羔”或“吃大腿窝的筋”。如果人们可以通过她拒绝执行我们的某些指示时突然的固执来判断这一准则，那么这一准则似乎预见到了弗朗索瓦丝所处的环境或她的职业生涯中所没有的社会复杂性和时尚的精致化。村里的仆人可以把它放进她的脑袋里；我们不得不假设她身上潜藏着法国古代历史中的某种过去的存在，高贵而鲜为人知，就像在那些制造业城镇中一样，那里的老宅邸仍然见证着他们以前的宫廷岁月，还有化学工人的辛劳。其中包括《提奥菲勒斯奇迹》或《艾蒙之四》的精美雕刻场景。

In this particular instance, the article of her code which made it highly improbable that—barring an outbreak of fire—Françoise would go down and disturb Mamma when M. Swann was there for so unimportant a person as myself was one embodying the respect she shewed not only for the family (as for the dead, for the clergy, or for royalty), but also for the stranger within our gates; a respect which I should perhaps have found touching in a book, but which never failed to irritate me on her lips, because of the solemn and gentle tones in which she would utter it, and which irritated me more than usual this evening when the sacred character in which she invested the dinner-party might have the effect of making her decline to disturb its ceremonial. But to give myself one chance of success I lied without hesitation, telling her that it was not in the least myself who had wanted to write to Mamma, but Mamma who, on saying good night to me, had begged me not to forget to send her an answer about something she had asked me to find, and that she would certainly be very angry if this note were not taken to her. I think that Françoise disbelieved me, for, like those primitive men whose senses were so much keener than our own, she could immediately detect, by signs imperceptible by the rest of us, the truth or falsehood of anything that we might wish to conceal from her. She studied the envelope for five minutes as though an examination of the paper itself and the look of my handwriting could enlighten her as to the nature of the contents, or tell her to which article of her code she ought to refer the matter. Then she went out with an air of resignation which seemed to imply: ‘What a dreadful thing for parents to have a child like this!’
在这个特殊的例子中，她的守则中的条款规定，除非发生火灾，当斯旺先生在为像我这样不重要的人服务时，弗朗索瓦丝不太可能下去打扰妈妈，这体现了她所表现出的尊重不仅为了家人（对于死者、神职人员或皇室成员），也为了我们大门内的陌生人；我也许会在书中找到一种感人的尊重，但她的嘴唇总是让我感到恼火，因为她说话时的语气庄严而温柔，今晚当神圣的仪式发生时，这种尊重比平时更让我恼火。她参加晚宴的性格可能会导致她拒绝打扰晚宴的仪式。但为了给自己一次成功的机会，我毫不犹豫地撒了谎，告诉她，本来想写信给妈妈的根本不是我自己，而是妈妈，在向我道晚安时，恳求我不要忘记给妈妈写信。她对我要找的某件事的答复，如果不把这张纸条交给她，她肯定会非常生气。我认为弗朗索瓦丝不相信我，因为就像那些感官比我们敏锐得多的原始人一样，她可以通过我们其他人察觉不到的迹象立即察觉到我们可能希望隐瞒的任何事情的真实性或虚假性。她。她研究了信封五分钟，仿佛检查纸张本身和我的笔迹可以启发她了解内容的性质，或者告诉她应该参考代码中的哪一条来解决这个问题。然后她带着一种无奈的神情走了出去，似乎在暗示：“父母生出这样的孩子是多么可怕的事情啊！”

A moment later she returned to say that they were still at the ice stage and that it was impossible for the butler to deliver the note at once, in front of everybody; but that when the finger-bowls were put round he would find a way of slipping it into Mamma’s hand. At once my anxiety subsided; it was now no longer (as it had been a moment ago) until to-morrow that I had lost my mother, for my little line was going—to annoy her, no doubt, and doubly so because this contrivance would make me ridiculous in Swann’s eyes—but was going all the same to admit me, invisibly and by stealth, into the same room as herself, was going to whisper from me into her ear; for that forbidden and unfriendly dining-room, where but a moment ago the ice itself—with burned nuts in it—and the finger-bowls seemed to me to be concealing pleasures that were mischievous and of a mortal sadness because Mamma was tasting of them and I was far away, had opened its doors to me and, like a ripe fruit which bursts through its skin, was going to pour out into my intoxicated heart the gushing sweetness of Mamma’s attention while she was reading what I had written. Now I was no longer separated from her; the barriers were down; an exquisite thread was binding us. Besides, that was not all, for surely Mamma would come.
过了一会儿，她回来说，他们还处于冰阶段，管家不可能当着所有人的面立即送出纸条。但当手指碗放在周围时，他会找到一种方法将它滑入妈妈的手中。我的焦虑立刻消退了。现在不再（像刚才一样）直到明天我就失去了我的母亲，因为我的小台词无疑会惹恼她，而且更是如此，因为这个发明会让我在生活中变得可笑。斯万的眼睛——但仍然要让我隐形地、偷偷地进入她自己的同一个房间，她要在她耳边对我低声说话；那个被禁止的、不友好的餐厅，就在不久前，冰块本身——里面有烧焦的坚果——和手指碗在我看来似乎隐藏着调皮的快乐和致命的悲伤，因为妈妈正在品尝它们我在很远的地方，它已经向我敞开了大门，就像一个成熟的水果破皮而出，当妈妈读我写的东西时，她的注意力所带来的甜蜜将倾注到我陶醉的心中。现在我和她不再分离了；障碍已经消失；一根精致的线把我们绑在了一起。此外，这还不是全部，因为妈妈肯定会来的。

As for the agony through which I had just passed, I imagined that Swann would have laughed heartily at it if he had read my letter and had guessed its purpose; whereas, on the contrary, as I was to learn in due course, a similar anguish had been the bane of his life for many years, and no one perhaps could have understood my feelings at that moment so well as himself; to him, that anguish which lies in knowing that the creature one adores is in some place of enjoyment where oneself is not and cannot follow—to him that anguish came through Love, to which it is in a sense predestined, by which it must be equipped and adapted; but when, as had befallen me, such an anguish possesses one’s soul before Love has yet entered into one’s life, then it must drift, awaiting Love’s coming, vague and free, without precise attachment, at the disposal of one sentiment to-day, of another to-morrow, of filial piety or affection for a comrade. And the joy with which I first bound myself apprentice, when Françoise returned to tell me that my letter would be delivered; Swann, too, had known well that false joy which a friend can give us, or some relative of the woman we love, when on his arrival at the house or theatre where she is to be found, for some ball or party or ‘first-night’ at which he is to meet her, he sees us wandering outside, desperately awaiting some opportunity of communicating with her. He recognises us, greets us familiarly, and asks what we are doing there. And when we invent a story of having some urgent message to give to his relative or friend, he assures us that nothing could be more simple, takes us in at the door, and promises to send her down to us in five minutes. How much we love him—as at that moment I loved Françoise—the good-natured intermediary who by a single word has made supportable, human, almost propitious the inconceivable, infernal scene of gaiety in the thick of which we had been imagining swarms of enemies, perverse and seductive, beguiling away from us, even making laugh at us, the woman whom we love. If we are to judge of them by him, this relative who has accosted us and who is himself an initiate in those cruel mysteries, then the other guests cannot be so very demoniacal. Those inaccessible and torturing hours into which she had gone to taste of unknown pleasures—behold, a breach in the wall, and we are through it. Behold, one of the moments whose series will go to make up their sum, a moment as genuine as the rest, if not actually more important to ourself because our mistress is more intensely a part of it; we picture it to ourselves, we possess it, we intervene upon it, almost we have created it: namely, the moment in which he goes to tell her that we are waiting there below. And very probably the other moments of the party will not be essentially different, will contain nothing else so exquisite or so well able to make us suffer, since this kind friend has assured us that ‘Of course, she will be delighted to come down! It will be far more amusing for her to talk to you than to be bored up there.’ Alas! Swann had learned by experience that the good intentions of a third party are powerless to control a woman who is annoyed to find herself pursued even into a ball-room by a man whom she does not love. Too often, the kind friend comes down again alone.
至于我刚刚经历的痛苦，我想如果斯万读了我的信并猜到了它的目的，他一定会大笑起来；然而，相反，正如我后来了解到的那样，类似的痛苦多年来一直是他生活中的祸根，也许没有人能像他自己一样清楚地理解我当时的感受；对他来说，那种痛苦在于知道一个人所崇拜的生物正处于某个享受的地方，而自己不在，也无法追随——对他来说，这种痛苦来自于爱，在某种意义上，它是注定的，必须通过爱来实现。装备和改造；但是，就像发生在我身上的那样，当爱情尚未进入一个人的生活之前，这样一种痛苦就占据了一个人的灵魂，那么它就必须漂流，等待爱情的到来，模糊而自由，没有精确的依恋，今天可以由一种情感支配，另一个明天，孝顺或对同志的感情。当弗朗索瓦丝回来告诉我我的信即将送达时，我第一次把自己当学徒时的喜悦；斯旺也很清楚，当朋友或我们所爱的女人的亲戚到达她所在的房子或剧院时，在参加舞会或聚会或“第一次”时，他可以给我们带来虚假的快乐。 “那天晚上”，他要和她见面，他看到我们在外面徘徊，拼命地等待着与她交流的机会。他认出了我们，亲切地向我们打招呼，并询问我们在那里做什么。当我们编造一个故事，要向他的亲戚或朋友传达一些紧急信息时，他向我们保证没有什么比这更简单的了，他把我们带到门口，并承诺在五分钟内将她送到我们这里。 我们是多么爱他——就像在那一刻我爱弗朗索瓦丝一样——这位善良的中间人，只用一句话就让我们想象中的那一团难以想象的、地狱般的欢乐景象变得可以支持、人性化、几乎吉祥。敌人，邪恶而诱人，欺骗我们，甚至嘲笑我们，我们所爱的女人。如果我们以他这个与我们搭讪的亲戚来评判他们，而且他本人也是那些残酷神秘事件的入门者，那么其他客人就不可能如此邪恶。在那些难以接近和折磨人的时光里，她尝到了未知的快乐——看哪，墙上有一个缺口，而我们正在穿过它。看哪，这是一个系列将弥补其总和的时刻，一个与其他时刻一样真实的时刻，如果不是实际上对我们自己更重要，因为我们的情妇更强烈地成为其中的一部分；我们想象它，我们拥有它，我们干预它，几乎我们已经创造了它：即，他去告诉她我们正在下面等的那一刻。聚会的其他时刻很可能不会有本质上的不同，不会包含任何其他如此精致或如此能让我们受苦的东西，因为这位好心的朋友向我们保证，“当然，她会很高兴下来！”对她来说，和你说话比在上面无聊有趣得多。’唉！斯旺从经验中了解到，当一个女人发现自己被一个她不爱的男人追赶进舞厅时，她会感到恼火，第三方的善意是无法控制的。很多时候，好心的朋友又独自下来。

My mother did not appear, but with no attempt to safeguard my self-respect (which depended upon her keeping up the fiction that she had asked me to let her know the result of my search for something or other) made Françoise tell me, in so many words ‘There is no answer’—words I have so often, since then, heard the hall-porters in ‘mansions’ and the flunkeys in gambling-clubs and the like, repeat to some poor girl, who replies in bewilderment: ‘What! he’s said nothing? It’s not possible. You did give him my letter, didn’t you? Very well, I shall wait a little longer.’ And just as she invariably protests that she does not need the extra gas which the porter offers to light for her, and sits on there, hearing nothing further, except an occasional remark on the weather which the porter exchanges with a messenger whom he will send off suddenly, when he notices the time, to put some customer’s wine on the ice; so, having declined Françoise’s offer to make me some tea or to stay beside me, I let her go off again to the servants’ hall, and lay down and shut my eyes, and tried not to hear the voices of my family who were drinking their coffee in the garden.
我母亲没有出现，但她没有试图保护我的自尊（这取决于她继续编造她要求我让她知道我寻找某物或其他东西的结果），让弗朗索瓦丝告诉我，这么多话“没有答案”——从那时起，我经常听到“豪宅”中的门房和赌场里的走狗等向某个可怜的女孩重复这句话，她困惑地回答道： '什么！他什么也没说？这是不可能的。你确实把我的信给了他，不是吗？很好，我再等一会儿。”正当她总是抗议说她不需要门房为她点的额外煤气时，她就坐在那儿，除了偶尔谈论一下天气之外，什么也没听到。搬运工与一个信使交换了这个信息，当他注意到时间时，他会突然派出一个信使，把一些顾客的酒放在冰上；因此，在拒绝了弗朗索瓦丝为我泡茶或待在我身边的提议后，我让她再次前往仆人大厅，然后躺下并闭上眼睛，尽量不听家人正在喝酒的声音。他们在花园里喝咖啡。

But after a few seconds I realised that, by writing that line to Mamma, by approaching—at the risk of making her angry—so near to her that I felt I could reach out and grasp the moment in which I should see her again, I had cut myself off from the possibility of going to sleep until I actually had seen her, and my heart began to beat more and more painfully as I increased my agitation by ordering myself to keep calm and to acquiesce in my ill-fortune. Then, suddenly, my anxiety subsided, a feeling of intense happiness coursed through me, as when a strong medicine begins to take effect and one’s pain vanishes: I had formed a resolution to abandon all attempts to go to sleep without seeing Mamma, and had decided to kiss her at all costs, even with the certainty of being in disgrace with her for long afterwards, when she herself came up to bed. The tranquillity which followed my anguish made me extremely alert, no less than my sense of expectation, my thirst for and my fear of danger.
但几秒钟后我意识到，通过把这句话写给妈妈，通过接近——冒着让她生气的风险——离她如此之近，我觉得我可以伸出手来抓住我应该再次见到她的那一刻，我已经切断了自己睡觉的可能性，直到我真正见到她，我的心开始跳动得越来越痛苦，因为我命令自己保持冷静并默许我的不幸，这增加了我的不安。然后，突然间，我的焦虑平息了，一种强烈的幸福感席卷了我，就像一剂强效药物开始发挥作用，一个人的痛苦消失了：我已经下定决心，放弃所有在看不到妈妈的情况下睡觉的尝试，并且决定不惜一切代价吻她，即使当她自己上床睡觉时，她肯定会在很长一段时间内蒙羞。痛苦过后的宁静让我极度警觉，正如我对危险的期待、渴望和恐惧一样。

Noiselessly I opened the window and sat down on the foot of my bed; hardly daring to move in case they should hear me from below. Things outside seemed also fixed in mute expectation, so as not to disturb the moonlight which, duplicating each of them and throwing it back by the extension, forwards, of a shadow denser and more concrete than its substance, had made the whole landscape seem at once thinner and longer, like a map which, after being folded up, is spread out upon the ground. What had to move—a leaf of the chestnut-tree, for instance—moved. But its minute shuddering, complete, finished to the least detail and with utmost delicacy of gesture, made no discord with the rest of the scene, and yet was not merged in it, remaining clearly outlined. Exposed upon this surface of silence, which absorbed nothing from them, the most distant sounds, those which must have come from gardens at the far end of the town, could be distinguished with such exact ‘finish’ that the impression they gave of coming from a distance seemed due only to their ‘pianissimo’ execution, like those movements on muted strings so well performed by the orchestra of the Conservatoire that, although one does not lose a single note, one thinks all the same that they are being played somewhere outside, a long way from the concert hall, so that all the old subscribers, and my grandmother’s sisters too, when Swann had given them his seats, used to strain their ears as if they had caught the distant approach of an army on the march, which had not yet rounded the corner of the Rue de Trévise.
我无声无息地打开窗户，坐在床脚上。几乎不敢动，生怕他们从下面听到我的声音。外面的事物似乎也被固定在无声的期待中，以免打扰月光，月光复制了它们，并通过比其实体更密集、更具体的阴影向前延伸，将其向后投射，使整个景观看起来像是在等待。曾经更薄更长，就像一张地图，折叠起来后铺在地上。必须移动的东西——例如栗树的叶子——移动了。但它那微小的颤抖，是完整的，以最细微的细节和极其精致的姿态完成的，与场景的其他部分没有任何不协调，但又没有融入其中，保留了清晰的轮廓。暴露在这片寂静的表面上，没有吸收任何东西，最遥远的声音，那些一定来自城镇远端花园的声音，可以以如此精确的“完成”来区分，以至于它们给人的印象是来自距离似乎只是由于他们的“极弱”演奏而产生的，就像音乐学院管弦乐队在静音弦乐上演奏得如此出色，尽管人们没有丢失任何一个音符，但人们仍然认为它们是在外面的某个地方演奏的离音乐厅很远，所以所有的老订户，还有我祖母的姐妹们，当斯万给她们让座时，常常竖起耳朵，仿佛听到了行军中远方逼近的军队，还没有绕过特雷维斯街的拐角处。

I was well aware that I had placed myself in a position than which none could be counted upon to involve me in graver consequences at my parents’ hands; consequences far graver, indeed, than a stranger would have imagined, and such as (he would have thought) could follow only some really shameful fault. But in the system of education which they had given me faults were not classified in the same order as in that of other children, and I had been taught to place at the head of the list (doubtless because there was no other class of faults from which I needed to be more carefully protected) those in which I can now distinguish the common feature that one succumbs to them by yielding to a nervous impulse. But such words as these last had never been uttered in my hearing; no one had yet accounted for my temptations in a way which might have led me to believe that there was some excuse for my giving in to them, or that I was actually incapable of holding out against them. Yet I could easily recognise this class of transgressions by the anguish of mind which preceded, as well as by the rigour of the punishment which followed them; and I knew that what I had just done was in the same category as certain other sins for which I had been severely chastised, though infinitely more serious than they. When I went out to meet my mother as she herself came up to bed, and when she saw that I had remained up so as to say good night to her again in the passage, I should not be allowed to stay in the house a day longer, I should be packed off to school next morning; so much was certain. Very good: had I been obliged, the next moment, to hurl myself out of the window, I should still have preferred such a fate. For what I wanted now was Mamma, and to say good night to her. I had gone too far along the road which led to the realisation of this desire to be able to retrace my steps.
我很清楚，我已经把自己置于这样一个境地：我父母不可能让我承担更严重的后果。事实上，后果比陌生人想象的要严重得多，而且（他会认为）只会发生一些真正可耻的错误。但在他们给我的教育体系中，错误的分类顺序与其他孩子的错误顺序不同，我被教导要把错误放在列表的首位（毫无疑问，因为没有其他类别的错误）我需要更加小心地保护它们）那些我现在可以区分出一个共同特征的东西，即人们通过屈服于神经冲动而屈服于它们。但我从来没有听过最后这些话。还没有人以某种方式解释我的诱惑，使我相信我有某种理由屈服于它们，或者我实际上无法抵抗它们。然而，通过之前的内心痛苦以及随之而来的严厉惩罚，我可以很容易地识别出这类违法行为。我知道我刚才的所作所为与我受到严厉惩罚的某些其他罪属于同一类，尽管比它们严重得多。当我出去迎接母亲时，她自己也上床睡觉了，当她看到我还没睡，在过道里再次向她道晚安时，就不能让我在家里呆一天。再长一点，第二天早上我就该被送去学校了；一切都是确定的。很好：如果我下一刻被迫跳出窗外，我仍然宁愿选择这样的命运。因为我现在想要的是妈妈，并向她道晚安。 我在这条路上走了太远，导致我实现了能够原路返回的愿望。

I could hear my parents’ footsteps as they went with Swann; and, when the rattle of the gate assured me that he had really gone, I crept to the window. Mamma was asking my father if he had thought the lobster good, and whether M. Swann had had some of the coffee-and-pistachio ice. ‘I thought it rather so-so,’ she was saying; ‘next time we shall have to try another flavour.’
我能听到父母和斯旺一起走的脚步声。当大门的嘎嘎声让我确信他真的走了时，我爬到窗前。妈妈问父亲觉得龙虾好吃吗，斯旺先生是否喝过咖啡和开心果冰块。 “我觉得一般般，”她说。 “下次我们得尝试另一种口味。”

‘I can’t tell you,’ said my great-aunt, ‘what a change I find in Swann. He is quite antiquated!’ She had grown so accustomed to seeing Swann always in the same stage of adolescence that it was a shock to her to find him suddenly less young than the age she still attributed to him. And the others too were beginning to remark in Swann that abnormal, excessive, scandalous senescence, meet only in a celibate, in one of that class for whom it seems that the great day which knows no morrow must be longer than for other men, since for such a one it is void of promise, and from its dawn the moments steadily accumulate without any subsequent partition among his offspring.
“我无法告诉你，”我的姨婆说，“我在斯旺身上发现了多么大的变化。”他太老了！”她已经习惯了看到斯万总是处于青春期的同一阶段，以至于当她发现他突然比她所认为的他的年龄更年轻时，她感到很震惊。其他人也开始在斯万身上评论说，异常的、过度的、可耻的衰老，只有在独身者身上才会出现，对于这一类人来说，似乎没有明天的伟大日子一定比其他人更长，因为对于这样的人来说，它是没有希望的，从它的黎明开始，这些时刻就不断地积累，而不会在他的后代中出现任何后续的分裂。

‘I fancy he has a lot of trouble with that wretched wife of his, who ‘lives’ with a certain Monsieur de Charlus, as all Combray knows. It’s the talk of the town.’
“我想他和他那个可怜的妻子有很多麻烦，她和某个德·夏吕斯先生‘住在一起’，这是所有贡布雷都知道的。这是镇上的话题。

My mother observed that, in spite of this, he had looked much less unhappy of late. ‘And he doesn’t nearly so often do that trick of his, so like his father, of wiping his eyes and passing his hand across his forehead. I think myself that in his heart of hearts he doesn’t love his wife any more.’
我母亲注意到，尽管如此，他最近看起来不那么不高兴了。 “而且他很少像他父亲那样经常做那种擦眼睛、用手抚摸额头的把戏。我自己认为，在他的内心深处，他不再爱他的妻子了。

‘Why, of course he doesn’t,’ answered my grandfather. ‘He wrote me a letter about it, ages ago, to which I took care to pay no attention, but it left no doubt as to his feelings, let alone his love for his wife. Hullo! you two; you never thanked him for the Asti!’ he went on, turning to his sisters-in-law.
“为什么，他当然不知道，”我祖父回答道。 “多年前，他给我写了一封信，讲述了这件事，我小心翼翼地没有注意，但这毫无疑问地表明了他的感情，更不用说他对妻子的爱了。哈喽！你们俩;你从来没有为阿斯蒂感谢他！”他继续说道，转向他的嫂子。

‘What! we never thanked him? I think, between you and me, that I put it to him quite neatly,’ replied my aunt Flora.
'什么！我们从来没有感谢过他？我想，在你和我之间，我把它交给了他，”我的弗洛拉姨妈回答道。

‘Yes, you managed it very well; I admired you for it,’ said my aunt Céline.
‘是的，你处理得很好；我很钦佩你，”我的姨妈塞琳说道。

‘But you did it very prettily, too.’
“但你也做得非常漂亮。”

‘Yes; I liked my expression about ‘nice neighbours.’’
'是的;我喜欢我关于“好邻居”的表达。

‘What! Do you call that thanking him?’ shouted my grandfather. ‘I heard that all right, but devil take me if I guessed it was meant for Swann. You may be quite sure he never noticed it.’
'什么！你管这叫感谢他吗？”祖父喊道。 “我听到了，好吧，但如果我猜到这是给斯旺的，那我就见鬼了。你可能很确定他从来没有注意到这一点。

‘Come, come; Swann is not a fool. I am positive he appreciated the compliment. You didn’t expect me to tell him the number of bottles, or to guess what he paid for them.’
'来来;斯旺不是傻子。我确信他很欣赏这种赞美。你没想到我会告诉他瓶子的数量，或者猜出他买这些瓶子的价格。”

My father and mother were left alone and sat down for a moment; then my father said: ‘Well, shall we go up to bed?’
只剩下我的父亲和母亲独自坐了一会儿。然后我父亲说：“好吧，我们去睡觉吧？”

‘As you wish, dear, though I don’t feel in the least like sleeping. I don’t know why; it can’t be the coffee-ice—it wasn’t strong enough to keep me awake like this. But I see a light in the servants’ hall: poor Françoise has been sitting up for me, so I will get her to unhook me while you go and undress.’
“如你所愿，亲爱的，尽管我一点也不想睡觉。我不知道为什么；不可能是咖啡冰——它的浓度不足以让我保持清醒。但我看到仆人大厅里有灯光：可怜的弗朗索瓦丝一直在等我，所以我会让她帮我解开钩子，而你去脱衣服。

My mother opened the latticed door which led from the hall to the staircase. Presently I heard her coming upstairs to close her window. I went quietly into the passage; my heart was beating so violently that I could hardly move, but at least it was throbbing no longer with anxiety, but with terror and with joy. I saw in the well of the stair a light coming upwards, from Mamma’s candle. Then I saw Mamma herself: I threw myself upon her. For an instant she looked at me in astonishment, not realising what could have happened. Then her face assumed an expression of anger. She said not a single word to me; and, for that matter, I used to go for days on end without being spoken to, for far less offences than this. A single word from Mamma would have been an admission that further intercourse with me was within the bounds of possibility, and that might perhaps have appeared to me more terrible still, as indicating that, with such a punishment as was in store for me, mere silence, and even anger, were relatively puerile.
我母亲打开从大厅通向楼梯的格子门。不久我听到她上楼来关窗户。我悄悄地走进通道；我的心剧烈地跳动，几乎无法动弹，但至少不再是因为焦虑而跳动，而是因为恐惧和喜悦而跳动。我看到楼梯井里有一道光从妈妈的蜡烛中向上射出。然后我看到了妈妈本人：我扑倒在她身上。一瞬间，她惊讶地看着我，没有意识到会发生什么。然后她的脸上露出了愤怒的表情。她没有对我说一句话；就这一点而言，我常常连续几天没有人与我交谈，因为比这少得多的冒犯。妈妈只要说出一句话，就等于承认与我进一步交往是有可能的，而这对我来说可能会显得更可怕，因为这表明，在我即将受到的惩罚下，仅仅沉默，甚至愤怒，都是相对幼稚的。

A word from her then would have implied the false calm in which one converses with a servant to whom one has just decided to give notice; the kiss one bestows on a son who is being packed off to enlist, which would have been denied him if it had merely been a matter of being angry with him for a few days. But she heard my father coming from the dressing-room, where he had gone to take off his clothes, and, to avoid the ‘scene’ which he would make if he saw me, she said, in a voice half-stifled by her anger: ‘Run away at once. Don’t let your father see you standing there like a crazy jane!’
那时她的一句话就暗示着一种虚假的平静，就像一个人与一个刚刚决定要注意的仆人交谈一样。一个人给了一个被送去入伍的儿子一个吻，如果只是生他几天的气，他就会被拒绝。但她听到我父亲从更衣室走来，他去那里脱衣服，为了避免他看到我时会做出的“场面”，她用一种被她几乎窒息的声音说道。愤怒：‘立刻逃走。别让你父亲看到你像个疯子一样站在那里！

But I begged her again to ‘Come and say good night to me!’ terrified as I saw the light from my father’s candle already creeping up the wall, but also making use of his approach as a means of blackmail, in the hope that my mother, not wishing him to find me there, as find me he must if she continued to hold out, would give in to me, and say: ‘Go back to your room. I will come.’
但我再次恳求她“过来跟我说晚​​安！”当我看到父亲蜡烛的光已经爬上墙壁时，我感到害怕，但同时也利用他的做法作为勒索的手段，希望我的女儿能得到她的帮助。母亲不希望他在那儿找到我，如果她继续坚持下去，他就一定会找到我，于是她向我让步，说：“回你的房间去吧。”我会来。'

Too late: my father was upon us. Instinctively I murmured, though no one heard me, ‘I am done for!’
太晚了：我父亲已经追上我们了。尽管没有人听见，我本能地低声说道：“我完蛋了！”

I was not, however. My father used constantly to refuse to let me do things which were quite clearly allowed by the more liberal charters granted me by my mother and grandmother, because he paid no heed to ‘Principles,’ and because in his sight there were no such things as ‘Rights of Man.’ For some quite irrelevant reason, or for no reason at all, he would at the last moment prevent me from taking some particular walk, one so regular and so consecrated to my use that to deprive me of it was a clear breach of faith; or again, as he had done this evening, long before the appointed hour he would snap out: ‘Run along up to bed now; no excuses!’ But then again, simply because he was devoid of principles (in my grandmother’s sense), so he could not, properly speaking, be called inexorable. He looked at me for a moment with an air of annoyance and surprise, and then when Mamma had told him, not without some embarrassment, what had happened, said to her: ‘Go along with him, then; you said just now that you didn’t feel like sleep, so stay in his room for a little. I don’t need anything.’
然而我不是。我的父亲常常拒绝让我做那些由我的母亲和祖母授予我的更自由的章程中明确允许的事情，因为他不关心“原则”，因为在他看来，没有诸如此类的事情。 “人权。”出于某种完全不相干的原因，或者根本没有任何原因，他会在最后一刻阻止我进行某种特定的散步，这种散步如此定期且如此奉献给我使用，以至于剥夺我的这种散步是一种明显违反信用；或者，就像他今晚所做的那样，早在约定的时间之前，他就会突然说：“现在就跑到床上去吧；快去睡觉吧！”没有借口！”但话又说回来，仅仅因为他缺乏原则（在我祖母的意义上），所以正确地说，他不能被称为无情。他带着恼怒和惊讶的神情看了我一会儿，然后当妈妈不无尴尬地告诉他发生了什么事时，他对她说：“那就跟他走吧；”你刚才说你不想睡觉，就在他房间里呆一会儿吧。我不需要任何东西。

‘But dear,’ my mother answered timidly, ‘whether or not I feel like sleep is not the point; we must not make the child accustomed...’
“但是亲爱的，”我母亲胆怯地回答，“我是否觉得睡觉不是重点；我们不能让孩子习惯……”

‘There’s no question of making him accustomed,’ said my father, with a shrug of the shoulders; ‘you can see quite well that the child is unhappy. After all, we aren’t gaolers. You’ll end by making him ill, and a lot of good that will do. There are two beds in his room; tell Françoise to make up the big one for you, and stay beside him for the rest of the night. I’m off to bed, anyhow; I’m not nervous like you. Good night.’
“让他习惯是毫无疑问的，”我父亲耸了耸肩说道。 ‘你看得很清楚，孩子不高兴。毕竟，我们不是狱卒。你最终会让他生病，这会带来很多好处。他的房间里有两张床；让弗朗索瓦丝给你做一份大份的，然后在他身边度过余下的夜晚。无论如何，我要去睡觉了；我不像你那么紧张。晚安。'

It was impossible for me to thank my father; what he called my sentimentality would have exasperated him. I stood there, not daring to move; he was still confronting us, an immense figure in his white nightshirt, crowned with the pink and violet scarf of Indian cashmere in which, since he had begun to suffer from neuralgia, he used to tie up his head, standing like Abraham in the engraving after Benozzo Gozzoli which M. Swann had given me, telling Sarah that she must tear herself away from Isaac. Many years have passed since that night. The wall of the staircase, up which I had watched the light of his candle gradually climb, was long ago demolished. And in myself, too, many things have perished which, I imagined, would last for ever, and new structures have arisen, giving birth to new sorrows and new joys which in those days I could not have foreseen, just as now the old are difficult of comprehension. It is a long time, too, since my father has been able to tell Mamma to ‘Go with the child.’ Never again will such hours be possible for me. But of late I have been increasingly able to catch, if I listen attentively, the sound of the sobs which I had the strength to control in my father’s presence, and which broke out only when I found myself alone with Mamma. Actually, their echo has never ceased: it is only because life is now growing more and more quiet round about me that I hear them afresh, like those convent bells which are so effectively drowned during the day by the noises of the streets that one would suppose them to have been stopped for ever, until they sound out again through the silent evening air.
我不可能感谢我的父亲；他所说的我的多愁善感会激怒他。我站在那里，不敢动；他仍然站在我们面前，身材魁梧，身穿白色睡衣，头戴粉色和紫色的印度羊绒围巾，自从他开始患有神经痛以来，他常常把头绑起来，像版画中的亚伯拉罕一样站立斯万先生给我的贝诺佐·戈佐利之后，告诉莎拉她必须与艾萨克分开。距离那天晚上已经过去很多年了。我看着他的烛光逐渐爬上楼梯的墙壁，早已被拆除了。在我自己身上，许多我想象中会永远存在的东西已经消失，新的结构出现了，产生了新的悲伤和新的欢乐，这些在当时是我无法预见的，就像现在旧的一样。难以理解。自从我父亲能够告诉妈妈“和孩子一起去”以来，也已经有很长一段时间了。我再也不可能有这样的时间了。但最近，如果我仔细听的话，我越来越能听到父亲在场时我有能力控制的抽泣声，只有当我发现自己单独和妈妈在一起时，这种声音才会爆发。事实上，它们的回声从未停止过：只是因为我周围的生活变得越来越安静，我才重新听到它们，就像那些修道院的钟声，白天被街道的噪音淹没，以至于人们无法听到它们的声音。假设它们永远停止了，直到它们在寂静的夜晚空气中再次发出声音。

Mamma spent that night in my room: when I had just committed a sin so deadly that I was waiting to be banished from the household, my parents gave me a far greater concession than I should ever have won as the reward of a good action. Even at the moment when it manifested itself in this crowning mercy, my father’s conduct towards me was still somewhat arbitrary, and regardless of my deserts, as was characteristic of him and due to the fact that his actions were generally dictated by chance expediencies rather than based on any formal plan. And perhaps even what I called his strictness, when he sent me off to bed, deserved that title less, really, than my mother’s or grandmother’s attitude, for his nature, which in some respects differed more than theirs from my own, had probably prevented him from guessing, until then, how wretched I was every evening, a thing which my mother and grandmother knew well; but they loved me enough to be unwilling to spare me that suffering, which they hoped to teach me to overcome, so as to reduce my nervous sensibility and to strengthen my will. As for my father, whose affection for me was of another kind, I doubt if he would have shewn so much courage, for as soon as he had grasped the fact that I was unhappy he had said to my mother: ‘Go and comfort him.’ Mamma stayed all night in my room, and it seemed that she did not wish to mar by recrimination those hours, so different from anything that I had had a right to expect; for when Françoise (who guessed that something extraordinary must have happened when she saw Mamma sitting by my side, holding my hand and letting me cry unchecked) said to her: ‘But, Madame, what is little Master crying for?’ she replied: ‘Why, Françoise, he doesn’t know himself: it is his nerves. Make up the big bed for me quickly and then go off to your own.’ And thus for the first time my unhappiness was regarded no longer as a fault for which I must be punished, but as an involuntary evil which had been officially recognised a nervous condition for which I was in no way responsible: I had the consolation that I need no longer mingle apprehensive scruples with the bitterness of my tears; I could weep henceforward without sin. I felt no small degree of pride, either, in Franchise’s presence at this return to humane conditions which, not an hour after Mamma had refused to come up to my room and had sent the snubbing message that I was to go to sleep, raised me to the dignity of a grown-up person, brought me of a sudden to a sort of puberty of sorrow, to emancipation from tears. I ought then to have been happy; I was not. It struck me that my mother had just made a first concession which must have been painful to her, that it was a first step down from the ideal she had formed for me, and that for the first time she, with all her courage, had to confess herself beaten. It struck me that if I had just scored a victory it was over her; that I had succeeded, as sickness or sorrow or age might have succeeded, in relaxing her will, in altering her judgment; that this evening opened a new era, must remain a black date in the calendar. And if I had dared now, I should have said to Mamma: ‘No, I don’t want you; you mustn’t sleep here.’ But I was conscious of the practical wisdom, of what would be called nowadays the realism with which she tempered the ardent idealism of my grandmother’s nature, and I knew that now the mischief was done she would prefer to let me enjoy the soothing pleasure of her company, and not to disturb my father again. Certainly my mother’s beautiful features seemed to shine again with youth that evening, as she sat gently holding my hands and trying to check my tears; but, just for that reason, it seemed to me that this should not have happened; her anger would have been less difficult to endure than this new kindness which my childhood had not known; I felt that I had with an impious and secret finger traced a first wrinkle upon her soul and made the first white hair shew upon her head. This thought redoubled my sobs, and then I saw that Mamma, who had never allowed herself to go to any length of tenderness with me, was suddenly overcome by my tears and had to struggle to keep back her own. Then, as she saw that I had noticed this, she said to me, with a smile: ‘Why, my little buttercup, my little canary-boy, he’s going to make Mamma as silly as himself if this goes on. Look, since you can’t sleep, and Mamma can’t either, we mustn’t go on in this stupid way; we must do something; I’ll get one of your books.’ But I had none there. ‘Would you like me to get out the books now that your grandmother is going to give you for your birthday? Just think it over first, and don’t be disappointed if there is nothing new for you then.’
那天晚上，妈妈在我的房间里度过了：当我犯下了如此致命的罪孽，等待着被逐出家庭时，我的父母给了我一个比我本应赢得的更大的让步，作为对良好行为的奖励。即使在这种至高无上的仁慈体现出来的那一刻，我父亲对我的行为仍然有些武断，不管我的功劳如何，这是他的特点，因为他的行为通常是出于偶然的权宜之计，而不是出于偶然。基于任何正式计划。也许，当他送我上床睡觉时，我所说的他的严厉，实际上也比我母亲或祖母的态度更不值得称谓，因为他的本性在某些方面比他们与我的本性不同，可能阻止了我的行为。直到那时，他才猜到我每天晚上有多可怜，这一点我的母亲和祖母都很清楚。但他们太爱我了，不肯放过我那些痛苦，他们希望教我克服这些痛苦，从而减少我的紧张感，增强我的意志。至于父亲，他对我的感情却是另一种，我怀疑他是否会表现出这么大的勇气，因为当他得知我不高兴的时候，他就对我母亲说：“你去安慰他吧。”妈妈在我的房间里待了整整一夜，似乎她不想因为相互指责而破坏那些时光，因为这与我有权期待的一切如此不同；因为当弗朗索瓦丝（当她看到妈妈坐在我身边，握着我的手，任由我哭泣时，她猜一定发生了一些不寻常的事情）对她说：“但是，夫人，小主人为什么哭呢？”她回答道： “为什么，弗朗索瓦丝，他不了解自己：这是他的神经。 赶紧为我铺好大床，然后去你自己的床上。”就这样，我的不幸第一次不再被视为一种必须受到惩罚的过错，而是一种非自愿的罪恶，已被官方承认为一种罪恶。我的神经状况与我无关：我得到了安慰，因为我不再需要将忧虑的顾虑与我的眼泪的苦涩混在一起；从此我可以无罪地哭泣。弗兰奇斯在场，在这种人道条件的回归中，我也感到了不小的自豪感，就在妈妈拒绝到我的房间并发出冷落的信息让我去睡觉后不到一个小时，弗兰奇斯把我养大了。一个成年人的尊严，突然让我进入一种青春期的悲伤，从眼泪中解放出来。那时我应该感到高兴；我不是。我突然意识到，我的母亲刚刚做出了第一个让步，这对她来说一定是痛苦的，这是她为我所建立的理想的第一步，也是她第一次用她所有的勇气，承认自己被殴打。我突然意识到，如果说我刚刚取得了胜利，那一定是战胜了她；我已经成功地放松了她的意志，改变了她的判断，就像疾病、悲伤或衰老所可能成功的那样。今晚开启了一个新纪元，一定会在日历上留下一个黑色的日期。如果我现在有勇气的话，我就会对妈妈说：‘不，我不需要你；我要你了。你不能睡在这里。”但我意识到她的实用智慧，即现在所谓的现实主义，她用它来调和我祖母天性中热切的理想主义，我知道现在恶作剧已经完成，她更愿意让我享受她陪伴带来的舒缓的快乐，不要再打扰我的父亲。 当然，那天晚上，当我母亲温柔地握着我的手，试图阻止我的泪水时，她美丽的容貌似乎再次焕发出青春的光芒。但正因为如此，我觉得这种事不应该发生。她的愤怒比我童年时所不知道的这种新的仁慈更容易忍受。我觉得我用一只不虔诚而秘密的手指在她的灵魂上划出了第一条皱纹，让她的头上露出了第一根白发。这个念头让我的抽泣更加厉害，然后我发现，从来没有对我表现出任何温柔的妈妈，突然被我的泪水淹没，不得不努力忍住自己的泪水。然后，当她看到我注意到这一点时，她微笑着对我说：“为什么，我的小毛茛，我的金丝雀小男孩，如果再这样下去，他会让妈妈像他自己一样愚蠢。”你看，既然你睡不着，妈妈也睡不着，我们就不能再这样傻下去了；我们必须做点什么；我要买一本你的书。’但我那里没有。 “既然你的祖母要送给你生日礼物，你需要我把书拿出来吗？”先想一想，如果没有什么新的东西对你来说也不要失望。’

I was only too delighted, and Mamma went to find a parcel of books in which I could not distinguish, through the paper in which it was wrapped, any more than its squareness and size, but which, even at this first glimpse, brief and obscure as it was, bade fair to eclipse already the paint-box of last New Year’s Day and the silkworms of the year before. It contained La Mare au Diable, François le Champi, La Petite Fadette, and Les Maîtres Sonneurs. My grandmother, as I learned afterwards, had at first chosen Mussel’s poems, a volume of Rousseau, and Indiana; for while she considered light reading as unwholesome as sweets and cakes, she did not reflect that the strong breath of genius must have upon the very soul of a child an influence at once more dangerous and less quickening than those of fresh air and country breezes upon his body. But when my father had seemed almost to regard her as insane on learning the names of the books she proposed to give me, she had journeyed back by herself to Jouy-le-Vicomte to the bookseller’s, so that there should be no fear of my not having my present in time (it was a burning hot day, and she had come home so unwell that the doctor had warned my mother not to allow her again to tire herself in that way), and had there fallen back upon the four pastoral novels of George Sand.
我太高兴了，妈妈去找了一包书，透过包裹的纸，我无法区分它的方形和大小，但即使是第一眼看到，它也很简短和简洁。尽管它很不起眼，但它已经让去年元旦的颜料盒和前一年的蚕黯然失色了。其中包括《La Mare au Diable》、《François le Champi》、《La Petite Fadette》和《Les Maîtres Sonneurs》。后来我才知道，我的祖母最初选择了穆塞尔的诗、一本卢梭的诗集和《印第安纳》。因为虽然她认为轻松的阅读就像糖果和蛋糕一样不健康，但她没有想到，天才的强烈气息对孩子的灵魂所产生的影响，比新鲜空气和乡村微风对孩子的影响更危险，但更不那么迅速。他的身体。但当我父亲得知她打算送给我的书名后，几乎认为她疯了，她就独自回到了茹伊子爵的书店，这样我就不用担心我的书了。没有及时收到我的礼物（那天天气炎热，她回家后身体很不舒服，医生警告我母亲不要再让她以这种方式疲惫不堪），然后又回到了四田园乔治·桑的小说。

‘My dear,’ she had said to Mamma, ‘I could not allow myself to give the child anything that was not well written.’
“亲爱的，”她对妈妈说，“我不能让自己给孩子任何写得不好的东西。”

The truth was that she could never make up her mind to purchase anything from which no intellectual profit was to be derived, and, above all, that profit which good things bestowed on us by teaching us to seek our pleasures elsewhere than in the barren satisfaction of worldly wealth. Even when she had to make some one a present of the kind called ‘useful,’ when she had to give an armchair or some table-silver or a walking-stick, she would choose ‘antiques,’ as though their long desuetude had effaced from them any semblance of utility and fitted them rather to instruct us in the lives of the men of other days than to serve the common requirements of our own. She would have liked me to have in my room photographs of ancient buildings or of beautiful places. But at the moment of buying them, and for all that the subject of the picture had an aesthetic value of its own, she would find that vulgarity and utility had too prominent a part in them, through the mechanical nature of their reproduction by photography. She attempted by a subterfuge, if not to eliminate altogether their commercial banality, at least to minimise it, to substitute for the bulk of it what was art still, to introduce, as it might be, several ‘thicknesses’ of art; instead of photographs of Chartres Cathedral, of the Fountains of Saint-Cloud, or of Vesuvius she would inquire of Swann whether some great painter had not made pictures of them, and preferred to give me photographs of ‘Chartres Cathedral’ after Corot, of the ‘Fountains of Saint-Cloud’ after Hubert Robert, and of ‘Vesuvius’ after Turner, which were a stage higher in the scale of art. But although the photographer had been prevented from reproducing directly the masterpieces or the beauties of nature, and had there been replaced by a great artist, he resumed his odious position when it came to reproducing the artist’s interpretation. Accordingly, having to reckon again with vulgarity, my grandmother would endeavour to postpone the moment of contact still further. She would ask Swann if the picture had not been engraved, preferring, when possible, old engravings with some interest of association apart from themselves, such, for example, as shew us a masterpiece in a state in which we can no longer see it to-day, as Morghen’s print of the ‘Cenacolo’ of Leonardo before it was spoiled by restoration. It must be admitted that the results of this method of interpreting the art of making presents were not always happy. The idea which I formed of Venice, from a drawing by Titian which is supposed to have the lagoon in the background, was certainly far less accurate than what I have since derived from ordinary photographs. We could no longer keep count in the family (when my great-aunt tried to frame an indictment of my grandmother) of all the armchairs she had presented to married couples, young and old, which on a first attempt to sit down upon them had at once collapsed beneath the weight of their recipient. But my grandmother would have thought it sordid to concern herself too closely with the solidity of any piece of furniture in which could still be discerned a flourish, a smile, a brave conceit of the past. And even what in such pieces supplied a material need, since it did so in a manner to which we are no longer accustomed, was as charming to her as one of those old forms of speech in which we can still see traces of a metaphor whose fine point has been worn away by the rough usage of our modern tongue. In precisely the same way the pastoral novels of George Sand, which she was giving me for my birthday, were regular lumber-rooms of antique furniture, full of expressions that have fallen out of use and returned as imagery, such as one finds now only in country dialects. And my grandmother had bought them in preference to other books, just as she would have preferred to take a house that had a gothic dovecot, or some other such piece of antiquity as would have a pleasant effect on the mind, filling it with a nostalgic longing for impossible journeys through the realms of time.
事实是，她永远不会下定决心购买任何不能从中获得智力利润的东西，最重要的是，好东西通过教导我们在贫瘠的满足之外寻找快乐来赋予我们利润。的世俗财富。即使当她不得不送某人一份所谓“有用”的礼物时，当她不得不送一把扶手椅或一些桌银或一根手杖时，她也会选择“古董”，就好像它们的长期废弃已经被抹去了一样。从它们身上可以看出任何实用性，并且它们更适合指导我们了解其他时代人们的生活，而不是满足我们自己的共同需求。她希望我在房间里放一些古建筑或美丽地方的照片。但在购买它们的那一刻，尽管图片的主题有其自身的审美价值，但她会发现，由于摄影复制它们的机械性质，粗俗和实用在它们中占据了太突出的地位。她试图通过一种诡计，即使不能完全消除它们的商业平庸，至少将其最小化，用艺术的大部分来替代它，引入艺术的几种“厚度”；她不会向斯万询问沙特尔大教堂、圣克劳喷泉或维苏威火山的照片，而是询问斯旺是否有某个伟大的画家为它们画过照片，并且更愿意给我柯罗之后的“沙特尔大教堂”的照片，休伯特·罗伯特之后的“圣克劳德喷泉”和特纳之后的“维苏威火山”，在艺术规模上更上一层楼。 但是，尽管摄影师被禁止直接再现杰作或自然之美，并且被一位伟大的艺术家取代，但在再现艺术家的解释时，他又恢复了令人厌恶的地位。因此，不得不再次考虑粗俗，我的祖母会尽力进一步推迟接触的时间。她会问斯旺，这幅画是否没有被雕刻过，如果可能的话，她更喜欢古老的雕刻，除了它们本身之外还有一些关联的兴趣，例如，向我们展示一幅杰作，在这种状态下我们再也看不到它了。 - 天，作为摩根的列奥纳多的“Cenacolo”版画，在被修复损坏之前。必须承认，这种解释礼物制作艺术的方法的结果并不总是令人满意。我从提香的一幅以泻湖为背景的画中形成的威尼斯概念，肯定远不如我从普通照片中得出的概念准确。我们已经无法在家里（当我的姨婆试图对我的祖母提出起诉时）统计她送给已婚夫妇（无论年轻还是年老）的所有扶手椅，这些扶手椅在第一次尝试坐在他们身上时就被拒绝了。立刻就在接受者的重压下崩溃了。但我的祖母会认为，过于关注任何一件家具的坚固性是肮脏的，因为其中仍然可以看出过去的华丽、微笑和勇敢的自负。 即使在这些作品中提供了物质需要，因为它以我们不再习惯的方式提供，对她来说也像那些古老的言语形式一样迷人，在这些古老的言语形式中我们仍然可以看到隐喻的痕迹，我们现代舌头的粗暴使用已经磨掉了细尖。同样地，她送给我的生日礼物乔治·桑的田园小说也是普通的古董家具储藏室，充满了不再使用的表达方式，并以意象的形式回归，就像人们现在才发现的那样。在乡村方言中。我的祖母优先购买它们而不是其他书籍，就像她更喜欢买一座有哥特式鸽舍的房子，或者其他一些能给心灵带来愉快影响的古董，让心灵充满怀旧的感觉。渴望穿越时空的不可能的旅程。

Mamma sat down by my bed; she had chosen François le Champi, whose reddish cover and incomprehensible title gave it a distinct personality in my eyes and a mysterious attraction. I had not then read any real novels. I had heard it said that George Sand was a typical novelist. That prepared me in advance to imagine that François le Champi contained something inexpressibly delicious. The course of the narrative, where it tended to arouse curiosity or melt to pity, certain modes of expression which disturb or sadden the reader, and which, with a little experience, he may recognise as ‘common form’ in novels, seemed to me then distinctive—for to me a new book was not one of a number of similar objects, but was like an individual man, unmatched, and with no cause of existence beyond himself—an intoxicating whiff of the peculiar essence of François le Champi. Beneath the everyday incidents, the commonplace thoughts and hackneyed words, I could hear, or overhear, an intonation, a rhythmic utterance fine and strange. The ‘action’ began: to me it seemed all the more obscure because in those days, when I read to myself, I used often, while I turned the pages, to dream of something quite different. And to the gaps which this habit made in my knowledge of the story more were added by the fact that when it was Mamma who was reading to me aloud she left all the love-scenes out. And so all the odd changes which take place in the relations between the miller’s wife and the boy, changes which only the birth and growth of love can explain, seemed to me plunged and steeped in a mystery, the key to which (as I could readily believe) lay in that strange and pleasant-sounding name of Champi, which draped the boy who bore it, I knew not why, in its own bright colour, purpurate and charming. If my mother was not a faithful reader, she was, none the less, admirable when reading a work in which she found the note of true feeling by the respectful simplicity of her interpretation and by the sound of her sweet and gentle voice. It was the same in her daily life, when it was not works of art but men and women whom she was moved to pity or admire: it was touching to observe with what deference she would banish from her voice, her gestures, from her whole conversation, now the note of joy which might have distressed some mother who had long ago lost a child, now the recollection of an event or anniversary which might have reminded some old gentleman of the burden of his years, now the household topic which might have bored some young man of letters. And so, when she read aloud the prose of George Sand, prose which is everywhere redolent of that generosity and moral distinction which Mamma had learned from my grandmother to place above all other qualities in life, and which I was not to teach her until much later to refrain from placing, in the same way, above all other qualities in literature; taking pains to banish from her voice any weakness or affectation which might have blocked its channel for that powerful stream of language, she supplied all the natural tenderness, all the lavish sweetness which they demanded to phrases which seemed to have been composed for her voice, and which were all, so to speak, within her compass. She came to them with the tone that they required, with the cordial accent which existed before they were, which dictated them, but which is not to be found in the words themselves, and by these means she smoothed away, as she read on, any harshness there might be or discordance in the tenses of verbs, endowing the imperfect and the preterite with all the sweetness which there is in generosity, all the melancholy which there is in love; guided the sentence that was drawing to an end towards that which was waiting to begin, now hastening, now slackening the pace of the syllables so as to bring them, despite their difference of quantity, into a uniform rhythm, and breathed into this quite ordinary prose a kind of life, continuous and full of feeling.
妈妈在我的床边坐下；她选择了《François le Champi》，这本书的淡红色封面和难以理解的标题在我眼中赋予了它鲜明的个性和神秘的吸引力。那时我还没有读过任何真正的小说。我听说乔治·桑是一位典型的小说家。这让我提前想象弗朗索瓦·勒尚皮含有某种难以形容的美味。在我看来，叙述的过程往往会引起好奇或同情，某些表达方式会令读者感到不安或悲伤，只要有一点经验，他可能会认为这是小说中的“常见形式”那么独特——对我来说，一本新书不是众多类似物体中的一个，而是像一个单独的人，无与伦比，除了他自己之外没有任何存在的理由——一股令人陶醉的弗朗索瓦·勒·尚皮独特本质的气息。在日常的事件、平常的想法和陈词滥调的背后，我能听到，或者说无意中听到，一种语调，一种有节奏的话语，优美而陌生。 “行动”开始了：对我来说，它似乎更加晦涩难懂，因为在那些日子里，当我自己读书时，我经常在翻页时梦见一些完全不同的东西。当妈妈大声朗读给我听时，她忽略了所有的爱情场景，这一事实进一步增加了我对这个故事的了解。因此，磨坊主的妻子和男孩之间的关系中发生的所有奇怪的变化，只有爱情的诞生和成长才能解释的变化，在我看来似乎陷入了一个谜团中，其中的关键（正如我所能理解的那样）很容易相信）存在于查姆皮这个奇怪而悦耳的名字中，我不知道为什么，这个名字给拥有这个名字的男孩披上了它自己的明亮色彩，紫色而迷人。 即使我的母亲不是一个忠实的读者，但她在阅读一部作品时仍然令人钦佩，她在作品中通过她令人尊敬的简单解释和她甜美温柔的声音找到了真实的感情。在她的日常生活中也是如此，她所同情或钦佩的不是艺术作品，而是男人和女人：看到她以怎样的尊重从她的声音、她的手势、从她的整体中消除，真是令人感动。谈话时而充满欢乐的气氛，这可能会让一些很久以前失去孩子的母亲感到痛苦，时而回忆起某件事或周年纪念日，这可能会让某位老绅士想起他这些年的负担，时而谈论家庭话题，这可能会引起人们的注意。令一些年轻的文人感到厌烦。因此，当她大声朗读乔治·桑的散文时，这些散文处处让人想起妈妈从祖母那里学到的慷慨和道德品质，这些品质高于生活中的所有其他品质，而我直到很长时间才教她这些品质。后来，以同样的方式，不再将文学的其他品质置于首位；她煞费苦心地从她的声音中消除任何可能阻碍强有力的语言通道的弱点或矫揉造作，她提供了所有自然的温柔，所有他们所要求的奢华的甜蜜，这些短语似乎是为她的声音而创作的，可以说，这一切都在她的范围内。 她以他们所需要的语气来到他们面前，带着他们之前存在的亲切口音，口授他们，但在文字本身中找不到这种口音，通过这些方式，她在继续读下去时，平息了气氛，动词时态可能存在任何粗暴或不和谐，从而赋予不完美和过时的事物以慷慨中的所有甜蜜，以及爱情中的所有忧郁；将即将结束的句子引向即将开始的句子，音节的节奏时而加快，时而放慢，以便使它们尽管数量不同，形成统一的节奏，并为这相当平常的事情注入了气息。散文是一种生活，绵绵不断，充满感情。

My agony was soothed; I let myself be borne upon the current of this gentle night on which I had my mother by my side. I knew that such a night could not be repeated; that the strongest desire I had in the world, namely, to keep my mother in my room through the sad hours of darkness, ran too much counter to general requirements and to the wishes of others for such a concession as had been granted me this evening to be anything but a rare and casual exception. To-morrow night I should again be the victim of anguish and Mamma would not stay by my side. But when these storms of anguish grew calm I could no longer realise their existence; besides, tomorrow evening was still a long way off; I reminded myself that I should still have time to think about things, albeit that remission of time could bring me no access of power, albeit the coming event was in no way dependent upon the exercise of my will, and seemed not quite inevitable only because it was still separated from me by this short interval.
我的痛苦得到了缓解；我让自己沉浸在这个温柔的夜晚的潮流中，母亲在我身边。我知道这样的夜晚不能再重来；我在世界上最强烈的愿望，即让我的母亲在我的房间里度过悲伤的黑暗时光，与一般要求和其他人对今晚给予我的让步的愿望背道而驰绝非罕见和偶然的例外。明天晚上我将再次成为痛苦的受害者，而妈妈不会留在我身边。但当这些痛苦的风暴平静下来时，我就不再意识到它们的存在；此外，距离明天晚上还有很长的路要走。我提醒自己，我应该还有时间去思考事情，尽管时间的宽裕并不能让我获得力量，尽管即将发生的事情绝不取决于我意志的运用，而且似乎也不是完全不可避免的，只是因为它仍然和我隔着这么短的距离。

*****

And so it was that, for a long time afterwards, when I lay awake at night and revived old memories of Combray, I saw no more of it than this sort of luminous panel, sharply defined against a vague and shadowy background, like the panels which a Bengal fire or some electric sign will illuminate and dissect from the front of a building the other parts of which remain plunged in darkness: broad enough at its base, the little parlour, the dining-room, the alluring shadows of the path along which would come M. Swann, the unconscious author of my sufferings, the hall through which I would journey to the first step of that staircase, so hard to climb, which constituted, all by itself, the tapering ‘elevation’ of an irregular pyramid; and, at the summit, my bedroom, with the little passage through whose glazed door Mamma would enter; in a word, seen always at the same evening hour, isolated from all its possible surroundings, detached and solitary against its shadowy background, the bare minimum of scenery necessary (like the setting one sees printed at the head of an old play, for its performance in the provinces) to the drama of my undressing, as though all Combray had consisted of but two floors joined by a slender staircase, and as though there had been no time there but seven o’clock at night. I must own that I could have assured any questioner that Combray did include other scenes and did exist at other hours than these. But since the facts which I should then have recalled would have been prompted only by an exercise of the will, by my intellectual memory, and since the pictures which that kind of memory shews us of the past preserve nothing of the past itself, I should never have had any wish to ponder over this residue of Combray. To me it was in reality all dead.
就这样，在之后的很长一段时间里，当我在夜里醒着，唤起对贡布雷的旧记忆时，我看到的只是这种发光的面板，在模糊和阴暗的背景下清晰可见，就像面板一样孟加拉的火或某种电子标志会从建筑物的前面照亮并剖析它，而建筑物的其他部分仍然陷入黑暗中：它的底部足够宽，小客厅，餐厅，沿途小路迷人的阴影斯旺先生，我的痛苦的无意识制造者，我将通过这个大厅到达那个楼梯的第一步，很难爬，它本身就构成了一个不规则金字塔的逐渐变细的“高度” ;在山顶，是我的卧室，有一条小通道，妈妈可以通过它的玻璃门进入。总而言之，总是在同一晚的时间看到，与所有可能的环境隔绝，在阴暗的背景下分离和孤独，所需的最低限度的风景（就像人们在一部老戏剧的开头看到的场景一样，因为它的在我脱衣服的戏剧性表演中，好像整个贡布雷只有两层楼，中间有一个细长的楼梯，好像除了晚上七点钟之外，那里没有时间。我必须承认，我可以向任何提问者保证，康布雷确实包含了其他场景，并且确实存在于除这些之外的其他时间。但是，由于我当时应该回忆起的事实只能通过意志的运用、通过我的智力记忆来促使，而且由于那种记忆向我们展示的过去的画面没有保留过去本身，所以我应该从来没有想过去思考贡布雷的这一残余。对我来说，它实际上已经全部死了。

Permanently dead? Very possibly.
永久死亡？很有可能。

There is a large element of hazard in these matters, and a second hazard, that of our own death, often prevents us from awaiting for any length of time the favours of the first.
这些事情中存在很大的危险因素，而第二个危险，即我们自己的死亡，常常使我们无法等待第一个危险的任何时间。

I feel that there is much to be said for the Celtic belief that the souls of those whom we have lost are held captive in some inferior being, in an animal, in a plant, in some inanimate object, and so effectively lost to us until the day (which to many never comes) when we happen to pass by the tree or to obtain possession of the object which forms their prison. Then they start and tremble, they call us by our name, and as soon as we have recognised their voice the spell is broken. We have delivered them: they have overcome death and return to share our life.
我觉得凯尔特人的信仰有很多话要说，即我们失去的那些人的灵魂被囚禁在某种低等生物中，在动物、植物、某种无生命的物体中，因此实际上已经失去了我们，直到当我们碰巧路过那棵树或获得构成他们监狱的物体的那一天（对许多人来说永远不会到来）。然后他们开始颤抖，他们叫我们的名字，一旦我们认出他们的声音，咒语就被打破了。我们拯救了他们：他们已经克服了死亡并回来分享我们的生活。

And so it is with our own past. It is a labour in vain to attempt to recapture it: all the efforts of our intellect must prove futile. The past is hidden somewhere outside the realm, beyond the reach of intellect, in some material object (in the sensation which that material object will give us) which we do not suspect. And as for that object, it depends on chance whether we come upon it or not before we ourselves must die.
我们自己的过去也是如此。试图重新夺回它是徒劳的：我们智力的所有努力都必定是徒劳的。过去隐藏在领域之外的某个地方，超出了智力的范围，隐藏在我们不怀疑的某些物质对象中（在该物质对象将给我们带来的感觉中）。至于那个物体，在我们自己必死之前能否遇到它取决于机会。

Many years had elapsed during which nothing of Combray, save what was comprised in the theatre and the drama of my going to bed there, had any existence for me, when one day in winter, as I came home, my mother, seeing that I was cold, offered me some tea, a thing I did not ordinarily take. I declined at first, and then, for no particular reason, changed my mind. She sent out for one of those short, plump little cakes called ‘petites madeleines,’ which look as though they had been moulded in the fluted scallop of a pilgrim’s shell. And soon, mechanically, weary after a dull day with the prospect of a depressing morrow, I raised to my lips a spoonful of the tea in which I had soaked a morsel of the cake. No sooner had the warm liquid, and the crumbs with it, touched my palate than a shudder ran through my whole body, and I stopped, intent upon the extraordinary changes that were taking place. An exquisite pleasure had invaded my senses, but individual, detached, with no suggestion of its origin. And at once the vicissitudes of life had become indifferent to me, its disasters innocuous, its brevity illusory—this new sensation having had on me the effect which love has of filling me with a precious essence; or rather this essence was not in me, it was myself. I had ceased now to feel mediocre, accidental, mortal. Whence could it have come to me, this all-powerful joy? I was conscious that it was connected with the taste of tea and cake, but that it infinitely transcended those savours, could not, indeed, be of the same nature as theirs. Whence did it come? What did it signify? How could I seize upon and define it?
许多年过去了，除了剧院里的内容和我在那里睡觉的戏剧之外，贡布雷的一切对我来说都不再存在，当冬天的一天，当我回到家时，我的母亲看到我天冷了，给我倒了一些茶，这是我平时不喝的。我一开始拒绝了，后来无缘无故地改变了主意。她派人去买了一种又矮又胖的小蛋糕，叫做“小玛德琳蛋糕”，看起来就像是用朝圣者贝壳的凹槽扇贝模制而成的。很快，我机械地、疲惫地度过了沉闷的一天，并期待着明天的沮丧，我将一勺茶举到唇边，茶里泡了一小块蛋糕。温热的液体和面包屑一接触到我的上颚，我的全身就一阵颤抖，我停了下来，专注于正在发生的非凡变化。一种美妙的快乐侵入了我的感官，但这种快乐是单独的、超然的，没有任何迹象表明它的起源。立刻，生活的沧桑对我变得漠不关心，它的灾难无伤大雅，它的短暂是虚幻的——这种新的感觉对我产生了爱的效果，让我充满了宝贵的本质;或者更确切地说，这个本质并不在我身上，而是我自己。我现在不再觉得自己平庸、偶然、凡人。这种全能的喜悦从何而来？我意识到它与茶和糕点的味道有关，但它无限地超越了这些味道，确实不可能与它们具有相同的性质。它从哪里来？这意味着什么？我该如何抓住并定义它？

I drink a second mouthful, in which I find nothing more than in the first, a third, which gives me rather less than the second. It is time to stop; the potion is losing its magic. It is plain that the object of my quest, the truth, lies not in the cup but in myself. The tea has called up in me, but does not itself understand, and can only repeat indefinitely with a gradual loss of strength, the same testimony; which I, too, cannot interpret, though I hope at least to be able to call upon the tea for it again and to find it there presently, intact and at my disposal, for my final enlightenment. I put down my cup and examine my own mind. It is for it to discover the truth. But how? What an abyss of uncertainty whenever the mind feels that some part of it has strayed beyond its own borders; when it, the seeker, is at once the dark region through which it must go seeking, where all its equipment will avail it nothing. Seek? More than that: create. It is face to face with something which does not so far exist, to which it alone can give reality and substance, which it alone can bring into the light of day.
我喝了第二口，与第一口相比，我什么也没发现，第三口却比第二口少得多。是时候停下来了；药剂正在失去魔力。显然，我追寻的对象——真理，并不在杯子里，而是在我自己身上。茶召唤了我，但它本身并不理解，只能无限地重复着同样的见证，逐渐失去力量；我也无法解释这一点，尽管我希望至少能够再次召唤茶，并立即在那里找到它，完好无损并可供我使用，以供我最终的启蒙。我放下杯子，审视自己的内心。这是为了它发现真相。但如何呢？每当心灵感觉自己的某些部分已经偏离了自己的边界时，这是多么不确定的深渊啊！当它，探索者，立刻成为它必须去寻找的黑暗区域，在那里它的所有装备都对它毫无用处。寻找？不仅如此：创造。它面对的是迄今为止还不存在的东西，只有它才能赋予它现实和实质，只有它才能将其带入光明之中。

And I begin again to ask myself what it could have been, this unremembered state which brought with it no logical proof of its existence, but only the sense that it was a happy, that it was a real state in whose presence other states of consciousness melted and vanished. I decide to attempt to make it reappear. I retrace my thoughts to the moment at which I drank the first spoonful of tea. I find again the same state, illumined by no fresh light. I compel my mind to make one further effort, to follow and recapture once again the fleeting sensation. And that nothing may interrupt it in its course I shut out every obstacle, every extraneous idea, I stop my ears and inhibit all attention to the sounds which come from the next room. And then, feeling that my mind is growing fatigued without having any success to report, I compel it for a change to enjoy that distraction which I have just denied it, to think of other things, to rest and refresh itself before the supreme attempt. And then for the second time I clear an empty space in front of it. I place in position before my mind’s eye the still recent taste of that first mouthful, and I feel something start within me, something that leaves its resting-place and attempts to rise, something that has been embedded like an anchor at a great depth; I do not know yet what it is, but I can feel it mounting slowly; I can measure the resistance, I can hear the echo of great spaces traversed.
我再次开始问自己它可能是什么，这种被遗忘的状态没有带来它存在的逻辑证据，但只有一种感觉，那就是它是一种幸福，它是一种真实的状态，在它的存在下还有其他意识状态。融化并消失。我决定尝试让它重新出现。我回想起我喝下第一勺茶的那一刻。我再次发现同样的状态，没有新鲜的光线照亮。我强迫自己的大脑再努力一点，去追踪并再次捕捉那转瞬即逝的感觉。为了避免任何事情干扰它的进程，我排除了所有障碍，所有无关的想法，我堵住耳朵，抑制对隔壁房间传来的声音的所有注意力。然后，我感觉我的头脑越来越疲惫，却没有任何成功的报告，我强迫它做出改变，去享受我刚刚拒绝的那种分心，去思考其他事情，在最高的尝试之前休息和恢复活力。然后我第二次在它前面清理出一块空地。我将第一口的味道放在我的脑海中，我感到我内心有某种东西开始了，某种东西离开了它的安息地并试图升起，某种东西已经像锚一样深深地嵌入了；我的身体里有一种东西在我的脑海里。我还不知道那是什么，但我能感觉到它正在慢慢上升；我可以测量阻力，我可以听到穿越广阔空间的回声。

Undoubtedly what is thus palpitating in the depths of my being must be the image, the visual memory which, being linked to that taste, has tried to follow it into my conscious mind. But its struggles are too far off, too much confused; scarcely can I perceive the colourless reflection in which are blended the uncapturable whirling medley of radiant hues, and I cannot distinguish its form, cannot invite it, as the one possible interpreter, to translate to me the evidence of its contemporary, its inseparable paramour, the taste of cake soaked in tea; cannot ask it to inform me what special circumstance is in question, of what period in my past life.
毫无疑问，在我内心深处如此悸动的一定是图像，是视觉记忆，它与那种味道联系在一起，试图追随它进入我的意识头脑。但它的斗争太遥远、太混乱；我几乎看不到无色的倒影，其中混合着无法捕捉的旋转混合的光芒四射的色调，我无法区分它的形式，无法邀请它作为唯一可能的解释者，向我翻译它同时代的证据，它不可分割的情人，蛋糕泡茶的味道；不能要求它告诉我有什么特殊情况，在我过去的生活中的什么时期。

Will it ultimately reach the clear surface of my consciousness, this memory, this old, dead moment which the magnetism of an identical moment has travelled so far to importune, to disturb, to raise up out of the very depths of my being? I cannot tell. Now that I feel nothing, it has stopped, has perhaps gone down again into its darkness, from which who can say whether it will ever rise? Ten times over I must essay the task, must lean down over the abyss. And each time the natural laziness which deters us from every difficult enterprise, every work of importance, has urged me to leave the thing alone, to drink my tea and to think merely of the worries of to-day and of my hopes for to-morrow, which let themselves be pondered over without effort or distress of mind.
它最终会到达我意识的清晰表面，这个记忆，这个古老的、死寂的时刻，同一时刻的磁力已经走到了如此远的地方，强求、扰乱、从我存在的最深处升起吗？我不能说。现在我感觉不到任何东西了，它已经停止了，也许又陷入了黑暗，谁能说它是否会从黑暗中升起呢？我必须十次重复这个任务，必须俯身于深渊。每一次，天生的懒惰阻止我们从事每一项困难的事业，每一项重要的工作，促使我把这件事放在一边，喝我的茶，只考虑今天的忧虑和我对今天的希望——明天，让我们不费力气或心烦意乱地思考自己。

And suddenly the memory returns. The taste was that of the little crumb of madeleine which on Sunday mornings at Combray (because on those mornings I did not go out before church-time), when I went to say good day to her in her bedroom, my aunt Léonie used to give me, dipping it first in her own cup of real or of lime-flower tea. The sight of the little madeleine had recalled nothing to my mind before I tasted it; perhaps because I had so often seen such things in the interval, without tasting them, on the trays in pastry-cooks’ windows, that their image had dissociated itself from those Combray days to take its place among others more recent; perhaps because of those memories, so long abandoned and put out of mind, nothing now survived, everything was scattered; the forms of things, including that of the little scallop-shell of pastry, so richly sensual under its severe, religious folds, were either obliterated or had been so long dormant as to have lost the power of expansion which would have allowed them to resume their place in my consciousness. But when from a long-distant past nothing subsists, after the people are dead, after the things are broken and scattered, still, alone, more fragile, but with more vitality, more unsubstantial, more persistent, more faithful, the smell and taste of things remain poised a long time, like souls, ready to remind us, waiting and hoping for their moment, amid the ruins of all the rest; and bear unfaltering, in the tiny and almost impalpable drop of their essence, the vast structure of recollection.
突然记忆又回来了。味道就像贡布雷的周日早上（因为那些早上我在教堂时间之前没有出去），当我去她的卧室向她道早安时，我姑姑莱奥妮过去常常吃玛德琳小面包屑的味道。给我，先把它浸入她自己的一杯真茶或酸橙花茶中。在我品尝小玛德琳蛋糕之前，我的脑海里没有任何记忆。也许是因为我在这段时间里经常在糕点师橱窗里的托盘上看到这样的东西，但没有品尝过它们，所以它们的形象已经脱离了贡布雷时代的束缚，取而代之的是最近的其他东西。或许是因为那些被长期遗弃和遗忘的记忆，现在什么也没有留下来，一切都散了。事物的形式，包括糕点的小扇贝壳的形式，在其严格的宗教褶皱下如此丰富的感性，要么被消灭，要么已经休眠太久，以至于失去了可以让它们恢复的扩张能力。他们在我意识中的位置。但是，当从遥远的过去开始，一切都不再存在时，在人死之后，在物破碎散之后，仍然，孤独，更加脆弱，但更具活力，更加虚无，更加执着，更加忠实，气味和味道事物在很长一段时间内保持平静，就像灵魂一样，准备提醒我们，在其余一切的废墟中等待和希望它们的时刻；并在其本质的微小而几乎不可触摸的一滴中坚定不移地承载着巨大的记忆结构。

And once I had recognized the taste of the crumb of madeleine soaked in her decoction of lime-flowers which my aunt used to give me (although I did not yet know and must long postpone the discovery of why this memory made me so happy) immediately the old grey house upon the street, where her room was, rose up like the scenery of a theatre to attach itself to the little pavilion, opening on to the garden, which had been built out behind it for my parents (the isolated panel which until that moment had been all that I could see); and with the house the town, from morning to night and in all weathers, the Square where I was sent before luncheon, the streets along which I used to run errands, the country roads we took when it was fine. And just as the Japanese amuse themselves by filling a porcelain bowl with water and steeping in it little crumbs of paper which until then are without character or form, but, the moment they become wet, stretch themselves and bend, take on colour and distinctive shape, become flowers or houses or people, permanent and recognisable, so in that moment all the flowers in our garden and in M. Swann’s park, and the water-lilies on the Vivonne and the good folk of the village and their little dwellings and the parish church and the whole of Combray and of its surroundings, taking their proper shapes and growing solid, sprang into being, town and gardens alike, from my cup of tea.
一旦我立刻认出浸泡在她的酸橙花汤中的玛德琳面包屑的味道，那是我姨妈以前给我的（尽管我还不知道，而且必须推迟很久才能发现为什么这段记忆让我如此高兴）街上那栋灰色的老房子，也就是她的房间所在，像剧院的布景一样拔地而起，与小亭子相连，通向花园，花园是在它后面为我父母建造的（隔离的面板，直到那一刻我才看到）；还有房子，城镇，从早到晚，无论天气如何，午饭前我被送去的广场，我过去办事的街道，天气好的时候我们走的乡间小路。就像日本人取乐一样，他们在瓷碗里装满水，然后将小纸屑浸泡在其中，在此之前，这些纸屑还没有特征或形状，但是，一旦它们变湿，就会伸展并弯曲，呈现出颜色和独特的形状，成为花朵、房屋或人，永久且可辨认，因此在那一刻，我们花园和斯旺先生的公园里的所有花朵，以及维冯纳河上的睡莲，还有村里的好人们，他们的小住所和教区教堂、整个贡布雷及其周边地区，都在我的茶中形成了适当的形状并变得坚固，城镇和花园都一样。

COMBRAY
康布雷

Combray at a distance, from a twenty-mile radius, as we used to see it from the railway when we arrived there every year in Holy Week, was no more than a church epitomising the town, representing it, speaking of it and for it to the horizon, and as one drew near, gathering close about its long, dark cloak, sheltering from the wind, on the open plain, as a shepherd gathers his sheep, the woolly grey backs of its flocking houses, which a fragment of its mediaeval ramparts enclosed, here and there, in an outline as scrupulously circular as that of a little town in a primitive painting. To live in, Combray was a trifle depressing, like its streets, whose houses, built of the blackened stone of the country, fronted with outside steps, capped with gables which projected long shadows downwards, were so dark that one had, as soon as the sun began to go down, to draw back the curtains in the sitting-room windows; streets with the solemn names of Saints, not a few of whom figured in the history of the early lords of Combray, such as the Rue Saint-Hilaire, the Rue Saint-Jacques, in which my aunt’s house stood, the Rue Sainte-Hildegarde, which ran past her railings, and the Rue du Saint-Esprit, on to which the little garden gate opened; and these Combray streets exist in so remote a quarter of my memory, painted in colours so different from those in which the world is decked for me to-day, that in fact one and all of them, and the church which towered above them in the Square, seem to me now more unsubstantial than the projections of my magic-lantern; while at times I feel that to be able to cross the Rue Saint-Hilaire again, to engage a room in the Rue de l’Oiseau, in the old hostelry of the Oiseau Flesché, from whose windows in the pavement used to rise a smell of cooking which rises still in my mind, now and then, in the same warm gusts of comfort, would be to secure a contact with the unseen world more marvellously supernatural than it would be to make Golo’s acquaintance and to chat with Geneviève de Brabant.
贡布雷在二十英里半径的远处，就像我们每年圣周到达那里时从铁路上看到的那样，只不过是一座教堂，它是这座城镇的缩影，代表着它，谈论着它，也为它服务。到了地平线，当它接近地平线时，在开阔的平原上，当牧羊人聚集他的羊时，它紧紧地裹住它长长的、黑色的斗篷，以避风，它的羊群的羊毛灰色的背部，这是它的一部分到处都是中世纪的城墙，其轮廓严格地呈圆形，就像原始绘画中的小镇一样。 居住在贡布雷有点令人沮丧，就像它的街道一样，这里的房屋是用乡下发黑的石头建造的，前面有台阶，山墙顶上向下投射出长长的阴影，光线昏暗，让人一看到就觉得很暗。太阳开始落山，客厅的窗帘拉开了。街道上刻有庄严的圣人名字，其中不少人出现在贡布雷早期领主的历史中，例如圣伊莱尔街、圣雅克街（我姨妈的房子就坐落在其中）、圣希尔德加德街，它穿过她的栏杆，还有圣埃斯普利特街，花园的小门就开在圣埃斯普利特街上。这些贡布雷街道存在于我记忆中如此遥远的四分之一中，它们所描绘的颜色与今天为我装饰的世界如此不同，事实上，它们中的一个和全部，以及高耸在它们之上的教堂现在对我来说，广场比我的魔法灯笼的投影更虚幻。有时我觉得能够再次穿过圣伊莱尔街，在Oiseau Flesché的老旅馆里订一间位于Oiseau街的房间，人行道上的窗户曾经散发出一股气味在同样温暖的安慰中，时不时地在我的脑海中浮现出烹饪的乐趣，这将是确保与看不见的世界的接触，这比结识戈洛并与吉纳维耶夫·德·布拉班特聊天更奇妙、超自然。

My grandfather’s cousin—by courtesy my great-aunt—with whom we used to stay, was the mother of that aunt Léonie who, since her husband’s (my uncle Octave’s) death, had gradually declined to leave, first Combray, then her house in Combray, then her bedroom, and finally her bed; and who now never ‘came down,’ but lay perpetually in an indefinite condition of grief, physical exhaustion, illness, obsessions, and religious observances. Her own room looked out over the Rue Saint-Jacques, which ran a long way further to end in the Grand-Pré (as distinct from the Petit-Pré, a green space in the centre of the town where three streets met) and which, monotonous and grey, with the three high steps of stone before almost every one of its doors, seemed like a deep furrow cut by some sculptor of gothic images in the very block of stone out of which he had fashioned a Calvary or a Crib. My aunt’s life was now practically confined to two adjoining rooms, in one of which she would rest in the afternoon while they, aired the other. They were rooms of that country order which (just as in certain climes whole tracts of air or ocean are illuminated or scented by myriads of protozoa which we cannot see) fascinate our sense of smell with the countless odours springing from their own special virtues, wisdom, habits, a whole secret system of life, invisible, superabundant and profoundly moral, which their atmosphere holds in solution; smells natural enough indeed, and coloured by circumstances as are those of the neighbouring countryside, but already humanised, domesticated, confined, an exquisite, skilful, limpid jelly, blending all the fruits of the season which have left the orchard for the store-room, smells changing with the year, but plenishing, domestic smells, which compensate for the sharpness of hoar frost with the sweet savour of warm bread, smells lazy and punctual as a village clock, roving smells, pious smells; rejoicing in a peace which brings only an increase of anxiety, and in a prosiness which serves as a deep source of poetry to the stranger who passes through their midst without having lived amongst them. The air of those rooms was saturated with the fine bouquet of a silence so nourishing, so succulent that I could not enter them without a sort of greedy enjoyment, particularly on those first mornings, chilly still, of the Easter holidays, when I could taste it more fully, because I had just arrived then at Combray: before I went in to wish my aunt good day I would be kept waiting a little time in the outer room, where the sun, a wintry sun still, had crept in to warm itself before the fire, lighted already between its two brick sides and plastering all the room and everything in it with a smell of soot, making the room like one of those great open hearths which one finds in the country, or one of the canopied mantelpieces in old castles under which one sits hoping that in the world outside it is raining or snowing, hoping almost for a catastrophic deluge to add the romance of shelter and security to the comfort of a snug retreat; I would turn to and fro between the prayer-desk and the stamped velvet armchairs, each one always draped in its crocheted antimacassar, while the fire, baking like a pie the appetising smells with which the air of the room, was thickly clotted, which the dewy and sunny freshness of the morning had already ‘raised’ and started to ‘set,’ puffed them and glazed them and fluted them and swelled them into an invisible though not impalpable country cake, an immense puff-pastry, in which, barely waiting to savour the crustier, more delicate, more respectable, but also drier smells of the cupboard, the chest-of-drawers, and the patterned wall-paper I always returned with an unconfessed gluttony to bury myself in the nondescript, resinous, dull, indigestible, and fruity smell of the flowered quilt.
我祖父的表弟——礼貌地说是我的曾祖母——我们曾经住在一起，她是莱奥妮姨妈的母亲，自从她的丈夫（我叔叔奥克塔夫）去世后，她就逐渐拒绝离开，先是贡布雷，然后是她在的房子。贡布雷，然后是她的卧室，最后是她的床；现在，他再也没有“下来”，而是永远处于悲伤、身体疲惫、疾病、痴迷和宗教仪式的无限状态中。她自己的房间俯瞰着圣雅克街，这条路延伸了很长一段路，一直延伸到大普雷区（与小普雷区不同，小普雷区是镇中心的一片绿地，三条街交汇处）。这座建筑单调而灰色，几乎每扇门前都有三座高高的石阶，看起来就像某个哥特式雕塑家在他用来制作加略山或婴儿床的那块石头上刻出的一道深深的沟槽。我姨妈的生活现在几乎被限制在两个相邻的房间里，下午她会在其中一间休息，而另一间则在晾晒。 它们是那种乡村秩序的房间（就像在某些气候下，整片空气或海洋被无数我们看不见的原生动物照亮或散发出香味一样）用它们自身特殊的美德、智慧所产生的无数气味来吸引我们的嗅觉。 ，习惯，整个秘密的生活系统，看不见的，丰富的和深刻的道德，他们的气氛解决了；确实闻起来很自然，并且像邻近乡村的环境一样着色，但已经人性化，驯化，封闭，精致，巧妙，清澈的果冻，混合了离开果园进入储藏室的当季水果，气味随年份而变化，但充实的家庭气味，用热面包的甜味弥补了白霜的刺鼻，闻起来像乡村时钟一样慵懒而准时，流浪的气味，虔诚的气味；欣喜于平静只会带来更多的焦虑，而欣喜于忙碌对于那些路过他们中间却没有生活在他们中间的陌生人来说，这是诗歌的深层源泉。 那些房间的空气中弥漫着静谧的芬芳，如此滋养、如此多汁，以至于我一进入它们，就会感到一种贪婪的享受，尤其是在复活节假期的第一个早晨，仍然寒冷，那时我可以品尝到更全面的是，因为我当时刚到达贡布雷：在我进去向姨妈祝愿之前，我会在外面的房间里等一会儿，那里的太阳，仍然是冬日的阳光，已经爬进温暖的房间。它本身就在火前，它的两个砖墙之间已经点燃了，整个房间和里面的所有东西都沾满了煤烟的味道，使这个房间就像人们在乡村找到的那些巨大的平炉之一，或者一个带顶篷的壁炉架之一在古老的城堡里，人们坐在下面，希望外面的世界正在下雨或下雪，希望一场灾难性的洪水能够为舒适的休养所带来庇护和安全的浪漫；我会在祈祷桌和印花天鹅绒扶手椅之间来回走动，每把椅子都披着钩针编织的反黑麦卡萨，而炉火像馅饼一样烤着，房间的空气中弥漫着令人垂涎欲滴的气味，浓浓的凝结着，早晨的露水和阳光的清新已经“升起”并开始“凝固”，使它们膨化，给它们上釉，给它们开槽，然后将它们膨胀成一个看不见但不是摸不着的乡村蛋糕，一个巨大的酥皮糕点，里面几乎没有等待品尝橱柜、抽屉柜和带图案壁纸的更坚硬、更精致、更体面但也更干燥的气味，我总是带着一种不承认的暴食回来，把自己埋在不起眼的、树脂般的、沉闷的东西里。 ，难消化，还有花被子的果香。

In the next room I could hear my aunt talking quietly to herself. She never spoke save in low tones, because she believed that there was something broken in her head and floating loose there, which she might displace by talking too loud; but she never remained for long, even when alone, without saying something, because she believed that it was good for her throat, and that by keeping the blood there in circulation it would make less frequent the chokings and other pains to which she was liable; besides, in the life of complete inertia which she led she attached to the least of her sensations an extraordinary importance, endowed them with a Protean ubiquity which made it difficult for her to keep them secret, and, failing a confidant to whom she might communicate them, she used to promulgate them to herself in an unceasing monologue which was her sole form of activity. Unfortunately, having formed the habit of thinking aloud, she did not always take care to see that there was no one in the adjoining room, and I would often hear her saying to herself: ‘I must not forget that I never slept a wink’—for ‘never sleeping a wink’ was her great claim to distinction, and one admitted and respected in our household vocabulary; in the morning Françoise would not ‘call’ her, but would simply ‘come to’ her; during the day, when my aunt wished to take a nap, we used to say just that she wished to ‘be quiet’ or to ‘rest’; and when in conversation she so far forgot herself as to say ‘what made me wake up,’ or ‘I dreamed that,’ she would flush and at once correct herself.
在隔壁房间，我能听到姨妈轻声自言自语。她从来不说话，除非声音很小，因为她相信她脑子里有什么东西坏了，飘浮在那里，她可能会因为说话太大声而取代它；但她从来不会长时间停留，即使是独自一人时，也不说什么，因为她相信这对她的喉咙有好处，并且通过保持那里的血液循环，可以减少她容易遭受的窒息和其他疼痛。 ;此外，在她过着完全惰性的生活中，她对自己的任何感觉都异常重视，赋予它们千变万化的普遍性，这使她很难保守秘密，而且，没有一个她可以与之交流的知己她常常通过不断的独白向自己传播它们，这是她唯一的活动形式。不幸的是，由于养成了大声思考的习惯，她并不总是留意隔壁房间里没有人，我经常听到她对自己说：“我不能忘记，我从来没有合眼过” ——因为“从不睡觉”是她杰出的标志，在我们的家庭词汇中得到承认和尊重；早上，弗朗索瓦丝不会“打电话”给她，而只是“来到”她身边。白天，当姨妈想小睡时，我们就说她想“安静”或“休息”；当她在谈话中忘记说“是什么让我醒来”或“我梦见了”时，她会脸红并立即纠正自己。

After waiting a minute, I would go in and kiss her; Françoise would be making her tea; or, if my aunt were feeling ‘upset,’ she would ask instead for her ‘tisane,’ and it would be my duty to shake out of the chemist’s little package on to a plate the amount of lime-blossom required for infusion in boiling water. The drying of the stems had twisted them into a fantastic trellis, in whose intervals the pale flowers opened, as though a painter had arranged them there, grouping them in the most decorative poses. The leaves, which had lost or altered their own appearance, assumed those instead of the most incongruous things imaginable, as though the transparent wings of flies or the blank sides of labels or the petals of roses had been collected and pounded, or interwoven as birds weave the material for their nests. A thousand trifling little details—the charming prodigality of the chemist—details which would have been eliminated from an artificial preparation, gave me, like a book in which one is astonished to read the name of a person whom one knows, the pleasure of finding that these were indeed real lime-blossoms, like those I had seen, when coming from the train, in the Avenue de la Gare, altered, but only because they were not imitations but the very same blossoms, which had grown old. And as each new character is merely a metamorphosis from something older, in these little grey balls I recognised green buds plucked before their time; but beyond all else the rosy, moony, tender glow which lit up the blossoms among the frail forest of stems from which they hung like little golden roses—marking, as the radiance upon an old wall still marks the place of a vanished fresco, the difference between those parts of the tree which had and those which had not been ‘in bloom’—shewed me that these were petals which, before their flowering-time, the chemist’s package had embalmed on warm evenings of spring. That rosy candlelight was still their colour, but half-extinguished and deadened in the diminished life which was now theirs, and which may be called the twilight of a flower. Presently my aunt was able to dip in the boiling infusion, in which she would relish the savour of dead or faded blossom, a little madeleine, of which she would hold out a piece to me when it was sufficiently soft.
