“请原谅，亲爱的朋友，去年你病得很重的时候，我在楼梯上从她身边经过。确实，我只见过她一会儿，而且你的楼梯很暗；但我看得很清楚，看出她是多么可爱。这位年轻的绅士有一双美丽的眼睛，还有这个，”她继续说道，用一根手指在额头下方画了一条线。 “告诉我，”她问我叔叔，“你的侄女女士是——；她的名字和你的名字一样吗？

‘He takes most after his father,’ muttered my uncle, who was no more anxious to effect an introduction by proxy, in repeating Mamma’s name aloud, than to bring the two together in the flesh. ‘He’s his father all over, and also like my poor mother.’
“他最像他的父亲。”我舅舅嘀咕道，他并不急于通过代理进行介绍，大声重复妈妈的名字，而是想让两个人真正走到一起。 “他完全就是他的父亲，也像我可怜的母亲。”

‘I have not met his father, dear,’ said the lady in pink, bowing her head slightly, ‘and I never saw your poor mother. You will remember it was just after your great sorrow that we got to know one another.’
“我没有见过他的父亲，亲爱的，”粉衣女士微微低着头说道，“我也从未见过你可怜的母亲。你会记得，正是在你经历了巨大的悲伤之后，我们才认识了彼此。”

I felt somewhat disillusioned, for this young lady was in no way different from other pretty women whom I had seen from time to time at home, especially the daughter of one of our cousins, to whose house I went every New Year’s Day. Only better dressed; otherwise my uncle’s friend had the same quick and kindly glance, the same frank and friendly manner. I could find no trace in her of the theatrical appearance which I admired in photographs of actresses, nothing of the diabolical expression which would have been in keeping with the life she must lead. I had difficulty in believing that this was one of ‘those women,’ and certainly I should never have believed her one of the ‘smart ones’ had I not seen the carriage and pair, the pink dress, the pearly necklace, had I not been aware, too, that my uncle knew only the very best of them. But I asked myself how the millionaire who gave her her carriage and her flat and her jewels could find any pleasure in flinging his money away upon a woman who had so simple and respectable an appearance. And yet, when I thought of what her life must be like, its immorality disturbed me more, perhaps, than if it had stood before me in some concrete and recognisable form, by its secrecy and invisibility, like the plot of a novel, the hidden truth of a scandal which had driven out of the home of her middle-class parents and dedicated to the service of all mankind which had brought to the flowering-point of her beauty, had raised to fame or notoriety this woman, the play of whose features, the intonations of whose voice, like so many others I already knew, made me regard her, in spite of myself, as a young lady of good family, her who was no longer of a family at all.
我感到有些失望，因为这位年轻女士与我在家里时不时见到的其他漂亮女人没有任何不同，尤其是我们一个表姐妹的女儿，我每年元旦都会去她家。只有穿得更好；除此之外，我叔叔的朋友也有同样敏捷而友善的目光，同样坦率而友好的态度。我在她身上找不到任何我在女演员照片中所欣赏的戏剧性外表的痕迹，也找不到与她必须过的生活相符的恶魔般的表情。我很难相信这是“那些女人”中的一个，当然，如果我没有看到那辆马车和一双、粉红色的裙子、珍珠项链，我绝对不会相信她是“聪明的女人”之一。我也意识到我叔叔只知道他们中最优秀的人。但我问自己，这位给了她马车、公寓和珠宝的百万富翁怎么能在把钱花在一个外表如此朴素、受人尊敬的女人身上找到乐趣呢？然而，当我想到她的生活一定是什么样子时，它的不道德行为也许比它以某种具体的、可识别的形式站在我面前更让我不安，因为它的秘密和隐形，就像小说的情节一样，一个丑闻的隐藏真相，这个丑闻被赶出了她的中产阶级父母的家，并致力于为全人类服务，这使她的美丽达到了巅峰，使这个女人名声大噪或臭名昭著，她的容貌、声音的语调，就像我已经认识的许多其他人一样，让我不由自主地将她视为一位出身名门的年轻女士，而她根本不再是一个家庭的人。

We had gone by this time into the ‘study,’ and my uncle, who seemed a trifle embarrassed by my presence, offered her a cigarette.
这时我们已经进入“书房”了，我的叔叔似乎对我的存在感到有点尴尬，递给她一支香烟。

‘No, thank you, dear friend,’ she said. ‘You know I only smoke the ones the Grand Duke sends me. I tell him that they make you jealous.’ And she drew from a case cigarettes covered with inscriptions in gold, in a foreign language. ‘Why, yes,’ she began again suddenly. ‘Of course I have met this young man’s father with you. Isn’t he your nephew? How on earth could I have forgotten? He was so nice, so charming to me,’ she went on, modestly and with feeling. But when I thought to myself what must actually have been the rude greeting (which, she made out, had been so charming), I, who knew my father’s coldness and reserve, was shocked, as though at some indelicacy on his part, at the contrast between the excessive recognition bestowed on it and his never adequate geniality. It has since struck me as one of the most touching aspects of the part played in life by these idle, painstaking women that they devote all their generosity, all their talent, their transferable dreams of sentimental beauty (for, like all artists, they never seek to realise the value of those dreams, or to enclose them in the four-square frame of everyday life), and their gold, which counts for little, to the fashioning of a fine and precious setting for the rubbed and scratched and ill-polished lives of men. And just as this one filled the smoking-room, where my uncle was entertaining her in his alpaca coat, with her charming person, her dress of pink silk, her pearls, and the refinement suggested by intimacy with a Grand Duke, so, in the same way, she had taken some casual remark by my father, had worked it up delicately, given it a ‘turn,’ a precious title, set in it the gem of a glance from her own eyes, a gem of the first water, blended of humility and gratitude; and so had given it back transformed into a jewel, a work of art, into something altogether charming.
“不，谢谢你，亲爱的朋友，”她说。 “你知道我只抽大公送我的烟。我告诉他，它们会让你嫉妒。”然后她从盒子里抽出香烟，上面刻着外语的金色铭文。 “啊，是的，”她突然又开口了。 ‘当然，我和你一起见过这个年轻人的父亲。他不是你的侄子吗？我到底怎么会忘记呢？他对我很好，很有魅力。”她谦虚而充满感情地继续说道。但当我心里想，这种粗鲁的问候实际上是什么（她说，这种问候是那么迷人）时，我，因为知道父亲的冷漠和矜持，感到震惊，仿佛对他的某些不礼貌行为感到震惊。过度的认可与他从未足够的和蔼可亲之间形成鲜明对比。从那以后，这些无所事事、辛勤工作的女性在生活中扮演的角色中最感人的方面之一给我留下了深刻的印象，她们奉献了所有的慷慨，所有的才华，以及她们对感伤之美的可转移的梦想（因为，像所有艺术家一样，她们从不努力实现这些梦想的价值，或者将它们封装在日常生活的四方形框架中），而他们的金子却毫无价值，为那些被摩擦、刮伤和生病的人塑造了一个精美而珍贵的环境。男人的精致生活。 正如这个人充满了吸烟室，我叔叔正在那里招待她穿着他的羊驼毛外套，她迷人的身材，她的粉红色丝绸连衣裙，她的珍珠，以及与大公的亲密关系所暗示的优雅，所以，在同样地，她接受了我父亲的一些漫不经心的评论，精心地对其进行了处理，给了它一个“转弯”，一个珍贵的头衔，在其中镶嵌了她自己眼睛里的一瞥的宝石，第一水的宝石，混合着谦卑和感恩；就这样，它被归还给他人，变成了一件珠宝、一件艺术品、一件完全迷人的东西。

‘Look here, my boy, it is time you went away,’ said my uncle.
“听着，我的孩子，你该离开了，”我叔叔说。

I rose; I could scarcely resist a desire to kiss the hand of the lady in pink, but I felt that to do so would require as much audacity as a forcible abduction of her. My heart beat loud while I counted out to myself ‘Shall I do it, shall I not?’ and then I ceased to ask myself what I ought to do so as at least to do something. Blindly, hotly, madly, flinging aside all the reasons I had just found to support such action, I seized and raised to my lips the hand she held out to me.
我站起来;我几乎无法抗拒亲吻粉红女士的手的欲望，但我觉得这样做就像强行绑架她一样大胆。当我对自己数着“我该做还是不该做？”时，我的心剧烈跳动，然后我不再问自己应该做什么，至少要做某事。我盲目地、热切地、疯狂地把我刚刚找到的所有支持这种行动的理由抛在一边，抓住她向我伸出的手，举到唇边。

‘Isn’t he delicious! Quite a ladies’ man already; he takes after his uncle. He’ll be a perfect ‘gentleman,’’ she went on, setting her teeth so as to give the word a kind of English accentuation. ‘Couldn’t he come to me some day for ‘a cup of tea,’ as our friends across the channel say; he need only send me a ‘blue’ in the morning?’
‘他不是很好吃吗！已经是个十足的女汉子了；他很像他叔叔。他会是一位完美的“绅士”，”她继续说道，咬紧牙关，让这个词有一种英国的重音。 “正如我们海峡对岸的朋友所说，有一天他就不能来找我‘喝杯茶’吗？”他只需要在早上给我发一张‘蓝色’就行了？”

I had not the least idea of what a ‘blue’ might be. I did not understand half the words which the lady used, but my fear lest there should be concealed in them some question which it would be impolite in me not to answer kept me from withdrawing my close attention from them, and I was beginning to feel extremely tired.
我根本不知道“蓝色”是什么。我听不懂这位女士所说的一半话，但我担心其中隐藏着一些问题，如果我不回答的话，那就太不礼貌了，这让我无法从他们身上撤回我的密切关注，我开始感觉到极度疲劳。

‘No, no; it is impossible,’ said my uncle, shrugging his shoulders. ‘He is kept busy at home all day; he has plenty of work to do. He brings back all the prizes from his school,’ he added in a lower tone, so that I should not hear this falsehood and interrupt with a contradiction. ‘You can’t tell; he may turn out a little Victor Hugo, a kind of Vaulabelle, don’t you know.’
'不，不;这是不可能的。”叔叔耸耸肩说道。 “他整天在家里忙碌；他还有很多工作要做。他从学校带回了所有奖品。”他低声补充道，这样我就不会听到这个谎言并用矛盾打断。 ‘你说不出来；他可能会变得有点维克多雨果，一种沃拉贝尔，你不知道吗？

‘Oh, I love artistic people,’ replied the lady in pink; ‘there is no one like them for understanding women. Them, and really nice men like yourself. But please forgive my ignorance. Who, what is Vaulabelle? Is it those gilt books in the little glass case in your drawing-room? You know you promised to lend them to me; I will take great care of them.’
“哦，我喜欢有艺术气质的人。”粉衣女士回答道。 “没有人像他们一样了解女性。他们，还有像你这样非常好的男人。但请原谅我的无知。沃拉贝尔是谁、什么？是客厅小玻璃柜里那些镀金的书吗？你知道你答应过把它们借给我；我会好好照顾他们。

My uncle, who hated lending people books, said nothing, and ushered me out into the hall. Madly in love with the lady in pink, I covered my old uncle’s tobacco-stained cheeks with passionate kisses, and while he, awkwardly enough, gave me to understand (without actually saying) that he would rather I did not tell my parents about this visit, I assured him, with tears in my eyes, that his kindness had made so strong an impression upon me that some day I would most certainly find a way of expressing my gratitude. So strong an impression had it made upon me that two hours later, after a string of mysterious utterances which did not strike me as giving my parents a sufficiently clear idea of the new importance with which I had been invested, I found it simpler to let them have a full account, omitting no detail, of the visit I had paid that afternoon. In doing this I had no thought of causing my uncle any unpleasantness. How could I have thought such a thing, since I did not wish it? And I could not suppose that my parents would see any harm in a visit in which I myself saw none. Every day of our lives does not some friend or other ask us to make his apologies, without fail, to some woman to whom he has been prevented from writing; and do not we forget to do so, feeling that this woman cannot attach much importance to a silence which has none for ourselves? I imagined, like everyone else, that the brains of other people were lifeless and submissive receptacles with no power of specific reaction to any stimulus which might be applied to them; and I had not the least doubt that when I deposited in the minds of my parents the news of the acquaintance I had made at my uncle’s I should at the same time transmit to them the kindly judgment I myself had based on the introduction. Unfortunately my parents had recourse to principles entirely different from those which I suggested they should adopt when they came to form their estimate of my uncle’s conduct. My father and grandfather had ‘words’ with him of a violent order; as I learned indirectly. A few days later, passing my uncle in the street as he drove by in an open carriage, Î felt at once all the grief, the gratitude, the remorse which I should have liked to convey to him. Beside the immensity of these emotions I considered tha merely to raise my hat to him would be incongruous and petty, and might make him think that I regarded myself as bound to shew him no more than the commonest form of courtesy. I decided to abstain from so inadéquate a gesture, and turned my head away. My uncle thought that, in doing so I was obeying my parents’ orders; he never forgave them; and though he did not die until many years later, not one of us ever set eyes on him again.
叔叔不喜欢借书，他什么也没说，把我领到了大厅里。我疯狂地爱着那个穿粉红衣服的女士，我用热情的吻覆盖了我老叔叔沾满烟草的脸颊，而他却很尴尬地让我明白（没有真正说出来）他宁愿我不要把这件事告诉我的父母我眼里含着泪水向他保证，他的善意给我留下了如此深刻的印象，有一天我一定会找到一种方式来表达我的感激之情。这给我留下了如此强烈的印象，以至于两个小时后，在一系列神秘的话语之后，我并没有让我的父母充分清楚地了解我被赋予的新重要性，我发现让他们更容易他们对我那天下午的访问有完整的记录，没有遗漏任何细节。我这样做并没有想过给叔叔带来任何不愉快。既然我不希望这样，我怎么会想到这样的事呢？我无法想象我的父母会在这次拜访中看到任何伤害，而我自己却没有看到任何伤害。在我们生活的每一天里，不会有某个朋友或其他人要求我们一定要向某个他无法写信的女人道歉；但是，我们却无法给他写信。难道我们没有忘记这样做吗，因为我们觉得这个女人不太重视我们自己没有的沉默？和其他人一样，我想象其他人的大脑是没有生命的、顺从的容器，对可能施加在他们身上的任何刺激没有特定反应的能力；我毫不怀疑，当我把在叔叔家相识的消息记在父母心里时，我应该同时向他们转达我自己根据介绍所做出的善意判断。 不幸的是，我父母在评估我叔叔的行为时所采用的原则与我建议他们采用的原则完全不同。我的父亲和祖父曾对他进行过暴力命令的“言语”；正如我间接了解到的。几天后，当我叔叔开着一辆敞篷马车在街上经过时，我立刻感受到了我本想向他传达的所有悲伤、感激和悔恨。除了这些巨大的情感之外，我认为仅仅向他脱帽是不协调和琐碎的，并且可能会让他认为我认为自己有义务向他展示只不过是最常见的礼貌形式。我决定放弃这种不恰当的举动，并把头转开。舅舅认为我这样做是听从了父母的吩咐；他从未原谅他们；尽管他直到许多年后才去世，但我们中没有人再见过他。

And so I no longer used to go into the little sitting-room (now kept shut) of my uncle Adolphe; instead, after hanging about on the outskirts of the back-kitchen until Françoise appeared on its threshold and an-nounced: ‘I am going to let the kitchen-maid serve the coffee and take up the hot water; it is time I went off to Mme. Octave,’ I would then decide to go indoors, and would go straight upstairs to my room to read. The kitchen-maid was an abstract personality, a permanent institution to which an invariable set of attributes assured a sort of fixity and continuity and identity throughout the long series of transitory human shapes in which that personality was incarnate; for we never found the same girl there two years running. In the year in which we ate such quantities of asparagus, the kitchen-maid whose duty it was to dress them was a poor sickly creature, some way ‘gone’ in pregnancy when we arrived at Com-bray for Easter, and it was indeed surprising that Françoise allowed her to run so many errands in the town and to do so much work in the house, for she was beginning to find a difficulty in bearing before her the mysterious casket, fuller and larger every day, whose splendid outline could be detected through the folds of her ample smocks. These last recalled the cloaks in which Giotto shrouds some of the allegorical figures in his paintings, of which M. Swann had given me photographs. He it was who pointed out the resemblance, and when he inquired after the kitchen-maid he would say: ‘Well, how goes it with Giotto’s Charity?’ And indeed the poor girl, whose pregnancy had swelled and stoutened every part of her, even to her face, and the vertical, squared outlines of her cheeks, did distinctly suggest those virgins, so strong and mannish as to seem matrons rather, in whom the Virtues are personified in the Arena Chapel. And I can see now that those Virtues and Vices of Padua resembled her in another respect as well. For just as the figure of this girl had been enlarged by the additional symbol which she carried in her body, without appearing to understand what it meant, without any rendering in her facial expression of all its beauty and spiritual significance, but carried as if it were an ordinary and rather heavy burden, so it is without any apparent suspicion of what she is about that the powerfully built housewife who is portrayed in the Arena beneath the label ‘Caritas,’ and a reproduction of whose portrait hung upon the wall of my schoolroom at Combray, incarnates that virtue, for it seems impossible, that any thought of charity can ever have found expression in her vulgar and energetic face. By a fine stroke of the painter’s invention she is tumbling all the treasures of the earth at her feet, but exactly as if she were treading grapes in a wine-press to extract their juice, or, still more, as if she had climbed on a heap of sacks to raise herself higher; and she is holding out her flaming heart to God, or shall we say ‘handing’ it to Him, exactly as a cook might hand up a corkscrew through the skylight of her underground kitchen to some one who had called down to ask her for it from the ground-level above. The ‘Invidia,’ again, should have had some look on her face of envy. But in this fresco, too, the symbol occupies so large a place and is represented with such realism; the serpent hissing between the lips of Envy is so huge, and so completely fills her wide-opened mouth that the muscles of her face are strained and contorted, like a child’s who is filling a balloon with his breath, and that Envy, and we ourselves for that matter, when we look at her, since all her attention and ours are concentrated on the action of her lips, have no time, almost, to spare for envious thoughts.
所以我不再去我叔叔阿道夫的小客厅（现在已经关着）；相反，在后厨房的外围徘徊，直到弗朗索瓦丝出现在门槛上并宣布：“我要让厨房女仆倒咖啡并接热水;我该去见夫人了。八度，”然后我会决定进屋，然后直接上楼到我的房间看书。厨房女仆是一个抽象的人格，一个永久的机构，一套不变的属性确保了在这个人格化身的一系列短暂的人类形状中的某种固定性、连续性和身份。因为连续两年我们都没有在那里找到同一个女孩。在我们吃了这么多芦笋的那一年，负责给芦笋穿衣服的厨房女仆是个可怜的病弱者，当我们到达康布雷过复活节时，她已经怀孕了，而且确实是这样。令人惊讶的是，弗朗索瓦丝允许她在城里跑这么多的差事，在家里做这么多的工作，因为她开始发现在她面前抬着这个神秘的棺材变得困难，棺材一天天变得越来越满，越来越大，其辉煌的轮廓可能是从她宽大的罩衫的褶皱中可以看出。最后这些让人想起乔托在他的画作中包裹一些寓言人物的斗篷，斯旺先生给了我这些画的照片。正是他指出了这种相似之处，当他询问厨房女仆时，他会说：“那么，乔托的慈善事业怎么样？”事实上，这个可怜的女孩，她的怀孕使她的每一部分都肿胀、粗壮，甚至到了她的脸，以及她脸颊垂直、方形的轮廓，确实明显地暗示了那些处女，如此坚强和男子气概，以至于看起来更像是主妇，在他们的美德在竞技场教堂中得到了化身。现在我发现帕多瓦的美德和恶习在另一个方面也与她相似。因为正如这个女孩的身材被她体内携带的附加符号放大了一样，她似乎并没有理解它的含义，也没有在她的面部表情中渲染出它的所有美丽和精神意义，但似乎带着它是一个普通且相当沉重的负担，因此，毫无疑问，这位身材魁梧的家庭主妇在竞技场上以“明爱”为标签，而我的墙上挂着她肖像的复制品，对此她的身份没有任何明显的怀疑。贡布雷的教室，体现了这种美德，因为任何慈善思想似乎都不可能在她粗俗而充满活力的脸上表达出来。通过画家巧妙的笔触，她将地球上所有的宝藏都翻倒在她的脚下，但就像她在压榨酒中踩葡萄以榨汁一样，或者更进一步，就好像她爬上了葡萄树一样。一堆麻袋，让自己举得更高；她正在向上帝伸出她燃烧的心，或者我们应该说“交给”他，就像厨师通过地下厨房的天窗将开瓶器递给某个打电话给她要的人一样从地面以上。 ‘英维迪亚’号，再一次，脸上应该露出嫉妒的表情。 但在这幅壁画中，这个符号也占据了如此大的位置，并以如此现实主义的方式表现出来。嫉妒嘴唇之间的蛇嘶嘶声如此巨大，完全充满了她张开的嘴巴，以至于她脸上的肌肉紧张扭曲，就像一个孩子用自己的呼吸填充气球，而嫉妒，我们就这一点而言，当我们看着她时，因为她和我们所有的注意力都集中在她嘴唇的动作上，所以我们几乎没有时间去产生嫉妒的想法。

Despite all the admiration that M. Swann might profess for these figures of Giotto, it was a long time before I could find any pleasure in seeing in our schoolroom (where the copies he had brought me were hung) that Charity devoid of charity, that Envy who looked like nothing so much as a plate in some medical book, illustrating the compression of the glottis or uvula by a tumour in the tongue, or by the introduction of the operator’s instrument, a Justice whose greyish and meanly regular features were the very same as those which adorned the faces of certain good and pious and slightly withered ladies of Combray whom I used to see at mass, many of whom had long been enrolled in the reserve forces of Injustice. But in later years I understood that the arresting strangeness, the special beauty of these frescoes lay in the great part played in each of them by its symbols, while the fact that these were depicted, not as symbols (for the thought symbolised was nowhere expressed), but as real things, actually felt or materially handled, added something more precise and more literal to their meaning, something more concrete and more striking to the lesson they imparted. And even in the case of the poor kitchen-maid, was not our attention incessantly drawn to her belly by the load which filled it; and in the same way, again, are not the thoughts of men and women in the agony of death often turned towards the practical, painful, obscure, internal, intestinal aspect, towards that ‘seamy side’ of death which is, as it happens, the side that death actually presents to them and forces them to feel, a side which far more closely resembles a crushing burden, a difficulty in breathing, a destroying thirst, than the abstract idea to which we are accustomed to give the name of Death?
尽管斯旺先生可能对乔托的这些人物表示钦佩，但过了很长一段时间，我才能够在我们的教室（挂着他给我带来的副本）看到没有慈善的慈善，嫉妒看起来就像是医学书中的盘子，说明舌头上的肿瘤对声门或悬雍垂的压迫，或者通过操作者的仪器的介绍，一位法官，他灰色而卑鄙的规则特征是非常典型的。与我过去在弥撒中看到的贡布雷某些善良、虔诚、略显枯萎的女士脸上的装饰一样，其中许多人早已加入了不公正的后备部队。但在后来的几年里，我明白了这些壁画的引人注目的陌生感和特殊的美感在于它们的象征在它们中所扮演的重要角色，而事实是这些壁画是被描绘的，而不是作为象征（因为象征的思想没有在任何地方表达出来） ），但作为真实的事物，实际感觉或物质处理，为它们的含义添加了更精确和更字面的东西，为它们所传授的教训添加了更具体和更引人注目的东西。即使是那个可怜的厨房女仆，我们的注意力也不是不断地被她肚子里装满的东西所吸引；她的肚子里装满了食物。同样地，在死亡的痛苦中，男人和女人的思想不也经常转向实际的、痛苦的、模糊的、内在的、肠道的方面，转向死亡的“阴暗的一面”吗？死亡实际上呈现给他们并迫使他们感受到的一面，这一面更像是一种沉重的负担、呼吸困难、毁灭性的干渴，而不是我们习惯于赋予死亡名称的抽象概念？

There must have been a strong element of reality in those Virtues and Vices of Padua, since they appeared to me to be as much alive as the pregnant servant-girl, while she herself appeared scarcely less allegorical than they. And, quite possibly, this lack (or seeming lack) of participation by a person’s soul in the significant marks of its own special virtue has, apart from its aesthetic meaning, a reality which, if not strictly psychological, may at least be called physiognomical. Later on, when, in the course of my life, I have had occasion to meet with, in convents for instance, literally saintly examples of practical charity, they have generally had the brisk, decided, undisturbed, and slightly brutal air of a busy surgeon, the face in which one can discern no commiseration, no tenderness at the sight of suffering humanity, and no fear of hurting it, the face devoid of gentleness or sympathy, the sublime face of true goodness.
帕多瓦的那些美德和恶习一定有很强的现实性，因为在我看来，它们就像怀孕的女仆一样充满活力，而她本人的寓言性也丝毫不亚于它们。而且，很有可能，一个人的灵魂缺乏（或表面上缺乏）参与其自身特殊美德的重要标志，除了其美学意义之外，还有一种现实，即使不是严格意义上的心理上的，至少也可以称为面相上的。 。后来，在我的一生中，当我有机会遇到，例如在修道院里，真正的实际慈善的圣人例子时，他们通常有一种忙碌的、坚决的、不受干扰的、略带残酷的气氛。外科医生的脸上，人们在看到受苦受难的人类时看不出任何怜悯、温柔，也没有害怕伤害它，这张脸上缺乏温柔或同情，一张真正善良的崇高面孔。

Then while the kitchen-maid—who, all unawares, made the superior qualities of Françoise shine with added lustre, just as Error, by force of contrast, enhances the triumph of Truth—took in coffee which (according to Mamma) was nothing more than hot water, and then carried up to our rooms hot water which was barely tepid, I would be lying stretched out on my bed, a book in my hand, in my room which trembled with the effort to defend its frail, transparent coolness against the afternoon sun, behind its almost closed shutters through which, however, a reflection of the sunlight had contrived to slip in on its golden wings, remaining motionless, between glass and woodwork, in a corner, like a butterfly poised upon a flower. It was hardly light enough for me to read, and my feeling of the day’s brightness and splendour was derived solely from the blows struck down below, in the Rue de la Curé, by Camus (whom Françoise had assured that my aunt was not ‘resting’ and that he might therefore make a noise), upon some old packing-cases from which nothing would really be sent flying but the dust, though the din of them, in the resonant atmosphere that accompanies hot weather, seemed to scatter broadcast a rain of blood-red stars; and from the flies who performed for my benefit, in their small concert, as it might be the chamber music of summer; evoking heat and light quite differently from an air of human music which, if you happen to have heard it during a fine summer, will always bring that summer back to your mind, the flies’ music is bound to the season by a closer, a more vital tie—born of sunny days, and not to be reborn but with them, containing something of their essential nature, it not merely calls up their image in our memory, but gives us a guarantee that they do really exist, that they are close around us, immediately accessible.
然后，当厨房女仆——不知不觉中，让弗朗索瓦丝的卓越品质变得更加光彩夺目，就像错误通过对比的力量增强了真理的胜利——喝了咖啡，而咖啡（据妈妈说）仅此而已。比热水还热，然后把不温不热的热水送到我们的房间，我会躺在床上，手里拿着一本书，在我的房间里，我的房间因努力捍卫脆弱的、透明的凉爽而颤抖。午后的阳光，在几乎关闭的百叶窗后面，然而，阳光的反射却设法从它金色的翅膀上溜进来，在玻璃和木制品之间，在一个角落里，一动不动，就像一只停在花朵上的蝴蝶。 天色还不足以让我阅读，我对这一天的明亮和辉煌的感觉完全来自于加缪（弗朗索瓦丝向加缪保证我的姨妈没有“休息”）在楼下的拉库雷街的敲击。 ”，因此他可能会发出噪音），在一些旧包装箱上，除了灰尘之外，实际上不会飞扬任何东西，尽管它们的喧闹声，在伴随着炎热天气的共鸣气氛中，似乎散布着一场雨血红色的星星；还有那些为了我的利益而表演的苍蝇，在他们的小型音乐会上，就像夏天的室内乐一样；与人类音乐的气氛截然不同，如果你碰巧在一个晴朗的夏天听到它，你总会想起那个夏天，苍蝇的音乐通过一种更接近的方式与季节联系在一起，更重要的纽带——诞生于阳光明媚的日子，不是重生，而是与它们一起重生，包含着它们本质的东西，它不仅唤起了我们记忆中的它们的形象，而且给了我们保证，它们确实存在，它们是就在我们周围，可立即到达。

This dim freshness of my room was to the broad daylight of the street what the shadow is to the sunbeam, that is to say, equally luminous, and presented to my imagination the entire panorama of summer, which my senses, if I had been out walking, could have tasted and enjoyed in fragments only; and so was quite in harmony with my state of repose, which (thanks to the adventures related in my books, which had just excited it) bore, like a hand reposing motionless in a stream of running water, the shock and animation of a torrent of activity and life.
我的房间里这种昏暗的清新之感，对于街道的光天化日之下，就像影子对于阳光一样，也就是说，同样明亮，它在我的想象中呈现出夏天的整个全景，如果我出去的话，我的感觉是这样的。行走，只能断断续续地品味和享受；因此，这与我的休息状态非常和谐，这种状态（多亏了我书中所涉及的冒险经历，刚刚激发了它）就像一只手一动不动地停在流水中，激流的冲击和活力的活动和生活。

But my grandmother, even if the weather, after growing too hot, had broken, and a storm, or just a shower, had burst over us, would come up and beg me to go outside. And as I did not wish to leave off my book, I would go on with it in the garden, under the chestnut-tree, in a little sentry-box of canvas and matting, in the farthest recesses of which I used to sit and feel that I was hidden from the eyes of anyone who might be coming to call upon the family.
但我的祖母，即使天气变得太热了，暴风雨，或者只是一场阵雨，在我们身上爆发，她也会过来求我出去。因为我不想放下我的书，所以我会在花园里的栗子树下，在一个用帆布和垫子搭建的小岗亭里继续看书，我常常坐在岗亭的最深处，感觉我被隐藏起来，看不到任何可能来拜访家人的人的眼睛。

And then my thoughts, did not they form a similar sort of hiding-hole, in the depths of which I felt that I could bury myself and remain invisible even when I was looking at what went on outside? When I saw any external object, my consciousness that I was seeing it would remain between me and it, enclosing it in a slender, incorporeal outline which prevented me from ever coming directly in contact with the material form; for it would volatilise itself in some way before I could touch it, just as an incandescent body which is moved towards something wet never actually touches moisture, since it is always preceded, itself, by a zone of evaporation. Upon the sort of screen, patterned with different states and impressions, which my consciousness would quietly unfold while I was reading, and which ranged from the most deeply hidden aspirations of my heart to the wholly external view of the horizon spread out before my eyes at the foot of the garden, what was from the first the most permanent and the most intimate part of me, the lever whose incessant movements controlled all the rest, was my belief in the philosophic richness and beauty of the book I was reading, and my desire to appropriate these to myself, whatever the book might be. For even if I had purchased it at Combray, having seen it outside Borange’s, whose grocery lay too far from our house for Françoise to be able to deal there, as she did with Camus, but who enjoyed better custom as a stationer and bookseller; even if I had seen it, tied with string to keep it in its place in the mosaic of monthly parts and pamphlets which adorned either side of his doorway, a doorway more mysterious, more teeming with suggestion than that of a cathedral, I should have noticed and bought it there simply because I had recognised it as a book which had been well spoken of, in my hearing, by the school-master or the school-friend who, at that particular time, seemed to me to be entrusted with the secret of Truth and Beauty, things half-felt by me, half-incomprehensible, the full understanding of which was the vague but permanent object of my thoughts.
然后我的想法，难道它们不是形成了一个类似的藏身之处，在它的深处，我觉得我可以把自己埋进去，即使我在看外面发生的事情，也可以保持隐形？当我看到任何外部物体时，我所看到的意识就会停留在我和它之间，将它包围在一个细长的、无形的轮廓中，阻止我直接接触物质形式；因为在我接触到它之前，它就会以某种方式挥发掉，就像一个白热的物体移向潮湿的物体，实际上从未接触到水分，因为它本身总是先有一个蒸发区。在那种布满不同状态和印象的屏幕上，当我阅读时，我的意识会悄悄地展开，从我内心最深处隐藏的愿望到在我眼前展开的完全外在的地平线景观。花园的脚下，从一开始就是我最永久和最亲密的部分，它不断运动的杠杆控制着所有其他部分，是我对我正在阅读的书的哲学丰富性和美丽的信念，也是我的信念。无论这本书是什么，我都希望将这些内容运用到自己身上。 因为即使我是在贡布雷买的，在博兰奇店外看到过它，博兰奇的杂货店离我们家太远，弗朗索瓦丝无法在那里做生意，就像她对加缪那样，但她作为文具商和书商更享受习俗；即使我看到了它，用绳子绑起来，固定在装饰着他门口两侧的月刊和小册子的马赛克中，这个门口比大教堂的门更神秘，更充满暗示，我也应该我注意到并在那里买了它，只是因为我认出这是一本在我看来受到校长或学校朋友好评的书，在那个特定的时间里，在我看来，他们似乎被托付了真与美的秘密，这些东西我一半能感觉到，一半不能理解，但对它的完全理解是我思想中模糊但永久的目标。

Next to this central belief, which, while I was reading, would be constantly a motion from my inner self to the outer world, towards the discovery of Truth, came the emotions aroused in me by the action in which I would be taking part, for these afternoons were crammed with more dramatic and sensational events than occur, often, in a whole lifetime. These were the events which took place in the book I was reading. It is true that the people concerned in them were not what Françoise would have called ‘real people.’ But none of the feelings which the joys or misfortunes of a ‘real’ person awaken in us can be awakened except through a mental picture of those joys or misfortunes; and the ingenuity of the first novelist lay in his understanding that, as the picture was the one essential element in the complicated structure of our emotions, so that simplification of it which consisted in the suppression, pure and simple, of ‘real’ people would be a decided improvement. A’real’ person, profoundly as we may sympathise with him, is in a great measure perceptible only through our senses, that is to say, he remains opaque, offers a dead weight which our sensibilities have not the strength to lift. If some misfortune comes to him, it is only in one small section of the complete idea we have of him that we are capable of feeling any emotion; indeed it is only in one small section of the complete idea he has of himself that he is capable of feeling any emotion either. The novelist’s happy discovery was to think of substituting for those opaque sections, impenetrable by the human spirit, their equivalent in immaterial sections, things, that is, which the spirit can assimilate to itself. After which it matters not that the actions, the feelings of this new order of creatures appear to us in the guise of truth, since we have made them our own, since it is in ourselves that they are happening, that they are holding in thrall, while we turn over, feverishly, the pages of the book, our quickened breath and staring eyes. And once the novelist has brought us to that state, in which, as in all purely mental states, every emotion is multiplied ten-fold, into which his book comes to disturb us as might a dream, but a dream more lucid, and of a more lasting impression than those which come to us in sleep; why, then, for the space of an hour he sets free within us all the joys and sorrows in the world, a few of which, only, we should have to spend years of our actual life in getting to know, and the keenest, the most intense of which would never have been revealed to us because the slow course of their development stops our perception of them. It is the same in life; the heart changes, and that is our worst misfortune; but we learn of it only from reading or by imagination; for in reality its alteration, like that of certain natural phenomena, is so gradual that, even if we are able to distinguish, successively, each of its different states, we are still spared the actual sensation of change.
在这个中心信念旁边，当我阅读时，它会不断地从我的内在自我到外部世界，走向发现真理的运动，接下来是我将参与的行动所激起的情感，因为这些下午充满了比一生中经常发生的更戏剧性和耸人听闻的事件。这些是我正在读的书中发生的事件。诚然，这些故事中的人物并不是弗朗索瓦丝所说的“真实的人”。但是，“真实”的人的快乐或不幸在我们心中激起的任何感情，只有通过这些人的心理图景才能被唤醒。欢乐或不幸；第一个小说家的聪明才智在于他的理解，因为图像是我们情感复杂结构中的一个基本元素，所以对它的简化，即纯粹而简单的对“真实”人的压制，是一个决定性的进步。一个“真实”的人，尽管我们可能深切地同情他，但在很大程度上只能通过我们的感官来感知，也就是说，他仍然是不透明的，提供了我们的情感没有力量举起的沉重负担。如果他遭遇不幸，我们只能在对他的完整认知中的一小部分中感受到任何情感；事实上，他也只能在他对自己的完整认知的一小部分中感受到任何情感。小说家的快乐发现是想到用非物质部分中的等价物来替代那些不透明的部分，即人类精神无法渗透的部分，即精神可以同化的东西。 此后，这种新生物秩序的行为和感受以真理的形式出现在我们面前并不重要，因为我们已经把它们变成了我们自己的，因为它们正在我们身上发生，它们被它们所束缚当我们狂热地翻动书页时，我们的呼吸急促，目光凝视。一旦小说家把我们带入这样一种状态，在这种状态下，就像在所有纯粹的精神状态中一样，每一种情感都会成倍增加十倍，在这种状态下，他的书可能会像一场梦一样扰乱我们，但这是一个更清晰的梦，而且是一个更清晰的梦。比我们在睡眠中获得的印象更持久；那么，为什么他在一个小时的时间里让我们释放了世界上所有的欢乐和悲伤，其中只有一些，我们应该花费我们现实生活中的数年时间来了解，而最敏锐的人，其中最强烈的部分永远不会向我们揭示，因为它们发展的缓慢过程阻止了我们对它们的感知。生活中也是如此；心变了，那是我们最大的不幸；但我们只能通过阅读或想象来了解它；因为实际上，它的变化就像某些自然现象一样，是渐进的，即使我们能够依次区分它的每一种不同状态，我们仍然无法感受到变化的实际感觉。

Next to, but distinctly less intimate a part of myself than this human element, would come the view, more or less projected before my eyes, of the country in which the action of the story was taking place, which made a far stronger impression on my mind than the other, the actual landscape which would meet my eyes when I raised them from my book. In this way, for two consecutive summers I used to sit in the heat of our Com-bray garden, sick with a longing inspired by the book I was then reading for a land of mountains and rivers, where I could see an endless vista of sawmills, where beneath the limpid currents fragments of wood lay mouldering in beds of watercress; and nearby, rambling and clustering along low walls, purple flowers and red. And since there was always lurking in my mind the dream of a woman who would enrich me with her love, that dream in those two summers used to be quickened with the freshness and coolness of running water; and whoever she might be, the woman whose image I called to mind, purple flowers and red would at once spring up on either side of her like complementary colours.
紧接着，但与人类因素相比，我自己的一部分明显不那么亲密，将会出现或多或少投射在我眼前的故事情节发生的国家的景色，这给我留下了更深刻的印象我的心灵比其他人更重要，当我从书本上抬起眼睛时，眼前所看到的实际风景。就这样，连续两个夏天，我坐在康布雷花园的炎热里，因当时正在读的书而感到病态，渴望那片山水之地，在那里我可以看到一望无际的景色。锯木厂，清澈的水流下面，豆瓣菜床上腐烂的木头碎片；附近，紫色和红色的花朵沿着矮墙散漫地聚集着。由于我心里一直潜藏着一个女人的梦想，她会用她的爱来充实我，所以那两个夏天的梦想常常随着流水的清新和凉爽而加速；无论她是谁，我脑海中浮现出的那个女人的形象，紫色的花朵和红色的花朵都会像互补色一样立即在她的两侧绽放。

This was not only because an image of which we dream remains for ever distinguished, is adorned and enriched by the association of colours not its own which may happen to surround it in our mental picture; for the scenes in the books I read were to me not merely scenery more vividly portrayed by my imagination than any which Combray could spread before my eyes but otherwise of the same kind. Because of the selection that the author had made of them, because of the spirit of faith in which my mind would exceed and anticipate his printed word, as it might be interpreting a revelation, these scenes used to give me the impression—one which I hardly ever derived from any place in which I might happen to be, and never from our garden, that undistinguished product of the strictly conventional fantasy of the gardener whom my grandmother so despised—of their being actually part of Nature herself, and worthy to be studied and explored.
这不仅是因为我们梦到的图像永远是独一无二的，并且被我们脑海中碰巧围绕在它周围的颜色所装饰和丰富，而不是它自己的颜色；而且因为它是由颜色组成的。因为我读过的书中的场景对我来说不仅是我的想象力所描绘的比贡布雷在我眼前展示的任何场景都更生动的场景，而且在其他方​​面都是同一类型的。由于作者对它们的选择，由于我的思想会超越并预见他的印刷文字的信仰精神，因为它可能正在解释一个启示，这些场景曾经给我留下了这样的印象——我的印象几乎从来没有从我可能碰巧在的任何地方，也从来没有从我们的花园中衍生出我祖母如此鄙视的园丁的严格传统幻想的平凡产物——它们实际上是大自然本身的一部分，值得成为研究和探索。

Had my parents allowed me, when I read a book, to pay a visit to the country it described, I should have felt that I was making an enormous advance towards the ultimate conquest of truth. For even if we have the sensation of being always enveloped in, surrounded by our own soul, still it does not seem a fixed and immovable prison; rather do we seem to be borne away with it, and perpetually struggling to pass beyond it, to break out into the world, with a perpetual discouragement as we hear endlessly, all around us, that unvarying sound which is no echo from without, but the resonance of a vibration from within. We try to discover in things, endeared to us on that account, the spiritual glamour which we ourselves have cast upon them; we are disillusioned, and learn that they are in themselves barren and devoid of the charm which they owed, in our minds, to the association of certain ideas; sometimes we mobilise all our spiritual forces in a glittering array so as to influence and subjugate other human beings who, as we very well know, are situated outside ourselves, where we can never reach them. And so, if I always imagined the woman I loved as in a setting of whatever places I most longed, at the time, to visit; if in my secret longings it was she who attracted me to them, who opened to me the gate of an unknown world, that was not by the mere hazard of a simple association of thoughts; no, it was because my dreams of travel and of love were only moments—which I isolate artificially to-day as though I were cutting sections, at different heights, in a jet of water, rainbow-flashing but seemingly without flow or motion—were only drops in a single, undeviat-ing, irresistible outrush of all the forces of my life.
当我读一本书时，如果我的父母允许我去参观书中所描述的国家，我应该会感到我正在朝着最终征服真理的方向取得巨大进步。因为即使我们有一种总是被自己的灵魂包围、包围的感觉，它仍然不像是一个固定的、不可移动的监狱；它似乎是一座牢笼。相反，我们似乎被它带走了，并且永远努力超越它，闯入这个世界，当我们在我们周围无休止地听到那种不变的声音时，我们会感到永远的沮丧，这种声音不是来自外界的回声，而是来自内部的振动的共振。我们试图在我们喜爱的事物中发现我们自己赋予它们的精神魅力；我们的幻想破灭了，并了解到它们本身是贫瘠的，缺乏在我们心目中由于某些观念的联想而具有的魅力；有时，我们会调动我们所有的精神力量，以一种闪闪发光的方式来影响和征服其他人，我们很清楚，这些人位于我们之外，我们永远无法接触到他们。因此，如果我总是想象我所爱的女人在我当时最渴望参观的任何地方；如果在我秘密的渴望中，是她吸引了我，为我打开了未知世界的大门，那么这不仅仅是简单的思想联想的冒险；不，那是因为我的旅行和爱情梦想都只是瞬间——今天我人为地将它们隔离开来，就像我在不同高度、在喷射的水流中切割剖面一样，彩虹闪烁，但似乎没有流动或运动——这些只是我生命中所有力量不可抗拒的单一的、坚定不移的、不可抗拒的爆发中的一滴滴。

And then, as I continue to trace the outward course of these impressions from their close-packed intimate source in my consciousness, and before I come to the horizon of reality which envelops them, I discover pleasures of another kind, those of being comfortably seated, of tasting the good scent on the air, of not being disturbed by any visitor; and, when an hour chimed from the steeple of Saint-Hilaire, of watching what was already spent of the afternoon fall drop by drop until I heard the last stroke which enabled me to add up the total sum, after which the silence that followed seemed to herald the beginning, in the blue sky above me, of that long part of the day still allowed me for reading, until the good dinner which Françoise was even now preparing should come to strengthen and refresh me after the strenuous pursuit of its hero through the pages of my book. And, as each hour struck, it would seem to me that a few seconds only had passed since the hour before; the latest would inscribe itself, close to its predecessor, on the sky’s surface, and I would be unable to believe that sixty minutes could be squeezed into the tiny arc of blue which was comprised between their two golden figures. Sometimes it would even happen that this precocious hour would sound two strokes more than the last; there must then have been an hour which I had not heard strike; something which had taken place had not taken place for me; the fascination of my book, a magic as potent as the deepest slumber, had stopped my enchanted ears and had obliterated the sound of that golden bell from the azure surface of the enveloping silence. Sweet Sunday afternoons beneath the chestnut-tree in our Combray garden, from which I was careful to eliminate every commonplace incident of my actual life, replacing them by a career of strange adventures and ambitions in a land watered by living streams, you still recall those adventures and ambitions to my mind when I think of you, and you embody and preserve them by virtue of having little by little drawn round and enclosed them (while I went on with my book and the heat of the day declined) in the gradual crystallisation, slowly altering in form and dappled with a pattern of chestnut-leaves, of your silent, sonorous, fragrant, limpid hours.
然后，当我继续从我意识中紧密相连的源头追踪这些印象的外在过程时，在我到达包围它们的现实地平线之前，我发现了另一种乐趣，即舒适地坐着的乐趣，品尝空气中的好闻气味，不受任何访客的打扰；当圣伊莱尔尖塔上响起一个小时的钟声时，我看着下午已经度过的时光一滴一滴地落下，直到我听到最后一声敲击声，这使我能够将总数加起来，之后接下来的沉默似乎在我头顶的蓝天上，预示着这一天的开始，这漫长的一段时间仍然允许我读书，直到弗朗索瓦丝正在准备的美味晚餐在我对英雄的艰苦追求之后，应该会增强我的力量和精神。我的书页。而且，当每个小时敲响时，我觉得自前一个小时以来只过去了几秒钟；最新的将把自己刻在天空的表面上，靠近它的前一个，我无法相信六十分钟可以被挤进他们两个金色人物之间组成的微小的蓝色弧线中。有时，这个早熟的时刻甚至会比上一个钟声敲响两下。肯定有一个小时我没有听到罢工的声音。已经发生的事情对我来说并没有发生；我的书的魅力，一种像最深沉的睡眠一样强大的魔力，阻止了我着魔的耳朵，并消除了笼罩着寂静的蔚蓝表面上那金铃的声音。 甜蜜的周日下午，在我们贡布雷花园的栗子树下，我小心翼翼地消除了我现实生活中的每一件平常的事件，取而代之的是在这片被活水浇灌的土地上进行奇怪的冒险和野心的职业生涯，你仍然记得那些当我想起你时，我的脑海中浮现出冒险和野心，你通过一点一点地把它们包围起来并把它们包含在逐渐的结晶中（当我继续写书时，天气的热度下降了），你体现并保留了它们。慢慢地改变形状，斑驳着栗叶的图案，代表着你沉默、铿锵、芬芳、清澈的时光。

Sometimes I would be torn from my book, in the middle of the afternoon, by the gardener’s daughter, who came running like a mad thing, overturning an orange-tree in its tub, cutting a finger, breaking a tooth, and screaming out ‘They’re coming, they’re coming!’ so that Françoise and I should run too and not miss anything of the show. That was on days when the cavalry stationed in Combray went out for some military exercise, going as a rule by the Rue Sainte-Hildegarde. While our servants, sitting in a row on their chairs outside the garden railings, stared at the people of Combray taking their Sunday walks and were stared at in return, the gardener’s daughter, through the gap which there was between two houses far away in the Avenue de la Gare, would have spied the glitter of helmets. The servants then hurried in with their chairs, for when the troopers filed through the Rue Sainte-Hildegarde they filled it from side to side, and their jostling horses scraped against the walls of the houses, covering and drowning the pavements like banks which present too narrow a channel to a river in flood.
有时候，在下午的中午，园丁的女儿会把我从书上拉下来，她像疯子一样跑过来，掀翻了盆里的一棵橘子树，割伤了一根手指，折断了一颗牙齿，并尖叫着“他们来了，他们来了！”这样我和弗朗索瓦丝也应该跑起来，才不会错过任何节目。那是驻扎在贡布雷的骑兵进行军事演习的日子，通常会经过圣希尔德加德街。当我们的仆人们坐在花园栏杆外的椅子上，盯着贡布雷的人们周日散步时，人们也从远处两栋房子之间的缝隙里盯着园丁的女儿看。车站大道，会发现头盔的闪光。然后仆人们拿着椅子匆匆走进去，因为当士兵们鱼贯而过圣希尔德加德街时，他们把街道从一边挤到另一边，他们推挤的马匹刮擦着房屋的墙壁，覆盖并淹没了人行道，就像河岸一样，现在也出现了。洪水中河道变窄。

‘Poor children,’ Françoise would exclaim, in tears almost before she had reached the railings; ‘poor boys, to be mown down like grass in a meadow. It’s just shocking to think of,’ she would go on, laying a hand over her heart, where presumably she had felt the shock.
“可怜的孩子们，”弗朗索瓦丝几乎在到达栏杆之前就泪流满面地喊道。 ‘可怜的孩子们，就像草地上的草一样被砍倒。想到这真是令人震惊，”她继续说道，并将一只手放在自己的心口上，想必她也曾在那里感受到了震惊。

‘A fine sight, isn’t it, Mme. Françoise, all these young fellows not caring two straws for their lives?’ the gardener would ask, just to ‘draw’ her. And he would not have spoken in vain.
“景色真美，不是吗，夫人。弗朗索瓦丝，所有这些年轻人都不关心自己的生命中有两根稻草吗？”园丁会问，只是为了“吸引”她。而且他的话也不会白说。

‘Not caring for their lives, is it? Why, what in the world is there that we should care for if it’s not our lives, the only gift the Lord never offers us a second time? Oh dear, oh dear; you’re right all the same; it’s quite true, they don’t care! I can remember them in ‘70; in those wretched wars they’ve no fear of death left in them; they’re nothing more nor less than madmen; and then they aren’t worth the price of a rope to hang them with; they’re not men any more, they’re lions.’ For by her way of thinking, to compare a man with a lion, which she used to pronounce ‘lie-on,’ was not at all complimentary to the man.
‘不关心他们的生命，是吗？为什么，如果这不是主永远不会第二次赐给我们的唯一礼物——我们的生命，那世界上还有什么是我们应该关心的呢？噢，亲爱的，噢，亲爱的；你还是对的；这是真的，他们不在乎！我还记得70年代的他们；在那些悲惨的战争中，他们不再害怕死亡；他们只不过是疯子；然后，它们就不值得用来悬挂它们的绳子的价格；他们不再是人了，他们是狮子了。”因为按照她的思维方式，将一个男人与一头狮子进行比较（她习惯将其发音为“lie-on”），这对男人来说根本不是一种恭维。

The Rue Sainte-Hildegarde turned too sharply for us to be able to see people approaching at any distance, and it was only through the gap between those two houses in the Avenue de la Gare that we could still make out fresh helmets racing along towards us, and flashing in the sunlight. The gardener wanted to know whether there were still many to come, and he was thirsty besides, with the sun beating down upon his head. So then, suddenly, his daughter would leap out, as though from a beleaguered city, would make a sortie, turn the street corner, and, having risked her life a hundred times over, reappear and bring us, with a jug of liquorice-water, the news that there were still at least a thousand of them, pouring along without a break from the direction of Thiberzy and Méséglise. Françoise and the gardener, having ‘made up’ their difference, would discuss the line to be followed in case of war.
圣希尔德加德街拐弯太急，我们无法看到远方有人靠近，只有通过车站大道上两栋房子之间的缝隙，我们才能看到新戴的头盔朝我们冲过来。 ，并在阳光下闪烁。园丁想知道是否还有很多人要来，而且他很渴，太阳照在他的头上。于是，突然间，他的女儿会像从一座被围困的城市中跳出来，出击，拐过街角，冒着生命危险一百次，重新出现，给我们带来一壶甘草——水，消息称仍有至少一千人从蒂贝日和梅塞格利斯的方向源源不断地涌来。弗朗索瓦丝和园丁“弥补”了分歧后，将讨论发生战争时应遵循的路线。

‘Don’t you see, Françoise,’ he would say. ‘Revolution would be better, because then no one would need to join in unless he liked.’
“你难道没有看到吗，弗朗索瓦丝，”他会说。 “革命会更好，因为这样就没有人需要加入，除非他愿意。”

‘Oh, yes, I can see that, certainly; it’s more straightforward.’
“哦，是的，我当然可以看到这一点；更简单。”

The gardener believed that, as soon as war was declared, they would stop all the railways.
园丁相信，一旦宣战，他们就会停止所有铁路。

‘Yes, to be sure; so that we sha’n’t get away,’ said Françoise.
“是的，当然； “这样我们就不会逃跑了。”弗朗索瓦丝说道。

And the gardener would assent, with ‘Ay, they’re the cunning ones,’ for he would not allow that war was anything but a kind of trick which the state attempted to play on the people, or that there was a man in the world who would not run away from it if he had the chance to do so.
园丁会同意，“是的，他们是狡猾的人”，因为他不允许战争只不过是国家试图对人民开的一种把戏，或者有一个人在战争中。如果有机会，他不会逃避这个世界。

But Françoise would hasten back to my aunt, and I would return to my book, and the servants would take their places again outside the gate to watch the dust settle on the pavement, and the excitement caused by the passage of the soldiers subside. Long after order had been restored, an abnormal tide of humanity would continue to darken the streets of Corn-bray. And in front of every house, even of those where it was not, as a rule, ‘done,’ the servants, and sometimes even the masters would sit and stare, festooning their doorsteps with a dark, irregular fringe, like the border of shells and sea-weed which a stronger tide than usual leaves on the beach, as though trimming it with embroidered crape, when the sea itself has retreated.
但弗朗索瓦丝会赶紧回到我姨妈身边，我会回到我的书本上，仆人们会在门外重新就座，看着尘土落在人行道上，士兵们的通过所引起的兴奋逐渐平息。在秩序恢复很久之后，异常的人潮将继续使康布雷的街道变得黑暗。在每一栋房子前面，即使是那些通常还没有“完工”的房子，仆人们，有时甚至是主人，都会坐在门口凝视着，用黑色的、不规则的边缘装饰他们的门阶，就像房子的边界一样。海水退去后，比平时更猛烈的潮水把贝壳和海草留在了海滩上，就像用绣花的绉纱装饰着海滩。

Except on such days as these, however, I would as a rule be left to read in peace. But the interruption which a visit from Swann once made, and the commentary which he then supplied to the course of my reading, which had brought me to the work of an author quite new to me, called Bergotte, had this definite result that for a long time afterwards it was not against a wall gay with spikes of purple blossom, but on a wholly different background, the porch of a gothic cathedral, that I would see outlined the figure of one of the women of whom I dreamed.
然而，除了这样的日子，我通常会安静地读书。但是斯万的一次来访打断了我的阅读过程，他随后对我的阅读过程进行了评论，这让我看到了一位对我来说很陌生的作家贝戈特的作品，这产生了这样一个明确的结果：很长一段时间后，我看到的不再是开满紫色花朵的墙壁，而是在完全不同的背景下，一座哥特式大教堂的门廊上，勾勒出我梦到的一位女性的轮廓。

I had heard Bergotte spoken of, for the first time, by a friend older than myself, for whom I had a strong admiration, a precious youth of the name of Bloch. Hearing me confess my love of the Nuit d’Octobre, he had burst out in a bray of laughter, like a bugle-call, and told me, by way of warning: ‘You must conquer your vile taste for A. de Musset, Esquire. He is a bad egg, one of the very worst, a pretty detestable specimen. I am bound to admit, natheless,’ he added graciously, ‘that he, and even the man Racine, did, each of them, once in his life, compose a line which is not only fairly rhythmical, but has also what is in my eyes the supreme merit of meaning absolutely nothing. One is
我第一次听到一位比我年长的朋友谈到贝戈特，我对他怀有强烈的钦佩，他是一位名叫布洛赫的宝贵青年。听到我承认我对十月之夜的喜爱，他突然爆发出一声号角般的笑声，并以警告的方式告诉我：“你必须克服对缪塞的恶趣味，绅士。他是一个坏蛋，是最坏的蛋之一，是一个相当可憎的样本。尽管如此，我还是不得不承认，”他和蔼地补充道，“他，甚至拉辛这个人，每个人在他的一生中，都曾经写过一句诗句，它不仅相当有节奏，而且还具有其中的内容。我眼中的无上功德毫无意义。一是

La blanche Oloossone et la blanche Camire,
La Blanche Oloossone 和 La Blanche Camire，

and the other
和另一个

La fille de Minos et de Pasiphaë.
米诺斯和帕西法埃的女儿。

They were submitted to my judgment, as evidence for the defence of the two runagates, in an article by my very dear master Father Lecomte, who is found pleasing in the sight of the immortal gods. By which token, here is a book which I have not the time, just now, to read, a book recommended, it would seem, by that colossal fellow. He regards, or so they tell me, its author, one Bergotte, Esquire, as a subtle scribe, more subtle, indeed, than any beast of the field; and, albeit he exhibits on occasion a critical pacifism, a tenderness in suffering fools, for which it is impossible to account, and hard to make allowance, still his word has weight with me as it were the Delphic Oracle. Read you then this lyrical prose, and, if the Titanic master-builder of rhythm who composed Bhagavat and the Lévrier de Magnus speaks not falsely, then, by Apollo, you may taste, even you, my master, the ambrosial joys of Olympus.’ It was in an ostensible vein of sarcasm that he had asked me to call him, and that he himself called me, ‘my master.’ But, as a matter of fact, we each derived a certain amount of satisfaction from the mannerism, being still at the age in which one believes that one gives a thing real existence by giving it a name.
在我非常亲爱的大师勒孔特神父的一篇文章中，它们被提交给我的判断，作为捍卫两个逃亡者的证据，他在不朽的众神眼中很讨人喜欢。因此，这是一本我现在没有时间阅读的书​​，看来是那位大人物推荐的书。他认为，或者他们告诉我，该书的作者，一位贝戈特，《先生》，是一位狡猾的抄写员，确实比田野里的任何野兽都更加狡猾。尽管他有时会表现出一种批判性的和平主义，一种对受苦愚人的温柔，对此我们无法解释，也很难原谅，但他的话对我来说仍然有分量，就像德尔菲神谕一样。那么，请给你读这篇抒情的散文，如果创作《博伽梵歌》和《马格努斯的利夫里耶》的泰坦尼克号节奏大师所说的话没有虚假的话，那么，在阿波罗的帮助下，你甚至可以品尝到，甚至你，我的主人，奥林匹斯山的芬芳欢乐。 ’他让我称呼他，他自己也称我为‘我的主人’，表面上是带着讽刺的口吻。但事实上，我们每个人都从这种矫揉造作中得到了一定程度的满足，还处于一个人相信通过给事物命名而赋予其真实存在的年龄。

Unfortunately I was not able to set at rest, by further talks with Bloch, in which I might have insisted upon an explanation, the doubts he had engendered in me when he told me that fine lines of poetry (from which I, if you please, expected nothing less than the revelation of truth itself) were all the finer if they meant absolutely nothing. For, as it happened, Bloch was not invited to the house again. At first, he had been well received there. It is true that my grandfather made out that, whenever I formed a strong attachment to any one of my friends and brought him home with me, that friend was invariably a Jew; to which he would not have objected on principle—indeed his own friend Swann was of Jewish extraction—had he not found that the Jews whom I chose as friends were not usually of the best type. And so I was hardly ever able to bring a new friend home without my grandfather’s humming the ‘O, God of our fathers’ from La Juive, or else ‘Israel, break thy chain,’ singing the tune alone, of course, to an ‘um-ti-tum-ti-tum, tra-la”; but I used to be afraid of my friend’s recognising the sound, and so being able to reconstruct the words.
不幸的是，我无法通过与布洛赫的进一步谈话来平静下来，在谈话中我可能坚持要求一个解释，当他告诉我那首优美的诗句时，我对他产生的怀疑（如果你愿意的话，我从中产生了疑问） ，期望的只是真相本身的揭示）如果它们完全没有任何意义，那就更好了。因为，碰巧的是，布洛赫没有再被邀请到家里来。起初，他在那里受到了很好的接待。确实，我的祖父发现，每当我对任何一个朋友产生强烈的依恋并把他带回家时，那个朋友总是犹太人；而当我对任何一个朋友产生强烈的依恋并把他带回家时，那个朋友总是犹太人。如果他没有发现我选择作为朋友的犹太人通常不是最好的类型，他原则上不会反对这一点——事实上，他自己的朋友斯旺有犹太血统。因此，每次带新朋友回家时，我的祖父都会哼唱《哦，我们祖先的上帝》，或者是《以色列，挣脱你的锁链》，当然，这首歌是独自对着一个人唱的。 'um-ti-tum-ti-tum，tra-la”；但我曾经害怕我的朋友认出声音，从而能够重建单词。

Before seeing them, merely on hearing their names, about which, as often as not, there was nothing particularly Hebraic, he would divine not only the Jewish origin of such of my friends as might indeed be of the chosen people, but even some dark secret which was hidden in their family.
在见到他们之前，仅仅听到他们的名字（关于这些名字，通常没有什么特别的希伯来语），他不仅会猜出我的朋友们可能确实是选民的犹太血统，甚至会猜出一些黑暗的人的血统。他们家族中隐藏的秘密。

‘And what do they call your friend who is coming this evening?’
“那么他们怎么称呼你今晚要来的朋友呢？”

‘Dumont, grandpapa.’
“杜蒙，爷爷。”

‘Dumont! Oh, I’m frightened of Dumont.’
‘杜蒙！哦，我害怕杜蒙。

And he would sing:
他会唱：

Archers, be on your guard! Watch without rest, without sound,
弓箭手们，要提高警惕！不休息、不发出声音地观看，

and then, after a few adroit questions on points of detail, he would call out ‘On guard! on guard,’ or, if it were the victim himself who had already arrived, and had been obliged, unconsciously, by my grandfather’s subtle examination, to admit his origin, then my grandfather, to shew us that he had no longer any doubts, would merely look at us, humming almost inaudibly the air of
然后，在熟练地问了几个细节问题后，他会喊道：“警惕！”或者，如果受害人本人已经到达，并在我祖父微妙的检查下无意识地被迫承认他的出身，那么我的祖父就会向我们表明他不再有任何怀疑，只会看着我们，哼着几乎听不见的空气

What! do you hither guide the feet Of this timid Israelite?
什么！你引导这个胆怯的以色列人到这里来吗？

or of
或的

Sweet vale of Hebron, dear paternal fields,
希伯伦甜蜜的山谷，亲爱的父辈田野，

or, perhaps, of
或者，也许，

Yes, I am of the chosen race.
是的，我是被选中的种族。

These little eccentricities on my grandfather’s part implied no ill-will whatsoever towards my friends. But Bloch had displeased my family for other reasons. He had begun by annoying my father, who, seeing him come in with wet clothes, had asked him with keen interest:
我祖父的这些小怪癖并不意味着他对我的朋友们有任何恶意。但布洛赫因为其他原因让我的家人不高兴。他一开始就惹恼了我父亲，父亲看到他穿着湿衣服进来，饶有兴趣地问他：

‘Why, M. Bloch, is there a change in the weather; has it been raining? I can’t understand it; the barometer has been ‘set fair.’’
“为什么，布洛赫先生，天气有变化吗？”下雨了吗？我无法理解；晴雨表已经“设定公平”。

Which drew from Bloch nothing more instructive than ‘Sir, I am absolutely incapable of telling you whether it has rained. I live so resolutely apart from physical contingencies that my senses no longer trouble to inform me of them.’
布洛赫的这句话最有启发性的莫过于“先生，我绝对无法告诉您是否下雨了”。我的生活如此坚决地远离了身体上的偶然事件，以至于我的感官不再费力地告诉我它们。

‘My poor boy,’ said my father after Bloch had gone, ‘your friend is out of his mind. Why, he couldn’t even tell me what the weather was like. As if there could be anything more interesting! He is an imbecile.’
“我可怜的孩子，”布洛赫走后父亲说道，“你的朋友疯了。”为什么，他甚至不能告诉我天气怎么样。好像还能有什么更有趣的事情一样！他是个低能儿。

Next, Bloch had displeased my grandmother because, after luncheon, when she complained of not feeling very well, he had stifled a sob and wiped the tears from his eyes.
接下来，布洛赫让我祖母很不高兴，因为午饭后，当她抱怨感觉不太舒服时，布洛赫强忍着抽泣，擦掉了眼中的泪水。

‘You cannot imagine that he is sincere,’ she observed to me. ‘Why he doesn’t know me. Unless he’s mad, of course.’
“你无法想象他是真诚的，”她对我说。 ‘为什么他不认识我。当然，除非他生气了。

And finally he had upset the whole household when he arrived an hour and a half late for luncheon and covered with mud from head to foot, and made not the least apology, saying merely: ‘I never allow myself to be influenced in the smallest degree either by atmospheric disturbances or by the arbitrary divisions of what is known as Time. I would willingly reintroduce to society the opium pipe of China or the Malayan kriss, but I am wholly and entirely without instruction in those infinitely more per-nicious (besides being quite bleakly bourgeois) implements, the umbrella and the watch.’
最后，当他吃午饭时迟到了一个半小时，从头到脚沾满了泥，惹恼了全家人，他并没有道歉，只是说：“我从来不让自己受到哪怕是最小程度的影响。”要么是通过大气扰动，要么是通过所谓的时间的任意划分。我愿意向社会重新介绍中国的鸦片烟斗或马来短剑，但我对那些极其有害（除了相当资产阶级之外）的工具、雨伞和手表完全没有任何指导。

In spite of all this he would still have been received at Combray. He was, of course, hardly the friend my parents would have chosen for me; they had, in the end, decided that the tears which he had shed on hearing of my grandmother’s illness were genuine enough; but they knew, either instinctively or from their own experience, that our early impulsive emo-tions have but little influence over our later actions and the conduct of our lives; and that regard for moral obligations, loyalty to our friends, patience in finishing our work, obedience to a rule of life, have a surer foundation in habits solidly formed and blindly followed than in these momentary transports, ardent but sterile. They would have preferred to Bloch, as companions for myself, boys who would have given me no more than it is proper, by all the laws of middle-class morality, for boys to give one another, who would not unexpectedly send me a basket of fruit because they happened, that morning, to have thought of me with affection, but who, since they were incapable of inclining in my favour, by any single impulse of their imagination and emotions, the exact balance of the duties and claims of friendship, were as incapable of loading the scales to my prejudice. Even the injuries we do them will not easily divert from the path of their duty towards us those conventional natures of which my great-aunt furnished a type: who, after quarrelling for years with a niece, to whom she never spoke again, yet made no change in the will in which she had left that niece the whole of her fortune, because she was her next-of-kin, and it was the ‘proper thing’ to do.
尽管如此，他仍然会在贡布雷受到接待。当然，我的父母很难为我选择他作为朋友。最后，他们认为他在听到我祖母生病时流下的眼泪是真诚的。但他们本能地或根据自己的经验知道，我们早期的冲动情绪对我们以后的行为和生活行为影响不大；对道德义务的尊重、对朋友的忠诚、完成工作的耐心、对生活规则的服从，在牢固形成和盲目遵循的习惯中拥有比这些短暂的兴奋（热情但毫无结果）更可靠的基础。他们更喜欢布洛赫，作为我自己的同伴，根据中产阶级道德的所有法则，男孩们不会给我超过适当的东西，男孩们不会意外地给我送一个篮子水果，因为那天早上，他们碰巧满怀感情地想到了我，但是，由于他们无法通过他们的想象力和情感的任何单一冲动，在义务和友谊的要求之间取得精确的平衡，因此他们无法对我产生好感。 ，对我的偏见来说，他们同样无法加载秤。即使是我们对他们造成的伤害，也不会轻易偏离他们对我们的责任，我的姨婆为他们提供了一种典型的传统性格：在与侄女争吵多年后，她再也没有和她说过话，但他们还是做出了让步。她把全部财产留给侄女的遗嘱没有改变，因为她是她的近亲，这是“正确的事情”。

But I was fond of Bloch; my parents wished me to be happy; and the insoluble problems which I set myself on such texts as the ‘absolutely meaningless’ beauty of La fille de Minos et de Pasiphaë tired me more and made me more unwell than I should have been after further talks with him, unwholesome as those talks might seem to my mother’s mind. And he would still have been received at Combray but for one thing. That same night, after dinner, having informed me (a piece of news which had a great influence on my later life, making it happier at one time and then more unhappy) that no woman ever thought of anything but love, and that there was not one of them whose resistance a man could not overcome, he had gone on to assure me that he had heard it said on unimpeachable authority that my great-aunt herself had led a ‘gay’ life in her younger days, and had been notoriously ‘kept.’ I could not refrain from passing on so important a piece of information to my parents; the next time Bloch called he was not admitted, and afterwards, when I met him in the street, he greeted me with extreme coldness.
但我很喜欢布洛赫；我的父母希望我幸福；我给自己设定的一些无法解决的问题，比如《米诺斯与帕西法埃的姑娘》中“毫无意义”的美丽，让我更加疲惫，让我更加不适，而在与他进一步交谈之后，我本应感到更加不适，尽管这些谈话可能是不健康的。似乎在我母亲的心里。如果不是因为一件事，他仍然会在贡布雷受到接待。当天晚上，吃过晚饭后，她告诉我（一个对我后来的生活影响很大的消息，让我一度快乐，然后更加不快乐），没有一个女人除了爱情以外什么都不想，而且有他们中没有一个人的抵抗力是男人无法克服的，他继续向我保证，他听到有无懈可击的权威人士说，我的姨婆本人在年轻时就过着“同性恋”的生活，而且臭名昭著。 “保留。”我忍不住把这么重要的信息传递给我的父母。布洛赫下次打电话时，他没有被录取，后来，当我在街上遇见他时，他以极其冷漠的态度向我打招呼。

But in the matter of Bergotte he had spoken truly.
但在贝戈特的问题上，他说的是实话。

For the first few days, like a tune which will be running in one’s head and maddening one soon enough, but of which one has not for the moment ‘got hold,’ the things I was to love so passionately in Bergotte’s style had not yet caught my eye. I could not, it is true, lay down the novel of his which I was reading, but I fancied that I was interested in the story alone, as in the first dawn of love, when we go every day to meet a woman at some party or entertainment by the charm of which we imagine it is that we are attracted. Then I observed the rare, almost archaic phrases which he liked to employ at certain points, where a hidden flow of harmony, a prelude contained and concealed in the work itself would animate and elevate his style; and it was at such points as these, too, that he would begin to speak of the ‘vain dream of life,’ of the ‘inexhaustible torrent of fair forms,’ of the ‘sterile, splendid torture of understanding and loving,’ of the ‘moving effigies which ennoble for all time the charming and venerable fronts of our cathedrals”; that he would express a whole system of philosophy, new to me, by the use of marvellous imagery, to the inspiration of which I would naturally have ascribed that sound of harping which began to chime and echo in my ears, an accompaniment to which that imagery added something ethereal and sublime. One of these passages of Bergotte, the third or fourth which I had detached from the rest, filled me with a joy to which the meagre joy I had tasted in the first passage bore no comparison, a joy which I felt myself to have experienced in some innermost chamber of my soul, deep, undivided, vast, from which all obstructions and partitions seemed to have been swept away. For what had happened was that, while I recognised in this passage the same taste for uncommon phrases, the same bursts of music, the same idealist philosophy which had been present in the earlier passages without my having taken them into account as the source of my pleasure, I now no longer had the impression of being confronted by a particular passage in one of Bergotte’s works, which traced a purely bi-dimensional figure in outline upon the surface of my mind, but rather of the ‘ideal passage’ of Bergotte, common to every one of his books, and to which all the earlier, similar passages, now becoming merged in it, had added a kind of density and volume, by which my own understanding seemed to be enlarged.
在最初的几天里，就像一首曲子会在人们的脑海中盘旋，很快就会让人发疯，但人们暂时还没有“抓住”它，我如此热爱的贝戈特风格的东西还没有出现。吸引了我的注意。确实，我无法放下我正在读的他的小说，但我想我只是对这个故事感兴趣，就像爱情的第一个黎明，当我们每天去某个地方遇见一个女人时。聚会或娱乐活动被我们想象中的魅力所吸引。然后我观察到他喜欢在某些地方使用罕见的、几乎古老的短语，其中隐藏的和声流动，作品本身包含和隐藏的前奏会激发和提升他的风格；也正是在这样的时刻，他开始谈论“生命的虚幻梦想”，“美丽形式的无穷无尽的洪流”，“理解和爱的贫瘠而辉煌的折磨”， “那些动人的雕像使我们大教堂迷人而庄严的正面永远显得高贵”；他将通过运用奇妙的意象来表达一整套对我来说是全新的哲学体系，我自然会将其灵感归因于开始在我耳边回响的竖琴声，这是一种伴奏。图像增添了一些空灵和崇高的东西。贝戈特的这些段落中的一个，我从其他段落中分离出来的第三或第四段，让我充满了一种喜悦，这是我在第一段中所尝到的微薄的喜悦无法比拟的，这种喜悦是我感觉自己在我灵魂的某个最深处的房间，深邃、完整、广阔，所有的障碍和隔阂似乎都被清除了。 因为所发生的事情是，虽然我在这篇文章中认识到了对不常见短语的同样的品味，同样的音乐爆发，同样的理想主义哲学，这些都出现在前面的段落中，而我没有将它们视为我的源泉。令人高兴的是，我现在不再有这样的印象：在贝戈特的一部作品中，有一个特定的段落在我的脑海中描绘出一个纯粹的二维轮廓，而是贝戈特的“理想的段落”，他的每一本书都有共同之处，所有早期的相似段落现在都融入其中，增加了一种密度和体积，由此我自己的理解似乎得到了扩大。

I was by no means Bergotte’s sole admirer; he was the favourite writer also of a friend of my mother’s, a highly literary lady; while Dr. du, Boulbon had kept all his patients waiting until he finished Bergotte’s latest volume; and it was from his consulting room, and from a house in a park near Combray that some of the first seeds were scattered of that taste for Bergotte, a rare-growth in those days, but now so universally acclimatised that one finds it flowering everywhere throughout Europe and America, and even in the tiniest villages, rare still in its refinement, but in that alone. What my mother’s friend, and, it would seem, what Dr. du Boulbon liked above all in the writings of Bergotte was just what I liked, the same flow of melody, the same old-fashioned phrases, and certain others, quite simple and familiar, but so placed by him, in such prominence, as to hint at a particular quality of taste on his part; and also, in the sad parts of his books, a sort of roughness, a tone that was almost harsh. And he himself, no doubt, realised that these were his principal attractions. For in his later books, if he had hit upon some great truth, or upon the name of an historic cathedral, he would break off his narrative, and in an invocation, an apostrophe, a lengthy prayer, would give a free outlet to that effluence which, in the earlier volumes, remained buried beneath the form of his prose, discernible only in a rippling of its surface, and perhaps even more delightful, more harmonious when it was thus veiled from the eye, when the reader could give no precise indication of where the murmur of the current began, or of where it died away. These passages in which he delighted were our favourites also. For my own part I knew all of them by heart. I felt even disappointed when he resumed the thread of his narrative. Whenever he spoke of something whose beauty had until then remained hidden from me, of pine-forests or of hailstorms, of Notre-Dame de Paris, of Athalie, or of Phèdre, by some piece of imagery he would make their beauty explode and drench me with its essence. And so, dimly realising that the universe contained innumerable elements which my feeble senses would be powerless to discern, did he not bring them within my reach, I wished that I might have his opinion, some metaphor of his, upon everything in the world, and especially upon such things as I might have an opportunity, some day, of seeing for myself; and among such things, more particularly still upon some of the historic buildings of France, upon certain views of the sea, because the emphasis with which, in his books, he referred to these shewed that he regarded them as rich in significance and beauty. But, alas, upon almost everything in the world his opinion was unknown to me. I had no doubt that it would differ entirely from my own, since his came down from an unknown sphere towards which I was striving to raise myself; convinced that my thoughts would have seemed pure foolishness to that perfected spirit, I had so completely obliterated them all that, if I happened to find in one of his books something which had already occurred to my own mind, my heart would swell with gratitude and pride as though some deity had, in his infinite bounty, restored it to me, had pronounced it to be beautiful and right. It happened now and then that a page of Bergotte would express precisely those ideas which I used often at night, when I was unable to sleep, to write to my grandmother and mother, and so concisely and well that his page had the appearance of a collection of mottoes for me to set at the head of my letters. And so too, in later years, when I began to compose a book of my own, and the quality of some of my sentences seemed so inadequate that I could not make up my mind to go on with the undertaking, I would find the equivalent of my sentences in Bergotte’s. But it was only then, when I read them in his pages, that I could enjoy them; when it was I myself who composed them, in my anxiety that they should exactly reproduce what I seemed to have detected in my mind, and in my fear of their not turning out ‘true to life,’ I had no time to ask myself whether what I was writing would be pleasant to read! But indeed there was no kind of language, no kind of ideas which I really liked, except these. My feverish and unsatisfactory attempts were themselves a token of my love, a love which brought me no pleasure, but was, for all that, intense and deep. And so, when I came suddenly upon similar phrases in the writings of another, that is to say stripped of their familiar accompaniment of scruples and repressions and self-tormentings, I was free to indulge to the full my own appetite for such things, just as a cook who, once in a while, has no dinner to prepare for other people, can then find time to gormandise himself. And so, when I had found, one day, in a book by Bergotte, some joke about an old family servant, to which his solemn and magnificent style added a great deal of irony, but which was in principle what I had often said to my grandmother about Françoise, and when, another time, I had discovered that he thought not unworthy of reflection in one of those mirrors of absolute Truth which were his writings, a remark similar to one which I had had occasion to make on our friend M. Legrandin (and, moreover, my remarks on Françoise and M. Legrandin were among those which I would most resolutely have sacrificed for Bergotte’s sake, in the belief that he would find them quite without interest); then it was suddenly revealed to me that my own humble existence and the Realms of Truth were less widely separated than I had supposed, that at certain points they were actually in contact; and in my new-found confidence and joy I wept upon his printed page, as in the arms of a long-lost father.
我绝不是贝戈特唯一的崇拜者。他是我母亲的一位朋友最喜欢的作家，她是一位非常有文学修养的女士。而杜博尔邦医生则让所有病人等待，直到他读完贝戈特的最新著作。正是从他的咨询室和贡布雷附近公园的一所房子里，播下了贝戈特的第一批种子，这在当时是一种罕见的植物，但现在已经普遍适应，人们发现它到处开花。整个欧洲和美洲，甚至在最小的村庄，其精致程度仍然罕见，但仅此而已。我母亲的朋友，以及杜布尔邦博士在贝戈特的作品中最喜欢的东西，似乎正是我所喜欢的东西，同样的旋律，同样的老式短语，以及其他某些东西，非常简单和简单。熟悉，但被他放在如此突出的位置，以暗示他具有特殊的品味品质；而且，在他的书中悲伤的部分，有一种粗糙，一种近乎严厉的语气。毫无疑问，他本人也意识到这些是他的主要吸引力。因为在他后来的书中，如果他偶然发现了一些伟大的真理，或者一座历史悠久的大教堂的名称，他就会中断他的叙述，并通过祈祷、撇号、冗长的祈祷，为他的叙述提供一个自由的出口。在早期的几卷书中，这些情感仍然埋藏在他的散文形式之下，只有在其表面的涟漪中才能辨别出来，当它被遮蔽在眼睛之外时，当读者无法给出精确的信息时，也许会更令人愉快、更和谐。指示电流杂音从何处开始或在何处消失。他喜欢的这些段落也是我们最喜欢的。就我而言，我对所有这些都了如指掌。 当他继续叙述他的故事时，我什至感到失望。每当他谈到一些至今仍对我隐秘之美的事物时，比如松树林或冰雹、巴黎圣母院、阿塔莉或费德尔，他都会通过一些意象让它们的美爆发和浸透。我及其本质。因此，我隐隐约约地意识到，宇宙包含着无数的元素，如果他没有把它们带到我的触手可及的范围内，我微弱的感官将无法辨别这些元素，我希望我能听听他对世界上一切事物的看法，他的一些隐喻，尤其是在某些事情上，有一天我可能有机会亲眼目睹；其中，更特别的是法国的一些历史建筑和某些海景，因为他在书中提到这些的重点表明，他认为它们具有丰富的意义和美丽。但是，唉，对于世界上几乎所有的事情，我都不知道他的看法。我毫不怀疑它会与我自己的完全不同，因为他来自一个未知的领域，而我正在努力提升自己的领域。我深信我的想法对于那个完美的灵魂来说似乎纯粹是愚蠢的，所以我完全把它们全部抹掉了，如果我碰巧在他的一本书中发现了我自己已经想到的东西，我的心会充满感激和感激。骄傲就好像某个神以其无限的慷慨将它恢复给了我，并宣称它是美丽的和正确的。 时不时地，贝戈特的一页恰好准确地表达了我在晚上睡不着的时候写信给祖母和母亲时经常使用的那些想法，而且如此简洁明了，以至于他的一页看起来像一本我收集的座右铭放在我信的开头。同样，在后来的几年里，当我开始写一本自己的书时，我的一些句子的质量似乎不够好，以至于我无法下定决心继续下去，我会找到同等的东西贝戈特的句子中我的句子。但直到那时，当我在他的书页中读到这些内容时，我才能够欣赏它们。当我自己创作它们时，我担心它们应该准确地再现我似乎在脑海中发现的东西，并且担心它们不会变得“真实”，我没有时间问自己是否我写的东西读起来会很愉快！但事实上，除了这些，没有一种语言、没有一种思想是我真正喜欢的。我狂热而不尽如人意的尝试本身就是我爱的象征，这种爱没有给我带来快乐，但尽管如此，却是强烈而深刻的。因此，当我突然在别人的著作中看到类似的短语时，也就是说，去掉了它们熟悉的顾忌、压抑和自我折磨的伴奏，我可以自由地尽情地满足自己对此类事物的胃口，只是作为一个厨师，偶尔没有时间为别人准备晚餐，那么他就可以找到时间来犒赏自己。 因此，有一天，当我在贝戈特的一本书中发现了一个关于一位老仆人的笑话时，他庄严而宏伟的风格给这个笑话增添了很大的讽刺意味，但这基本上是我经常对他说的话。我的祖母关于弗朗索瓦丝的事，还有一次，我发现他认为不值得在他的作品中的一面绝对真理的镜子中反思，这句话类似于我有机会对我们的朋友M说的一句话. 勒格朗丹（此外，我对弗朗索瓦丝和勒格朗丹先生的评论是我最愿意为了贝戈特而牺牲的评论之一，因为我相信他会发现他们毫无兴趣）；然后我突然发现，我自己卑微的存在和真理领域之间的距离没有我想象的那么远，在某些点上它们实际上是接触的；在我新获得的信心和喜悦中，我在他的印刷版上哭泣，就像在一位失散已久的父亲的怀里一样。

>From his books I had formed an impression of Bergotte as a frail and disappointed old man, who had lost his children, and had never found any consolation. And so I would read, or rather sing his sentences in my brain, with rather more dolce, rather more lento than he himself had, perhaps, intended, and his simplest phrase would strike my ears with something peculiarly gentle and loving in its intonation. More than anything else in the world I cherished his philosophy, and had pledged myself to it in lifelong devotion. It made me impatient to reach the age when I should be eligible to attend the class at school called ‘Philosophy.’ I did not wish to learn or do anything else there, but simply to exist and be guided entirely by the mind of Bergotte, and, if I had been told then that the metaphysicians whom I was actually to follow there resembled him in nothing, I should have been struck down by the despair a young lover feels who has sworn lifelong fidelity, when a friend speaks to him of the other mistresses he will have in time to come.
>从他的书中，我对贝戈特的印象是一个虚弱而失望的老人，他失去了孩子，从未找到任何安慰。因此，我会在脑海中读，或者更确切地说，唱他的句子，比他本人所希望的更加柔和，更加缓慢，他最简单的短语会以一种特别温柔和充满爱意的语调打动我的耳朵。我最珍视他的哲学，并承诺终生奉献。这让我迫不及待地想达到我应该有资格在学校上“哲学”课程的年龄。我不想在那里学习或做任何其他事情，而只是想存在并完全被贝戈特的思想所引导，而且，如果当时有人告诉我，我实际上要追随的形而上学家与他毫无相似之处，那么当一位年轻的恋人向一位发誓终身忠诚的年轻恋人谈论他的爱情时，我就会感到绝望。他很快就会有其他情妇。

One Sunday, while I was reading in the garden, I was interrupted by Swann, who had come to call upon my parents.
一个星期天，当我在花园里读书时，斯旺来拜访我的父母，打断了我。

‘What are you reading? May I look? Why, it’s Bergotte! Who has been telling you about him?’
'你在读什么？我可以看一下吗？为什么，这是贝戈特！谁跟你说过他的事？

I replied that Bloch was responsible.
我回答说布洛赫有责任。

‘Oh, yes, that boy I saw here once, who looks so like the Bellini portrait of Mahomet II. It’s an astonishing likeness; he has the same arched eyebrows and hooked nose and prominent cheekbones. When his beard comes he’ll be Mahomet himself. Anyhow he has good taste, for Bergotte is a charming creature.’ And seeing how much I seemed to admire Bergotte, Swann, who never spoke at all about the people he knew, made an exception in my favour and said: ‘I know him well; if you would like him to write a few words on the title-page of your book I could ask him for you.’
“哦，是的，我曾经在这里见过的那个男孩，他看起来很像贝利尼的穆罕默德二世肖像。真是惊人的相似。他有同样的拱形眉毛、鹰钩鼻和突出的颧骨。当他长出胡子时，他将成为穆罕默德本人。无论如何，他的品味很好，因为贝戈特是一个迷人的人。”看到我似乎多么崇拜贝戈特，斯万从不谈论他认识的人，破例对我有利，说：“我认识他出色地;如果你想让他在你书的扉页上写几句话，我可以请他帮你。

I dared not accept such an offer, but bombarded Swann with questions about his friend. ‘Can you tell me, please, who is his favourite actor?’
我不敢接受这样的提议，而是向斯旺提出了有关他朋友的问题。 “你能告诉我，他最喜欢的演员是谁吗？”

‘Actor? No, I can’t say. But I do know this: there’s not a man on the stage whom he thinks equal to Berma; he puts her above everyone. Have you seen her?’
'演员？不，我不能说。但我确实知道这一点：舞台上没有一个他认为可以与贝尔玛相提并论的人；他把她置于所有人之上。你有看见她吗？'

‘No, sir, my parents do not allow me to go to the theatre.’
“不，先生，我父母不允许我去剧院。”

‘That is a pity. You should insist. Berma in Phèdre, in the Cid; well, she’s only an actress, if you like, but you know that I don’t believe very much in the ‘hierarchy’ of the arts.’ As he spoke I noticed, what had often struck me before in his conversations with my grandmother’s sisters, that whenever he spoke of serious matters, whenever he used an expression which seemed to imply a definite opinion upon some important subject, he would take care to isolate, to sterilise it by using a special intonation, mechanical and ironic, as though he had put the phrase or word between inverted commas, and was anxious to disclaim any personal responsibility for it; as who should say ‘the ‘hierarchy,’ don’t you know, as silly people call it.’ But then, if it was so absurd, why did he say the ‘hierarchy’? A moment later he went on: ‘Her acting will give you as noble an inspiration as any masterpiece of art in the world, as—oh, I don’t know—‘ and he began to laugh, ‘shall we say the Queens of Chartres?’ Until then I had supposed that his horror of having to give a serious opinion was something Parisian and refined, in contrast to the provincial dogmatism of my grandmother’s sisters; and I had imagined also that it was characteristic of the mental attitude towards life of the circle in which Swann moved, where, by a natural reaction from the ‘lyrical’ enthusiasms of earlier generations, an excessive importance was given to small and precise facts, formerly regarded as vulgar, and anything in the nature of ‘phrase-making’ was banned. But now I found myself slightly shocked by this attitude which Swann invariably adopted when face to face with generalities. He appeared unwilling to risk even having an opinion, and to be at his ease only when he could furnish, with meticulous accuracy, some precise but unimportant detail. But in so doing he did not take into account that even here he was giving an opinion, holding a brief (as they say) for something, that the accuracy of his details had an importance of its own. I thought again of the dinner that night, when I had been so unhappy because Mamma would not be coming up to my room, and when he had dismissed the balls given by the Princesse de Léon as being of no importance. And yet it was to just that sort of amusement that he was devoting his life. For what other kind of existence did he reserve the duties of saying in all seriousness what he thought about things, of formulating judgments which he would not put between inverted commas; and when would he cease to give himself up to occupations of which at the same, time he made out that they were absurd? I noticed, too, in the manner in which Swann spoke to me of Bergotte, something which, to do him justice, was not peculiar to himself, but was shared by all that writer’s admirers at that time, at least by my mother’s friend and by Dr. du Boulbon. Like Swann, they would say of Bergotte: ‘He has a charming mind, so individual, he has a way of his own of saying things, which is a little far-fetched, but so pleasant. You never need to look for his name on the title-page, you can tell his work at once.’ But none of them had yet gone so far as to say ‘He is a great writer, he has great talent.’ They did not even credit him with talent at all. They did not speak, because they were not aware of it. We are very slow in recognising in the peculiar physiognomy of a new writer the type which is labelled ‘great talent’ in our museum of general ideas. Simply because that physiognomy is new and strange, we can find in it no resemblance to what we are accustomed to call talent. We say rather originality, charm, delicacy, strength; and then one day we add up the sum of these, and find that it amounts simply to talent.
'好可惜。你应该坚持。贝尔玛在菲德尔，在熙德；好吧，如果你愿意的话，她只是一名演员，但你知道我不太相信艺术的“等级制度”。”当他说话时，我注意到，以前在他与我祖母的谈话中经常让我震惊的事情姐妹们，每当他谈到严肃的事情时，每当他使用似乎暗示对某个重要主题有明确意见的表达方式时，他都会小心翼翼地用特殊的语气、机械和讽刺的语气将其隔离和消毒，就好像他在说话一样。将该短语或单词置于引号之间，并急于否认对此承担任何个人责任；谁应该说“‘等级制度’，你不知道吗，愚蠢的人们称之为‘等级制度’。”但是，如果这真是荒谬的话，他为什么要说“等级制度”呢？过了一会儿，他继续说道：“她的表演会给你带来与世界上任何艺术杰作一样高尚的灵感，因为——哦，我不知道——”然后他开始大笑，“我们可以说是女王吗？”沙特尔？”在那之前，我一直以为他对必须发表严肃意见的恐惧是巴黎人的一种优雅的态度，与我祖母姐妹的地方教条主义形成鲜明对比；我也曾想象过，这是斯万所在圈子对生活的心理态度的特征，在这个圈子里，由于前几代人的“抒情”热情的自然反应，过分重视微小而精确的事实，以前被认为是粗俗的，任何具有“造词”性质的东西都被禁止。但现在我发现自己对斯旺在面对笼统事物时总是采取的这种态度感到有点震惊。 他似乎不愿意冒发表意见的风险，只有当他能够一丝不苟地准确地提供一些精确但不重要的细节时，他才会感到轻松。但在这样做时，他没有考虑到，即使在这里，他也是在发表意见，为某件事举行简报（正如他们所说），他的细节的准确性本身就很重要。我再次想起那天晚上的晚餐，当时我非常不高兴，因为妈妈不会来我的房间，而且他认为莱昂公主举办的舞会并不重要，因此不予考虑。然而他却把自己的一生奉献给了这种娱乐。对于其他什么样的存在，他保留了严肃地表达他对事物的想法的责任，以及制定他不会放在引号之间的判断的责任；他什么时候才能停止投身于那些他同时又认为这些事情是荒谬的事情呢？我还注意到，斯旺向我谈论贝戈特时的态度，公平地说，这并不是他自己所特有的，而是当时所有这位作家的崇拜者所共有的，至少是我母亲的朋友和由杜布尔邦博士撰写。就像斯旺一样，他们会这样评价贝戈特：“他有一个迷人的头脑，非常有个性，他有自己的说话方式，虽然有点牵强，但却很令人愉快。”你永远不需要在扉页上寻找他的名字，你可以立即说出他的作品。”但他们中没有一个人会说“他是一位伟大的作家，他有伟大的才华。”他们做到了甚至根本不相信他有才华。他们没有说话，因为他们没有意识到。 我们很难从新作家的独特面貌中认识到我们一般思想博物馆中被标记为“伟大天才”的类型。仅仅因为这种相貌是新奇的，我们发现它与我们习惯上所说的天赋没有任何相似之处。我们说的是原创、魅力、精致、实力；然后有一天，我们把这些加起来，发现这就是天赋。

‘Are there any books in which Bergotte has written about Berma?’ I asked M. Swann.
“贝戈特有写过关于贝尔马的书吗？”我问斯旺先生。

‘I think he has, in that little essay on Racine, but it must be out of print. Still, there has perhaps been a second impression. I will find out. Anyhow, I can ask Bergotte himself all that you want to know next time he comes to dine with us. He never misses a week, from one year’s end to another. He is my daughter’s greatest friend. They go about together, and look at old towns and cathedrals and castles.’
“我认为他在那篇关于拉辛的小文章中说过，但它一定已经绝版了。尽管如此，也许还有第二印象。我会找出答案。不管怎样，下次贝戈特来和我们一起吃饭时，我可以问他所有你想知道的事情。从一年到另一年，他从来没有错过过一周。他是我女儿最好的朋友。他们一起四处走动，参观古老的城镇、大教堂和城堡。

As I was still completely ignorant of the different grades in the social hierarchy, the fact that my father found it impossible for us to see anything of Swann’s wife and daughter had, for a long time, had the contrary effect of making me imagine them as separated from us by an enormous gulf, which greatly enhanced their dignity and importance in my eyes. I was sorry that my mother did not dye her hair and redden her lips, as I had heard our neighbour, Mme. Sazerat, say that Mme. Swann did, to gratify not her husband but M. de Charlus; and I felt that, to her, we must be an object of scorn, which distressed me particularly on account of the daughter, such a pretty little girl, as I had heard, and one of whom I used often to dream, always imagining her with the same features and appearance, which I bestowed upon her quite arbitrarily, but with a charming effect. But from this afternoon, when I had learned that Mile. Swann was a creature living in such rare and fortunate circumstances, bathed, as in her natural element, in such a sea of privilege that, if she should ask her parents whether anyone were coming to dinner, she would be answered in those two syllables, radiant with celestial light, would hear the name of that golden guest who was to her no more than an old friend of her family, Bergotte; that for her the intimate conversation at table, corresponding to what my great-aunt’s conversation was for me, would be the words of Bergotte upon all those subjects which he had not been able to take up in his writings, and on which I would fain have heard him utter oracles; and that, above all, when she went to visit other towns, he would be walking by her side, unrecognised and glorious, like the gods who came down, of old, from heaven to dwell among mortal men: then I realised both the rare worth of a creature such as Mile. Swann, and, at the same time, how coarse and ignorant I should appear to her; and I felt so keenly how pleasant and yet how impossible it would be for me to become her friend that I was filled at once with longing and with despair. And usually, from this time forth, when I thought of her, I would see her standing before the porch of a cathedral, explaining to me what each of the statues meant, and, with a smile which was my highest commendation, presenting me, as her friend, to Bergotte. And invariably the charm of all the fancies which the thought of cathedrals used to inspire in me, the charm of the hills and valleys of the He de France and of the plains of Normandy, would radiate brightness and beauty over the picture I had formed in my mind of Mile. Swann; nothing more remained but to know and to love her. Once we believe that a fellow-creature has a share in some unknown existence to which that creature’s love for ourselves can win us admission, that is, of all the preliminary conditions which Love exacts, the one to which he attaches most importance, the one which makes him generous or indifferent as to the rest. Even those women who pretend that they judge a man by his exterior only, see in that exterior an emanation from some special way of life. And that is why they fall in love with a soldier or a fireman, whose uniform makes them less particular about his face; they kiss and believe that beneath the crushing breastplate there beats a heart different from the rest, more gallant, more adventurous, more tender; and so it is that a young king or a crown prince may travel in foreign countries and make the most gratifying conquests, and yet lack entirely that regular and classic profile which would be indispensable, I dare say, in an outside-broker.
