由于我对社会等级制度的不同等级仍然一无所知，事实上，我的父亲发现我们不可能看到斯旺的妻子和女儿的任何东西，这一事实在很长一段时间内产生了相反的效果，使我将她们想象为他们与我们之间有着巨大的鸿沟，这极大地增强了他们在我眼中的尊严和重要性。我很遗憾我的母亲没有像我听到的邻居夫人那样染发、涂红嘴唇。萨泽拉特女士，请这么说。斯旺这样做了，不是为了让她的丈夫满意，而是为了让德·夏吕斯先生满意。我觉得，对她来说，我们一定是一个被蔑视的对象，这让我特别难过，因为她的女儿，我听说过，是一个非常漂亮的小女孩，我经常梦见她，总是想象她的样子。与我随意赋予她的特征和外表相同，但却具有迷人的效果。但从今天下午开始，当我知道了米勒的事后。 斯旺是一个生活在如此罕见和幸运的环境中的生物，沐浴在她的自然元素中，沐浴在如此特权的海洋中，如果她问她的父母是否有人来吃晚饭，她会用这两个音节回答：她浑身散发着天国的光芒，听到那位金色客人的名字，对她来说，贝戈特只不过是她家里的老朋友。对她来说，餐桌上的亲密谈话，就像我姨婆对我的谈话一样，将是贝戈特的话，涉及他在著作中无法讨论的所有主题，而我却很乐意谈论这些主题。曾听他宣讲神谕；最重要的是，当她去拜访其他城镇时，他会走在她身边，不为人知，光荣无比，就像远古时代从天上降临到凡人中间的神灵一样：然后我意识到这两种罕见的情况像迈尔这样的生物的价值。斯旺，同时，我在她看来是多么粗俗和无知；我强烈地感觉到，成为她的朋友是多么愉快，但又是多么不可能，我立刻充满了渴望和绝望。通常，从那时起，当我想起她时，我会看到她站在大教堂的门廊前，向我解释每座雕像的含义，并带着微笑，这是我最高的赞扬，向我介绍，作为她的朋友，贝戈特。大教堂的想法曾经在我心中激发出的所有幻想的魅力，法国丘陵和山谷以及诺曼底平原的魅力，总是会在我所形成的画面上散发出明亮和美丽的光芒。我心中的迈尔。斯旺；除了了解她、爱她之外，什么也没有了。 一旦我们相信，某个同类在某种未知的存在中占有一席之地，而该生物对我们自己的爱可以赢得我们的承认，即爱所要求的所有初步条件，他最重视的条件，他最重视的条件这使得他对其他人要么慷慨，要么漠不关心。即使是那些假装只根据外表来判断一个男人的女人，也会在外表中看到某种特殊生活方式的散发。这就是为什么他们会爱上士兵或消防员，他们的制服让他们不那么挑剔他的脸；他们亲吻并相信，在破碎的胸甲下跳动着一颗与其他人不同的心，更勇敢，更冒险，更温柔；因此，年轻的国王或王储可能会在外国旅行并进行最令人满意的征服，但完全缺乏我敢说对于外部经纪人来说必不可少的常规和经典形象。

While I was reading in the garden, a thing my great-aunt would never have understood my doing save on a Sunday, that being the day on which it was unlawful to indulge in any serious occupation, and on which she herself would lay aside her sewing (on a week-day she would have said, ‘How you can go on amusing yourself with a book; it isn’t Sunday, you know!’ putting into the word ‘amusing’ an implication of childishness and waste of time), my aunt Léonie would be gossiping with Françoise until it was time for Eulalie to arrive. She would tell her that she had just seen Mme. Goupil go by ‘without an umbrella, in the silk dress she had made for her the other day at Châteaudun. If she has far to go before vespers, she may get it properly soaked.’
当我在花园里读书时，我的姨婆永远不会理解我所做的事情，除非是在周日，因为在这一天，从事任何严肃的工作都是非法的，在这一天，她自己也会放下她的工作。缝纫（在工作日，她会说，“你怎么能继续看书自娱自乐；你知道，这不是星期天！”把“有趣”这个词带入幼稚和浪费时间的含义） ，我的莱奥妮姨妈会和弗朗索瓦丝闲聊，直到尤拉莉到达为止。她会告诉她，她刚刚见到了夫人。古皮尔“没有带伞，穿着她前几天在沙托丹为她做的丝质连衣裙”。如果她在晚祷之前还有很长的路要走，她可能会把它适当地浸泡。

‘Very likely’ (which meant also ‘very likely not’) was the answer, for Françoise did not wish definitely to exclude the possibility of a happier alternative.
答案是“很可能”（也意味着“很可能不会”），因为弗朗索瓦丝并不希望绝对排除更幸福的选择的可能性。

‘There, now,’ went on my aunt, beating her brow, ‘that reminds me that I never heard if she got to church this morning before the Elevation. I must remember to ask Eulalie... Françoise, just look at that black cloud behind the steeple, and how poor the light is on the slates, you may be certain it will rain before the day is out. It couldn’t possibly keep on like this, it’s been too hot. And the sooner the better, for until the storm breaks my Vichy water won’t ‘go down,’’ she concluded, since, in her mind, the desire to accelerate the digestion of her Vichy water was of infinitely greater importance than her fear of seeing Mme. Goupil’s new dress ruined.
“好了，现在，”姨妈拍着额头继续说道，“这让我想起，我从来没有听说过她今天早上是否在升天之前到过教堂。我一定要记得问尤拉莉……弗朗索瓦丝，只要看看尖塔后面的那片乌云，石板上的光线有多弱，你就可以肯定天还没亮就会下雨。不可能再这样下去了，太热了。越早越好，因为在暴风雨来临之前，我的维希水不会“下降”，她总结道，因为在她看来，加速消化她的维希水的愿望比她的恐惧更重要见到夫人。古皮尔的新衣服被毁了。

‘Very likely.’
'很可能。'

‘And you know that when it rains in the Square there’s none too much shelter.’ Suddenly my aunt turned pale. ‘What, three o’clock!’ she exclaimed. ‘But vespers will have begun already, and I’ve forgotten my pepsin! Now I know why that Vichy water has been lying on my stomach.’ And falling precipitately upon a prayer-book bound in purple velvet, with gilt clasps, out of which in her haste she let fall a shower of the little pictures, each in a lace fringe of yellowish paper, which she used to mark the places of the greater feasts of the church, my aunt, while she swallowed her drops, began at full speed to mutter the words of the sacred text, its meaning being slightly clouded in her brain by the uncertainty whether the pepsin, when taken so long after the Vichy, would still be able to overtake it and to ‘send it down.’ ‘Three o’clock! It’s unbelievable how time flies.’
“你知道，下雨的时候广场上没有太多的庇护所。” 突然，姨妈的脸色变得苍白。 “什么，三点钟了！”她喊道。 “但是晚祷已经开始了，我忘了带胃蛋白酶了！”现在我知道为什么维希水一直躺在我的肚子上了。”她突然落在一本用紫色天鹅绒装订的祈祷书上，上面有镀金的扣子，在她的匆忙中，她从里面放出了一堆小图画，每张都在里面。一张淡黄色的花边纸，她用它来标记教堂重大节日的地点，我的姨妈一边吞下她的水，一边开始全速念诵神圣文本的话语，它的含义稍微模糊了。她的大脑不确定，在维希注射后这么长时间服用胃蛋白酶，是否仍然能够超越它并“将其发送下来”。“三点钟！”时间过得真令人难以置信。

A little tap at the window, as though some missile had struck it, followed by a plentiful, falling sound, as light, though, as if a shower of sand were being sprinkled from a window overhead; then the fall spread, took on an order, a rhythm, became liquid, loud, drumming, musical, innumerable, universal. It was the rain.
轻轻地敲了一下窗户，就好像有一枚导弹击中了它，接着是一声丰富的、落下的声音，虽然很轻，却好像一阵沙子从头顶的窗户上洒下来；然后秋天蔓延开来，呈现出一种秩序、一种节奏，变得流动、响亮、击鼓、音乐、无数、普遍。原来是下雨了。

‘There, Françoise, what did I tell you? How it’s coming down! But I think I heard the bell at the garden gate: go along and see who can be outside in this weather.’
“好了，弗朗索瓦丝，我告诉你什么了？怎么下来了！但我想我听到了花园门口的铃声：走吧，看看这种天气谁可以在外面。”

Françoise went and returned. ‘It’s Mme. Amédée’ (my grandmother). ‘She said she was going for a walk. It’s raining hard, all the same.’
弗朗索瓦丝去了又回来。 “是夫人。” Amédée（我的祖母）。 “她说她要去散步。尽管如此，雨还是很大。

‘I’m not at all surprised,’ said my aunt, looking up towards the sky. ‘I’ve always said that she was not in the least like other people. Well, I’m glad it’s she and not myself who’s outside in all this.’
“我一点也不惊讶，”姨妈抬头望着天空说道。 “我一直说她一点也不像其他人。好吧，我很高兴是她而不是我自己参与了这一切。

‘Mme. Amédée is always the exact opposite of the rest,’ said Françoise, not unkindly, refraining until she should be alone with the other servants from stating her belief that my grandmother was ‘a bit off her head.’
'女士。阿梅黛总是和其他人完全相反。”弗朗索瓦丝毫不客气地说，直到她和其他仆人独处时才说出她认为我祖母“有点疯狂”的看法。

‘There’s Benediction over! Eulalie will never come now,’ sighed my aunt. ‘It will be the weather that’s frightened her away.’
‘祝福结束了！尤拉莉现在永远不会来了。”姨妈叹息道。 “是天气把她吓跑了。”

‘But it’s not five o’clock yet, Mme. Octave, it’s only half-past four.’
“但是现在还不到五点，夫人。八度，现在才四点半。”

‘Only half-past four! And here am I, obliged to draw back the small curtains, just to get a tiny streak of daylight. At half-past four! Only a week before the Rogation-days. Ah, my poor Françoise, the dear Lord must be sorely vexed with us. The world is going too far in these days. As my poor Octave used to say, we have forgotten God too often, and He is taking vengeance upon us.’
“才四点半啊！而我就在这里，不得不拉开小窗帘，只是为了获得一丝阳光。四点半！距离加冕日仅一周。啊，我可怜的弗朗索瓦丝，亲爱的上帝一定对我们非常恼火。这些天世界已经走得太远了。正如我可怜的奥克塔夫常说的那样，我们经常忘记上帝，而他正在向我们报复。

A bright flush animated my aunt’s cheeks; it was Eulalie. As ill luck would have it, scarcely had she been admitted to the presence when Françoise reappeared and, with a smile which was meant to indicate her full participation in the pleasure which, she had no doubt, her tidings would give my aunt, articulating each syllable so as to shew that, in spite of her having to translate them into indirect speech, she was repeating, as a good servant should, the very words which the new visitor had condescended to use, said: ‘His reverence the Curé would be delighted, enchanted, if Mme. Octave is not resting just now, and could see him. His reverence does not wish to disturb Mme. Octave. His reverence is downstairs; I told him to go into the parlour.’
姨妈的脸颊泛起红晕。是尤拉莉。不幸的是，她刚被允许到场，弗朗索瓦丝就再次出现了，她脸上带着微笑，这意味着她完全参与到了快乐中，她毫不怀疑，她的消息会给我姨妈带来欢乐，阐明了每一个细节。音节，以表明，尽管她必须将它们翻译成间接引语，但她正在重复，作为一个好仆人应该使用的新来访者屈尊使用的词，说：“他尊敬的神父将是很高兴，很着迷，如果女士。奥克塔夫现在没有休息，可以看到他。他的尊敬不想打扰夫人。八度。他的崇敬在楼下；我叫他到客厅去。”

Had the truth been known, the Curé’s visits gave my aunt no such ecstatic pleasure as Françoise supposed, and the air of jubilation with which she felt bound to illuminate her face whenever she had to announce his arrival, did not altogether correspond to what was felt by her invalid. The Curé (an excellent man, with whom I am sorry now that I did not converse more often, for, even if he cared nothing for the arts, he knew a great many etymologies), being in the habit of shewing distinguished visitors over his church (he had even planned to compile a history of the Parish of Com-bray), used to weary her with his endless explanations, which, incidentally, never varied in the least degree. But when his visit synchronized exactly with Eulalie’s it became frankly distasteful to my aunt. She would have preferred to make the most of Eulalie, and not to have had the whole of her circle about her at one time. But she dared not send the Curé away, and had to content herself with making a sign to Eulalie not to leave when he did, so that she might have her to herself for a little after he had gone.
如果知道真相的话，神父的来访并没有给我姨妈带来弗朗索瓦丝所想象的那种欣喜若狂的快乐，每当她不得不宣布他的到来时，她都会感到脸上洋溢着喜悦的气氛，但这种气氛并不完全符合她的感受。由她无效。本堂神父（一位出色的人，我很抱歉我没有经常与他交谈，因为即使他对艺术毫不关心，他也知道很多词源），习惯于向尊贵的来访者展示他的作品。教堂（他甚至计划编撰一部康布雷教区的历史），常常用他没完没了的解释让她厌烦，顺便说一句，这些解释从来没有丝毫改变。但当他的来访与尤拉莉的来访完全同步时，坦率地说，我姨妈变得很反感。她宁愿充分利用尤拉莉，也不愿让整个圈子都围着她转。但她不敢送神甫走，只得在他走的时候向尤拉莉打个手势不要走，这样在他走后她就可以独处一会儿了。

‘What is this I have been hearing, Father, that a painter has set up his easel in your church, and is copying one of the windows? Old as I am, I can safely say that I have never even heard of such a thing in all my life! What is the world coming to next, I wonder! And the ugliest thing in the whole church, too.’
‘神父，我听说有一位画家在您的教堂里架起了画架，正在临摹其中一扇窗户，这是怎么回事？我虽然年纪大了，但可以肯定地说，我这辈子从来没有听说过这样的事！我想知道接下来的世界会怎样！也是整个教堂里最丑陋的东西。

‘I will not go so far as to say that it is quite the ugliest, for, although there are certain things in Saint-Hilaire which are well worth a visit, there are others that are very old now, in my poor basilica, the only one in all the diocese that has never even been restored. The Lord knows, our porch is dirty and out of date; still, it is of a majestic character; take, for instance, the Esther tapestries, though personally I would not give a brass farthing for the pair of them, but experts put them next after the ones at Sens. I can quite see, too, that apart from certain details which are—well, a trifle realistic, they shew features which testify to a genuine power of observation. But don’t talk to me about the windows. Is it common sense, I ask you, to leave up windows which shut out all the daylight, and even confuse the eyes by throwing patches of colour, to which I should be hard put to it to give a name, on a floor in which there are not two slabs on the same level? And yet they refuse to renew the floor for me because, if you please, those are the tombstones of the Abbots of Combray and the Lords of Guermantes, the old Counts, you know, of Brabant, direct ancestors of the present Duc de Guermantes, and of his Duchesse also, since she was a lady of the Guermantes family, and married her cousin.’ (My grandmother, whose steady refusal to take any interest in ‘persons’ had ended in her confusing all their names and titles, whenever anyone mentioned the Duchesse de Guermantes used to make out that she must be related to Mme. de Villeparisis. The whole family would then burst out laughing; and she would attempt to justify herself by harking back to some invitation to a christening or funeral: ‘I feel sure that there was a Guermantes in it somewhere.’ And for once I would side with the others, and against her, refusing to admit that there could be any connection between her school-friend and the descendant of Geneviève de Brabant.)
“我不会说它是最丑陋的，因为虽然圣伊莱尔的某些东西非常值得一游，但在我可怜的大教堂里，还有其他东西现在已经非常古老了，整个教区中只有一个从未恢复过。天知道，我们的门廊又脏又过时；尽管如此，它仍然具有雄伟的特征；以埃丝特挂毯为例，虽然我个人不会为这两幅挂毯花一分钱，但专家们把它们放在桑斯的挂毯之后。我也很清楚，除了某些细节之外——好吧，有点现实，它们所表现出的特征证明了真正的观察力。但别跟我谈论窗户。我问你，在这样的地板上留下挡住所有日光的窗户，甚至通过投掷色彩斑块来迷惑眼睛，这是常识吗？我很难给它起一个名字。不是有两块石板在同一水平面上吗？然而他们拒绝为我续约，因为如果你愿意的话，这些是贡布雷修道院院长和盖尔芒特勋爵的墓碑，你们知道，布拉班特的老伯爵，现任盖尔芒特公爵的直系祖先，还有他的公爵夫人，因为她是盖尔芒特家族的一位女士，并嫁给了她的表弟。”（我的祖母，她一贯拒绝对“人”产生任何兴趣，最终导致她混淆了他们所有的名字和头衔，每当有人提到盖尔芒特公爵夫人常常声称她一定与德·维尔帕里西斯夫人有亲戚关系。然后全家人都会大笑起来；她会试图通过回想起一些参加洗礼或葬礼的邀请来为自己辩护：“我确信其中某处有盖尔芒特葡萄酒。’这一次我会站在其他人一边，反对她，拒绝承认她的同学和吉纳维耶夫·德·布拉班特的后裔之间可能有任何联系。)

‘Look at Roussainville,’ the Curé went on. ‘It is nothing more nowadays than a parish of farmers, though in olden times the place must have had a considerable importance from its trade in felt hats and clocks. (I am not certain, by the way, of the etymology of Roussainville. I should dearly like to think that the name was originally Rouville, from Radulfi villa, analogous, don’t you see, to Châteauroux, Castrum Radulfi, but we will talk about that some other time.) Very well; the church there has superb windows, almost all quite modern, including that most imposing ‘Entry of Louis-Philippe into Combray’ which would be more in keeping, surely, at Combray itself, and which is every bit as good, I understand, as the famous^windows at Chartres. Only yesterday I met Dr. Percepied’s brother, who goes in for these things, and he told me that he looked upon it as a most beautiful piece of work. But, as I said to this artist, who, by the way, seems to be a most civil fellow, and is a regular virtuoso, it appears, with his brush; what on earth, I said to him, do you find so extraordinary in this window, which is, if anything, a little dingier than the rest?’
“看看鲁桑维尔，”本堂神父继续说道。 “如今它只不过是一个农民教区，尽管在古代，这个地方一定因毡帽和钟表贸易而具有相当大的重要性。 （顺便说一句，我不确定 Roussainville 的词源。我非常想认为这个名字最初是 Rouville，来自 Radulfi 别墅，类似于 Châteauroux，Castrum Radulfi，但我们会下次再谈。） 很好；很好；那里的教堂有精美的窗户，几乎都是相当现代的，包括最壮观的“路易·菲利普进入贡布雷”，这肯定更符合贡布雷本身的风格，而且据我所知，它也同样好沙特尔著名的^窗户。就在昨天，我遇到了珀塞皮德博士的兄弟，他热衷于这些事情，他告诉我，他认为这是一件最美丽的作品。但是，正如我对这位艺术家所说的那样，顺便说一句，他似乎是一个最有礼貌的人，而且似乎是一位普通的画笔大师；我对他说，你到底觉得这扇窗户有什么特别之处吗？如果有的话，就是比其他窗户脏一点点？

‘I am sure that if you were to ask his Lordship,’ said my aunt in a resigned tone, for she had begun to feel that she was going to be ‘tired,’ ‘he would never refuse you a new window.’
“我相信，如果您问陛下，”我姨妈用一种无奈的语气说道，因为她已经开始觉得自己会“累了”，“他绝不会拒绝给您打开一扇新窗户。”

‘You may depend upon it, Mme. Octave,’ replied the Curé. ‘Why, it was just his Lordship himself who started the outcry about the window, by proving that it represented Gilbert the Bad, a Lord of Guermantes and a direct descendant of Geneviève de Brabant, who was a daughter of the House of Guermantes, receiving absolution from Saint Hilaire.’
“你可以信赖它，夫人。八度，”神甫回答道。 “哎呀，正是勋爵阁下本人才对这扇窗户提出了强烈抗议，因为他证明它代表了吉尔伯特·坏人，他是盖尔芒特勋爵，也是吉纳维芙·德·布拉班特的直系后裔，盖尔芒特家族的女儿，接受了圣伊莱尔的赦免。

‘But I don’t see where Saint Hilaire comes in.’
“但我不明白圣伊莱尔的作用。”

‘Why yes, have you never noticed, in the corner of the window, a lady in a yellow robe? Very well, that is Saint Hilaire, who is also known, you will remember, in certain parts of the country as Saint Illiers, Saint Hèlier, and even, in the Jura, Saint Ylie. But these various corruptions of Sanctus Hilarius are by no means the most curious that have occurred in the names of the blessed Saints. Take, for example, my good Eulalie, the case of your own patron, Sancta Eulalia; do you know what she has become in Burgundy? Saint Eloi, nothing more nor less! The lady has become a gentleman. Do you hear that, Eulalie, after you are dead they will make a man of you!’
‘为什么是的，你有没有注意到，在窗户的角落里，有一个穿着黄色长袍的女士？很好，那就是圣伊莱尔（Saint Hilaire），您会记得，在该国的某些地区，他也被称为圣伊利耶（Saint Illiers）、圣赫利尔（Saint Hèlier），甚至在汝拉地区，也被称为圣伊利（Saint Ylie）。但圣希拉留斯的这些不同的腐败绝不是在受祝福的圣徒的名字中发生的最奇怪的。举个例子，我亲爱的尤拉莉亚，你自己的赞助人圣尤拉莉亚的例子；你知道她在勃艮第变成了什么吗？圣埃洛伊，不多也不少！淑女变成了绅士。你听到了吗，尤拉莉，你死后他们会让你成为一个男人！

‘Father will always have his joke.’
“父亲总是会开他的玩笑。”

‘Gilbert’s brother, Charles the Stammerer, was a pious prince, but, having early in life lost his father, Pepin the Mad, who died as a result of his mental infirmity, he wielded the supreme power with all the arrogance of a man who has not been subjected to discipline in his youth, so much so that, whenever he saw a man in a town whose face he did not remember, he would massacre the whole place, to the last inhabitant. Gilbert, wishing to be avenged on Charles, caused the church at Combray to be burned down, the original church, that was, which Théodebert, when he and his court left the country residence he had near here, at Thiberzy (which is, of course, Theodeberiacus), to go out and fight the Burgundians, had promised to build over the tomb of Saint Hilaire if the Saint brought him; victory. Nothing remains of it now but the crypt, into which Théodore has probably taken you, for Gilbert burned all the rest. Finally, he defeated the unlucky Charles with the aid of William’ which the Curé pronounced ‘Will’am’ ‘the Conqueror, which is why so many English still come to visit the place. But he does not appear to have managed to win the affection of the people of Combray, for they fell upon him as he was coming out from mass, and cut off his head. Théodore has a little book, that he lends people, which tells you the whole story.
吉尔伯特的兄弟，结巴者查尔斯，是一位虔诚的王子，但他的父亲疯子丕平因精神疾病去世，他早年就去世了，他以一个傲慢的人的身份掌握着至高无上的权力。他年轻时没有受到过管教，以至于每当他在一个小镇上看到一个他不记得长相的人时，他就会屠杀整个地方，直到最后一个居民。吉尔伯特希望向查理报仇，他烧毁了贡布雷的教堂，也就是原来的教堂，即泰奥德伯特和他的宫廷离开他在附近蒂贝齐（Thiberzy）的乡村住所时建造的教堂。当然，狄奥德贝里亚库斯（Theodeberiacus），为了出去与勃艮第人作战，答应如果圣人带他来，就在圣人伊莱尔的坟墓上建造；胜利。现在只剩下地下室了，西奥多可能已经带你进去了，因为吉尔伯特把剩下的都烧掉了。最后，他在威廉的帮助下击败了不幸的查尔斯。神父称威廉为“征服者”，这就是为什么仍有那么多英国人来参观这个地方。但他似乎并没有赢得贡布雷人民的喜爱，因为当他从弥撒中出来时，他们袭击了他，砍下了他的头。西奥多借给人们一本小书，里面告诉你整个故事。

‘But what is unquestionably the most remarkable thing about our church is the view from the belfry, which is full of grandeur. Certainly in your case, since you are not very strong, I should never recommend you: to climb our seven and ninety steps, just half the number they have in the famous cathedral at Milan. It is quite tiring enough for the most active person, especially as you have to go on your hands and knees, if you don’t wish to crack your skull, and you collect all the cobwebs off the staircase upon your clothes. In any case you should be well wrapped up,’ he went on, without noticing my aunt’s fury at the mere suggestion that she could ever, possibly, be capable of climbing into his belfry, ‘for there’s a strong breeze there, once you get to the top. Some people even assure me that they have felt the chill of death up there. No matter, on Sundays there are always clubs and societies, who come, some of them, long distances to admire our beautiful panorama, and they always go home charmed. Wait now, next Sunday, if the weather holds, you will be sure to find a lot of people there, for Rogation-tide. You must admit, certainly, that the view from up there is like a fairy-tale, with what you might call vistas along the plain, which have quite a special charm of their own. On a clear day you can see as far as Verneuil. And then another thing; you can see at the same time places which you are in the habit of seeing one without the other, as, for instance, the course of the Vivonne and the ditches at Saint-Assise-lès-Combray, which are separated, really, by a screen of tall trees; or, to take another example, there are all the canals at Jouy-le-Vicomte, which is Gaudiacus vicecomitis, as of course you know. Each time that I have been to Jouy I have seen a bit of a canal in one place, and then I have turned a corner and seen another, but when I saw the second I could no longer see the first. I tried in vain to imagine how they lay by one another; it was no good. But, from the top of Saint-Hilaire, it’s quite another matter; the whole countryside is spread out before you like a map. Only, you cannot make out the water; you would say that there were great rifts in the town, slicing it up so neatly that it looks like a loaf of bread which still holds together after it has been cut up. To get it all quite perfect you would have to be in both places at once; up here on the top of Saint-Hilaire and down there at Jouy-le-Vicomte.’
“但毫无疑问，我们教堂最引人注目的是钟楼的景色，它充满了宏伟。当然，就你而言，由于你不是很强壮，我永远不建议你：爬我们的七级和九十级台阶，只是米兰著名大教堂的一半。对于最活跃的人来说，这已经够累的了，尤其是当你不想摔碎头骨时，你必须用手和膝盖着地，并且你要把楼梯上的所有蜘蛛网收集到你的衣服上。不管怎样，你应该裹得严严实实的，”他继续说道，没有注意到我姨妈因为仅仅暗示她可能有能力爬进他的钟楼而勃然大怒，“因为那里有一阵强风，一旦你进去了，”到顶部。有些人甚至向我保证，他们在那里感受到了死亡的寒冷。不管怎样，周日总会有一些俱乐部和社团，他们中的一些人不远千里前来欣赏我们美丽的全景，而且他们总是心满意足地回家。现在等等，下周日，如果天气好的话，你一定会发现那里有很多人，等待落潮。当然，你必须承认，从上面看到的景色就像童话故事一样，你可以称之为平原远景，它们有自己独特的魅力。天气晴朗时，您可以远眺韦尔讷伊 (Verneuil)。然后还有一件事；你可以同时看到你习惯于看到一个而没有另一个的地方，例如，维沃纳河的河道和圣阿西斯莱贡布雷的沟渠，它们实际上是由高大的树木构成的屏障；或者，再举一个例子，茹伊子爵城（Jouy-le-Vicomte）有所有运河，这就是高迪亚库斯副科姆蒂斯（Gaudiacusvicecomitis），你当然知道。 每次我去茹伊，我都会在一个地方看到一点运河，然后我转过一个拐角，看到另一个地方，但当我看到第二个地方时，我就再也看不到第一个地方了。我徒劳地试图想象他们是如何躺在一起的。这没什么好处。但是，从圣伊莱尔的山顶来看，情况就完全不同了。整个乡村像一张地图一样展现在你的面前。只是，你看不清水；你会说镇上有很大的裂痕，它被切得如此整齐，看起来就像一条面包，切开后仍然粘在一起。为了让一切变得完美，你必须同时到达这两个地方；上到圣伊莱尔山顶，下到茹伊勒子孔特。’

The Curé had so much exhausted my aunt that no sooner had he gone than she was obliged to send away Eulalie also.
本堂神父让我姨妈太累了，他一走，她就不得不把尤拉莉也送走。

‘Here, my poor Eulalie,’ she said in a feeble voice, drawing a coin from a small purse which lay ready to her hand. ‘This is just something so that you shall not forget me in your prayers.’
“给你，我可怜的尤拉莉，”她用微弱的声音说，从手边的小钱包里取出一枚硬币。 “这只是为了让你在祈祷时不会忘记我。”

‘Oh, but, Mme. Octave, I don’t think I ought to; you know very well that I don’t come here for that!’ So Eulalie would answer, with the same hesitation and the same embarrassment, every Sunday, as though each temptation were the first, and with a look of displeasure which enlivened my aunt and never offended her, for if it so happened that Eulalie, when she took the money, looked a little less sulky than usual, my aunt would remark afterwards, ‘I cannot think what has come over Eulalie; I gave her just the trifle I always give, and she did not look at all pleased.’
哦，但是，夫人。奥克塔夫，我认为我不应该这样做；你很清楚，我来这里不是为了这个！”所以尤拉莉每个星期天都会带着同样的犹豫和同样的尴尬回答，仿佛每一次诱惑都是第一次，而且带着不高兴的表情，这让我姨妈很高兴。我从来没有冒犯过她，因为如果碰巧尤拉莉接过钱时看上去比平时没那么阴沉，我姨妈事后就会说：“我想不出尤拉莉到底出了什么事；我只给了她我一直给的小东西，但她看起来一点也不高兴。

‘I don’t think she has very much to complain of, all the same,’ Françoise would sigh grimly, for she had a tendency to regard as petty cash all that my aunt might give her for herself or her children, and as treasure riotously squandered on a pampered and ungrateful darling the little coins slipped, Sunday by Sunday, into Eulalie’s hand, but so discreetly passed that Françoise never managed to see them. It was not that she wanted to have for herself the money my aunt bestowed on Eulalie. She already enjoyed a sufficiency of all that my aunt possessed, in the knowledge that the wealth of the mistress automatically ennobled and glorified the maid in the eyes of the world; and that she herself was conspicuous and worthy to be praised throughout Combray, Jouy-le-Vicomte, and other cities of men, on account of my aunt’s many farms, her frequent and prolonged visits from the Curé, and the astonishing number of bottles of Vichy water which she consumed. Françoise was avaricious only for my aunt; had she had control over my aunt’s fortune (which would have more than satisfied her highest ambition) she would have guarded it from the assaults of strangers with a maternal ferocity. She would, however, have seen no great harm in what my aunt, whom she knew to be incurably generous, allowed herself to give away, had she given only to those who were already rich. Perhaps she felt that such persons, not being actually in need of my aunt’s presents, could not be suspected of simulating affection for her on that account. Besides, presents offered to persons of great wealth and position, such as Mme. Sazerat, M. Swann, M. Legrandin and Mme. Goupil, to persons of the ‘same class’ as my aunt, and who would naturally ‘mix with her,’ seemed to Françoise to be included among the ornamental customs of that strange and brilliant life led by rich people, who hunted and shot, gave balls and paid visits, a life which she would contemplate with an admiring smile. But it was by no means the same thing if, for this princely exchange of courtesies, my aunt substituted mere charity, if her beneficiaries were of the class which Françoise would label ‘people like myself,’ or ‘people no better than myself,’ people whom she despised even more if they did not address her always as ‘Mme. Françoise,’ just to shew that they considered themselves to be ‘not as good.’ And when she saw that, despite all her warnings, my aunt continued to do exactly as she pleased, and to fling money away with both hands (or so, at least, Françoise believed) on undeserving objects, she began to find that the presents she herself received from my aunt were very tiny compared to the imaginary riches squandered upon Eulalie, There was not, in the neighbourhood of Combray, a farm of such prosperity and importance that Françoise doubted Eulalie’s ability to buy it, without thinking twice, out of the capital which her visits to my aunt had ‘brought in.’ It must be added that Eulalie had formed an exactly similar estimate of the vast and secret hoards of Françoise. So, every Sunday, after Eulalie had gone, Françoise would mercilessly prophesy her coming downfall. She hated Eulalie, but was at the same time afraid of her, and so felt bound, when Eulalie was there, to ‘look pleasant.’ But she would make up for that after the other’s departure; never, it is true, alluding to her by name, bul hinting at her in Sibylline oracles, or in utterances of a comprehensive character, like those of Ecclesiastes, the Preacher, but so worded that their special application could not escape my aunt. After peering out at the side of the curtain to see whether Eulalie had shut the front-door behind her; ‘Flatterers know how to make themselves welcome, and to gather up the crumbs; but have patience, have patience; our God is a jealous God, and one fine day He will be avenged upon them!’ she would declaim, with the sidelong, insinuating glance of Joash, thinking of Athaliah alone when he says that the
“尽管如此，我认为她没什么可抱怨的，”弗朗索瓦丝会冷酷地叹息道，因为她倾向于把我姨妈可能给她自己或她的孩子们的所有东西都视为零用钱，并视为珍宝。这些小硬币在一个被宠坏了、忘恩负义的宝贝身上肆意挥霍，一个又一个星期天，这些小硬币滑落到尤拉莉的手里，但传递得如此谨慎，弗朗索瓦丝从未见过它们。她并不是想把我姨妈送给尤拉莉的钱占为己有。她已经充分享受了我姨妈所拥有的一切，因为她知道，女主人的财富自然会在世人的眼中使女仆变得高贵和荣耀。她本人在贡布雷、茹伊子爵和其他男人城市都很引人注目，值得赞扬，因为我姨妈有许多农场，神父频繁而长时间地造访，还有数量惊人的葡萄酒。她喝的维希水。弗朗索瓦丝只对我姨妈贪婪。如果她能控制我姨妈的财产（这足以满足她最高的野心），她就会以母性的凶猛来保护它免受陌生人的攻击。然而，她知道我姨妈慷慨得无可救药，如果她只把钱捐给那些已经很富有的人，她不会觉得有什么大害处。也许她觉得这些人实际上并不需要姨妈的礼物，所以不能被怀疑因此而对她表现出感情。此外，还向有钱有势的人赠送礼物，例如夫人。 Sazerat、M. Swann、M. Legrandin 和 Mme。 古皮尔，对于与我姨妈“同一阶级”的人来说，自然会“与她混在一起”，在弗朗索瓦丝看来，古皮尔似乎属于富人过着的奇怪而辉煌的生活的装饰习俗之一，他们狩猎和射击，她会带着钦佩的微笑思考这样的生活。但是，如果我姨妈以慈善来代替这种高贵的礼节，如果她的受益人属于弗朗索瓦丝所说的“像我这样的人”或“不比我更好的人”，那么事情就完全不同了。如果他们不总是称呼她为“夫人”，她就会更加鄙视那些人。弗朗索瓦丝，”只是为了表明他们认为自己“没有那么好。”当她看到这一点时，尽管她提出了所有警告，我姑妈仍然继续按照她的意愿行事，并用双手把钱扔掉（或者这样）至少，弗朗索瓦丝相信）在不值得的物品上，她开始发现，与她在尤拉莉身上挥霍的想象中的财富相比，她自己从我姨妈那里收到的礼物非常微不足道。弗朗索瓦丝怀疑尤拉莉是否有能力不假思索地用她拜访我姨妈“带来”的资金购买它。必须补充的是，尤拉莉对巨大而秘密的宝库也做出了完全相同的估计。弗朗索瓦丝.因此，每个星期天，尤拉莉走后，弗朗索瓦丝都会无情地预言她即将垮台。她讨厌尤拉莉，但同时又害怕她，因此当尤拉莉在场时，她觉得自己必须“看起来很愉快”。’但她会在对方离开后弥补这一点；确实，从来没有提到过她的名字，而是在女预言家的神谕中，或者在像传道者的传道书那样的全面人物的话语中暗示她，但措辞如此，以至于它们的特殊应用无法逃过我姨妈的眼睛。从窗帘的一侧向外看去，看看尤拉莉是否已经把前门关上了。 “阿谀奉承者知道如何让自己受欢迎，并收集面包屑；但要有耐心，要有耐心；我们的神是一位忌邪的神，总有一天他会向他们报仇！’她会朗诵道，当他说

But on this memorable afternoon, when the Curé had come as well, and by his interminable visit had drained my aunt’s strength, Françoise followed Eulalie from the room, saying: ‘Mme. Octave, I will leave you to rest; you look utterly tired out.’
但在这个令人难忘的下午，本堂神父也来了，无休无止的拜访耗尽了我姨妈的体力，弗朗索瓦丝跟着尤拉莉走出了房间，说道：“夫人。”奥克塔夫，我会让你休息；你看起来很累。”

And my aunt answered her not a word, breathing a sigh so faint that it seemed it must prove her last, and lying there with closed eyes, as though already dead. But hardly had Françoise arrived downstairs, when four peals of a bell, pulled with the utmost violence, reverberated through the house, and my aunt, sitting erect upon her bed, called out: ‘Has Eulalie gone yet? Would you believe it; I forgot to ask her whether Mme. Goupil arrived in church before the Elevation. Run after her, quick!’
我姨妈一言不发，轻轻地叹了口气，看来这一定是她的最后一次叹息，她闭着眼睛躺在那里，仿佛已经死了。但弗朗索瓦丝刚到楼下，四声猛烈的铃声就在屋子里回响，我姨妈笔直地坐在床上，喊道：“尤拉莉走了吗？”你相信吗？我忘了问她是否是。古皮尔在升天之前到达教堂。追她，快！”

But Françoise returned alone, having failed to overtake Eulalie. ‘It is most provoking,’ said my aunt, shaking her head. ‘The one important thing that I had to ask her.’
但弗朗索瓦丝独自返回，未能追上尤拉莉。 “这真是太令人恼火了，”姨妈摇着头说道。 “我必须问她一件重要的事情。”

In this way life went by for my aunt Léonie, always the same, in the gentle uniformity of what she called, with a pretence of deprecation but with a deep tenderness, her ‘little jog-trot.’ Respected by all and sundry, not merely in her own house, where every one of us, having learned the futility of recommending any healthier mode of life, had become gradually resigned to its observance, but in the village as well, where, three streets away, a tradesman who had to hammer nails into a packing-case would send first to Françoise to make sure that my aunt was not ‘resting’—her ‘little jog-trot’ was, none the less, brutally disturbed on one occasion in this same year. Like a fruit hidden among its leaves, which has grown and ripened unobserved by man, until it falls of its own accord, there came upon us one night the kitchen-maid’s confinement. Her pains were unbearable, and, as there was no midwife in Combray, Françoise had to set off before dawn to fetch one from Thiberzy. My aunt was unable to ‘rest,’ owing to the cries of the girl, and as Françoise, though the distance was nothing, was very late in returning, her services were greatly missed. And so, in the course of the morning, my mother said to me: ‘Run upstairs, and see if your aunt wants anything.’
就这样，莱奥妮姨妈的生活就这样过去了，始终如一，她所谓的温和统一，假装不赞成，但内心深处充满温柔，她的“小慢跑”。仅仅在她自己的家里，我们每个人都知道推荐任何更健康的生活方式都是徒劳的，因此逐渐接受了这种生活方式，但在三街之外的村庄里也是如此，一位商人不得不将钉子钉入包装箱会首先发送给弗朗索瓦丝，以确保我的姨妈没有“休息”——尽管如此，她的“小慢跑”在同一年有一次受到了残酷的干扰。就像隐藏在叶子中的果实一样，它在人们不注意的情况下生长和成熟，直到它自己落下，有一天晚上，厨房女仆的监禁降临到我们身上。她的痛苦难以忍受，而且由于贡布雷没有助产士，弗朗索瓦丝不得不在黎明前出发去蒂贝齐取一位助产士。由于女孩的哭声，我的姨妈无法“休息”，而弗朗索瓦丝虽然距离不远，但回来得很晚，人们非常怀念她的服务。于是，早上，妈妈对我说：“跑上楼去，看看你阿姨要不要什么。”

I went into the first of her two rooms, and through the open door of the other saw my aunt lying on her side, asleep. I could hear her breathing, in what was almost distinguishable as a snore. I was just going to slip away when something, probably the sound of my entry, interrupted her sleep, and made it ‘change speed,’ as they say of motorcars nowadays, for the music of her snore broke off for a second and began again on a lower note; then she awoke, and half turned her face, which I could see for the first time; a kind of horror was imprinted on it; plainly she had just escaped from some terrifying dream. She could not see me from where she was lying, and I stood there not knowing whether I ought to go forward or to retire; but all at once she seemed to return to a sense of reality, and to grasp the falsehood of the visions that had terrified her; a smile of joy, a pious act of thanksgiving to God, Who is pleased to grant that life shall be less cruel than our dreams, feebly illumined her face, and, with the habit she had formed of speaking to herself, half-aloud, when she thought herself alone, she murmured: ‘The Lord be praised! We have nothing to disturb us here but the kitchen-maid’s baby. And I’ve been dreaming that my poor Octave had come back to life, and was trying to make me take a walk every day!’ She stretched out a hand towards her rosary, which was lying on the small table, but sleep was once again getting the mastery, and did not leave her the strength to reach it; she fell asleep, calm and contented, and I crept out of the room on tiptoe, without either her or anyone’s else ever knowing, from that day to this, what I had seen and heard.
我走进她的两个房间中的第一个，透过另一个开着的门，看到姨妈侧身睡着了。我能听到她的呼吸声，几乎可以辨认出是鼾声。我正要溜走时，有什么东西，可能是我进入的声音，打断了她的睡眠，并使它“改变速度”，正如人们现在所说的汽车一样，因为她的鼾声中断了一秒钟，又开始了较低的音调；然后她醒了，半转过脸，这是我第一次看到她。一种恐怖烙印在上面；显然她刚刚从某个可怕的梦境中逃脱。她从她躺着的地方看不到我，我站在那儿不知道是该前进还是该退缩。但突然间，她似乎又回到了现实，并认识到那些令她恐惧的幻象是虚假的。喜悦的微笑，对上帝的虔诚感恩之举，上帝很高兴地承认生活不会像我们的梦想那么残酷，微弱地照亮了她的脸，并且，按照她养成的自言自语的习惯，半大声，当她独自一人时，她低声说道：“赞美主！”除了厨房女仆的孩子之外，我们这里没有什么可以打扰我们。我一直梦想着我可怜的奥克塔夫复活了，并试图让我每天去散步！”她向放在小桌子上的念珠伸出一只手，但睡眠已经过去了。再次掌握了一切，却没有给她留下达到它的力量；她平静而满足地睡着了，我蹑手蹑脚地走出房间，从那天到今天，她或其他任何人都不知道我所看到和听到的事情。

When I say that, apart from such rare happenings as this confinement, my aunt’s ‘little jog-trot’ never underwent any variation, I do not include those variations which, repeated at regular intervals and in identical form, did no more, really, than print a sort of uniform pattern upon the greater uniformity of her life. So, for instance, every Saturday, as Françoise had to go in the afternoon to market at Roussainville-le-Pin, the whole household would have to have luncheon an hour earlier. And my aunt had so thoroughly acquired the habit of this weekly exception to her general habits, that she clung to it as much as to the rest. She was so well ‘routined’ to it, as Françoise would say, that if, on a Saturday, she had had to wait for her luncheon until the regular hour, it would have ‘upset’ her as much as if she had had, on an ordinary day, to put her luncheon forward to its Saturday time. Incidentally this acceleration of luncheon gave Saturday, for all of us, an individual character, kindly and rather attractive. At the moment when, ordinarily, there was still an hour to be lived through before meal-time sounded, we would all know that in a few seconds we should see the endives make their precocious appearance, followed by the special favour of an omelette, an unmerited steak. The return of this asymmetrical Saturday was one of those petty occurrences, intra-mural, localised, almost civic, which, in uneventful lives and stable orders of society, create a kind of national unity, and become the favourite theme for conversation, for pleasantries, for anecdotes which can be «mbroidered as the narrator pleases; it would have provided a nucleus, ready-made, for a legendary cycle, if any of us had had the epic mind. At daybreak, before we were dressed, without rhyme or reason, save for the pleasure of proving the strength of our solidarity, we would call to one another good-humoredly, cordially, patriotically, ‘Hurry up; there’s no time to be lost; don’t forget, it’s Saturday!’ while my aunt, gossiping with Françoise, and reflecting that the day would be even longer than usual, would say, ‘You might cook them a nice bit of veal, seeing that it’s Saturday.’ If, at half-past ten, some one absent-mindedly pulled out a watch and said, ‘I say, an hour-and-a-half still before luncheon,’ everyone else would be in ecstasies over being able to retort at once: ‘Why, what are you thinking about? Have you for-gotten that it’s Saturday?’ And a quarter of an hour later we would still be laughing, and reminding ourselves to go up and tell aunt Léonie about this absurd mistake, to amuse her. The very face of the sky appeared to undergo a change. After luncheon the sun, conscious that it was Saturday, would blaze an hour longer in the zenith, and when some one, thinking that we were late in starting for our walk, said, ‘What, only two o’clock!’ feeling the heavy throb go by him of the twin strokes from the steeple of Saint-Hilaire (which as a rule passed no one at that hour upon the highways, deserted for the midday meal or for the nap which follows it, or on the banks of the bright and ever-flowing stream, which even the angler had abandoned, and so slipped unaccompanied into the vacant sky, where only a few loitering clouds remained to greet them) the whole family would respond in chorus: ‘Why, you’re forgetting; we had luncheon an hour earlier; you know very well it’s Saturday.’
当我说，除了像这次坐月子这样罕见的事情之外，我姨妈的“小慢跑”从未经历过任何变化时，我不包括那些以相同的形式定期重复的变化，真的，而不是在她的生活更加统一的基础上印上某种统一的模式。因此，举例来说，每个星期六，由于弗朗索瓦丝必须在下午去鲁桑维尔勒潘的市场，全家人都必须提前一个小时吃午饭。我姨妈已经完全养成了每周一次的例外习惯，这与她的一般习惯不同，她像其他人一样坚持这个习惯。正如弗朗索瓦丝所说，她对此已经“习惯”了，如果在星期六，她必须等到正常时间才能吃午饭，这会让她“心烦意乱”，就像她曾经有过一样，在一个平常的日子里，把午餐时间推迟到周六的时间。顺便说一句，午餐的加速给我们所有人带来了周六的个性，友善且相当有吸引力。通常，距离开饭时间还有一个小时，我们都知道，几秒钟后，我们就会看到菊苣早熟的样子，接下来是煎蛋卷的特别青睐，一块不值得的牛排这个不对称星期六的回归是那些琐碎的事件之一，壁画内的，局部的，几乎是公民的，它在平静的生活和稳定的社会秩序中创造了一种民族团结，并成为谈话和寒暄中最喜欢的主题，对于可以“按照叙述者的意愿进行刺绣的轶事”；如果我们中的任何一个人有史诗般的头脑，它就会为传奇的循环提供一个现成的核心。 天一亮，在我们穿好衣服之前，除了为了证明我们团结的力量而感到高兴之外，我们会毫无韵律或理由地互相呼唤，友好地、诚恳地、爱国地喊道：“快点，快点；快点，快点！”没有时间可以浪费；别忘了，今天是星期六！”而我的姨妈在和弗朗索瓦丝闲聊时，想到这一天会比平时更长，她会说，“你可以给他们煮一点小牛肉，因为今天是星期六。”如果十点半，有人心不在焉地掏出手表，说道：“我说，距离午餐时间还有一个半小时。”其他人都会欣喜若狂，立刻反驳道： ‘为什么，你在想什么？你忘了今天是星期六吗？”一刻钟后，我们仍然在笑，并提醒自己要上去告诉莱奥妮姨妈这个荒唐的错误，逗她开心。天空的面貌似乎也发生了变化。午饭后，太阳意识到今天是星期六，在天顶的亮度会增加一个小时，而当有人以为我们开始散步的时间已经晚了，就说：“什么，才两点钟！”圣伊莱尔尖塔上的双击使他感到强烈的悸动（通常在这个时间，高速公路上没有人经过，因为午餐或午睡而被遗弃，或者在河岸上）明亮而永远流淌的小溪，就连垂钓者也放弃了，就这样无人陪伴地溜进了空旷的天空，那里只剩下几朵徘徊的云彩迎接他们）全家人都会异口同声地回应：‘为什么，你忘了；’我们提前一个小时吃午饭；你很清楚今天是星期六。’

The surprise of a ‘barbarian’ (for so we termed everyone who was not acquainted with Saturday’s special customs) who had called at eleven o’clock to speak to my father, and had found us at table, was an event which used to cause Françoise as much merriment as, perhaps, anything that had ever happened in her life. And if she found it amusing that the nonplussed visitor should not have known, beforehand, that we had our luncheon an hour earlier on Saturday, it was still more irresistibly funny that my father himself (fully as she sympathised, from the bottom of her heart, with the rigid chauvinism which prompted him) should never have dreamed that the barbarian could fail to be aware of so simple a matter, and so had replied, with no further enlightenment of the other’s surprise at seeing us already in the dining-room: ‘You see, it’s Saturday.’ On reaching this point in the story, Françoise would pause to wipe the tears of merriment from her eyes, and then, to add to her own enjoyment, would prolong the dialogue, inventing a further reply for the visitor to whom the word ‘Saturday’ had conveyed nothing. And so far from our objecting to these interpolations, we would feel that the story was not yet long enough, and would rally her with: ‘Oh, but surely he said something else as well. There was more than that, the first time you told it.’
一个“野蛮人”（我们这样称呼所有不熟悉星期六特殊习俗的人）在十一点钟打电话给我父亲，发现我们坐在餐桌旁，这让他大吃一惊，这曾经引起了人们的注意。弗朗索瓦丝的欢乐程度可能不亚于她一生中发生过的任何事情。如果说这位不知所措的访客不应该事先知道我们周六提前一小时吃过午饭，这让她觉得很有趣，那么更令人难以抗拒的是我父亲本人（完全正如她从心底里所同情的那样） ，带着僵化的沙文主义促使他）永远不会想到野蛮人会没有意识到如此简单的事情，因此回答了，没有进一步了解对方看到我们已经在餐厅时的惊讶： “你看，今天是星期六。”故事讲到这里，弗朗索瓦丝会停下来擦掉眼中快乐的泪水，然后，为了增添自己的乐趣，她会延长对话，为对方发明进一步的回答。 “星期六”这个词对他来说没有任何意义。到目前为止，我们非但不反对这些插补，反而觉得这个故事还不够长，并会用这样的话来说服她：“哦，但他肯定还说了一些其他的话。”当你第一次告诉的时候，事情还不止这些。”

My great-aunt herself would lay aside her work, and raise her head and look on at us over her glasses.
我的姨婆本人也会放下手中的工作，抬起头，透过眼镜看着我们。

The day had yet another characteristic feature, namely, that during May we used to go out on Saturday evenings after dinner to the ‘Month of Mary’ devotions.
这一天还有另一个特点，即五月期间，我们常常在周六晚上晚饭后出去参加“玛丽月”灵修活动。

As we were liable, there, to meet M. Vinteuil, who held very strict views on ‘the deplorable untidiness of young people, which seems to be encouraged in these days,’ my mother would first see that there was nothing out of order in my appearance, and then we would set out for the church. It was in these ‘Month of Mary’ services that I can remember having first fallen in love with hawthorn-blossom. The hawthorn was not merely in the church, for there, holy ground as it was, we had all of us a right of entry; but, arranged upon the altar itself, inseparable from the mysteries in whose celebration it was playing a part, it thrust in among the tapers and the sacred vessels its rows of branches, tied to one another horizontally in a stiff, festal scheme of decoration; and they were made more lovely still by the scalloped outline of the dark leaves, over which were scattered in profusion, as over a bridal train, little clusters of buds of a dazzling whiteness. Though I dared not look at them save through my fingers, I could feel that the formal scheme was composed of living things, and that it was Nature herself who, by trimming the shape of the foliage, and by adding the crowning ornament of those snowy buds, had made the decorations worthy of what was at once a public rejoicing and a solemn mystery. Higher up on the altar, a flower had opened here and there with a careless grace, holding so unconcernedly, like a final, almost vaporous bedizening, its bunch of stamens, slender as gossamer, which clouded the flower itself in a white mist, that in following these with my eyes, in trying to imitate, somewhere inside myself, the action of their blossoming, I imagined it as a swift and thoughtless movement of the head with an enticing glance from her contracted pupils, by a young girl in white, careless and alive.
因为我们在那里有机会见到万特伊先生，他对“年轻人的邋遢行为可悲，如今似乎受到鼓励”持非常严格的看法，所以我母亲首先会发现房间里没有什么不正常的地方。我出现了，然后我们就出发去教堂。我记得正是在这些“玛丽月”仪式中，我第一次爱上了山楂花。山楂树不仅仅存在于教堂里，因为那里虽然是圣地，但我们所有人都有权进入；但是，它布置在祭坛上，与它所参与的庆祝活动密不可分，它把一排排的树枝插在蜡烛和神圣的器皿之间，这些树枝以一种僵硬的、节日的装饰方案相互水平地绑在一起。黑色叶子的扇形轮廓使它们更加可爱，叶子上散布着大量的小簇花蕾，它们的洁白令人眼花缭乱，就像新娘的拖尾一样。虽然我不敢只通过手指看它们，但我可以感觉到，正式的方案是由生物组成的，是大自然本身，通过修剪树叶的形状，并通过添加那些白雪皑皑的皇冠装饰花蕾，使这些装饰品值得立即成为公众的欢乐和庄严的神秘。 在祭坛的更高处，一朵花随处开放，漫不经心地优雅，漫不经心地举着，就像最后的、几乎是蒸汽般的睡衣，它的一束雄蕊，细长如游丝，把花本身笼罩在一层白雾中，当我用眼睛追随它们时，在我内心的某个地方试图模仿它们绽放的动作时，我把它想象成一个身穿白衣的年轻女孩迅速而轻率地转动头部，从她收缩的瞳孔中射出诱人的目光，粗心而活着。

M. Vinteuil had come in with his daughter and had sat down beside us. He belonged to a good family, and had once been music-master to my grandmother’s sisters; so that when, after losing his wife and inheriting some property, he had retired to the neighbourhood of Combray, we used often to invite him to our house. But with his intense prudishness he had given up coming, so as not to be obliged to meet Swann, who had made what he called ‘a most unsuitable marriage, as seems to be the fashion in these days.’ My mother, on hearing that he ‘composed,’ told him by way of a compliment that, when she came to see him, he must play her something of his own. M. Vinteuil would have liked nothing better, but he carried politeness and consideration for others to so fine a point, always putting himself in their place, that he was afraid of boring them, or of appearing egotistical, if he carried out, or even allowed them to suspect what were his own desires. On the day when my parents had gone to pay him a visit, I had accompanied them, but they had allowed me to remain outside, and as M. Vinteuil’s house, Montjouvain, stood on a site actually hollowed out from a steep hill covered with shrubs, among which I took cover, I had found myself on a level with his drawing-room, upstairs, and only a few feet away from its window. When a servant came in to tell him that my parents had arrived, I had seen M. Vinteuil run to the piano and lay out a sheet of music so as to catch the eye. But as soon as they entered the room he had snatched it away and hidden it in a corner. He was afraid, no doubt, of letting them suppose that he was glad to see them only because it gave him a chance of playing them some of his compositions. And every time that my mother, in the course of her visit, had returned to the subject of his playing, he had hurriedly protested: ‘I cannot think who put that on the piano; it is not the proper place for it at all,’ and had turned the conversation aside to other topics, simply because those were of less interest to himself.
文特伊先生带着他的女儿进来，坐在我们旁边。他出身于一个好家庭，曾是我祖母姐妹的音乐大师。因此，当他失去妻子并继承了一些财产后，退休到贡布雷附近时，我们经常邀请他到我们家来。但由于他的极度拘谨，他放弃了来，以免被迫与斯万见面，斯万结成了他所谓的“最不合适的婚姻，这似乎是当今的时尚。”我的母亲，听到这件事后他“作曲”，以恭维的方式告诉他，当她来看他时，他必须为她演奏一些他自己的东西。凡特伊先生本想再没有比这更好的了，但他对他人的礼貌和体贴做到了极点，总是设身处地为他人着想，以至于他害怕让他们厌烦，或者显得自负，如果他这样做的话，甚至会显得自负。让他们怀疑他自己的愿望是什么。当我父母去拜访他的那天，我陪着他们，但他们允许我留在外面，因为万特伊先生的房子，蒙茹万，坐落在一个实际上是从一座陡峭的山上挖空的地方，上面覆盖着我躲在灌木丛中，发现自己和他的客厅在同一水平线上，在楼上，距离窗户只有几英尺远。当仆人进来告诉他我父母来了时，我看到万特伊先生跑到钢琴前，摆出一张乐谱以吸引眼球。但他们一进房间，他就把它抢走了，藏在角落里。毫无疑问，他害怕让他们以为他很高兴见到他们只是因为这让他有机会向他们演奏他的一些作品。 每当我母亲在探访期间回到他演奏的话题时，他都会急忙抗议：“我想不出是谁把它放在钢琴上的； “这根本不是合适的地方。”他把话题转到了其他话题上，因为他自己对这些话题不太感兴趣。

His one and only passion was for his daughter, and she, with her somewhat boyish appearance, looked so robust that it was hard to restrain a smile when one saw the precautions her father used to take for her health, with spare shawls always in readiness to wrap around her shoulders. My grandmother had drawn our attention to the gentle, delicate, almost timid expression which might often be caught flitting across the face, dusted all over with freckles, of this otherwise stolid child. When she had spoken, she would at once take her own words in the sense in which her audience must have heard them, she would be alarmed at the possibility of a misunderstanding, and one would see, in clear outline, as though in a transparency, beneath the mannish face of the ‘good sort’ that she was, the finer features of a young woman in tears.
他唯一的热情就是对女儿，而她的外表有些孩子气，看起来那么健壮，看到父亲为她的健康采取的预防措施，随时准备着备用的披肩，人们不禁会心一笑。环绕她的肩膀。我的祖母让我们注意温柔、精致、近乎胆怯的表情，这种表情经常在这个冷漠的孩子满是雀斑的脸上掠过。当她讲话时，她会立即以她的听众一定听到的方式理解自己的话，她会对误解的可能性感到震惊，并且人们会看到清晰的轮廓，就像在透明中一样在她那张“好人”的男子气概的面孔下面，是一个泪流满面的年轻女子的美丽容貌。

When, before turning to leave the church, I made a genuflection before the altar, I felt suddenly, as I rose again, a bitter-sweet fragrance of almonds steal towards me from the hawthorn-blossom, and I then noticed that on the flowers themselves were little spots of a creamier colour, in which I imagined that this fragrance must lie concealed, as the taste of an almond cake lay in the burned parts, or the sweetness of Mile. Vinteuil’s cheeks beneath their freckles. Despite the heavy, motionless silence of the hawthorns, these gusts of fragrance came to me like the murmuring of an intense vitality, with which the whole altar was quivering like a roadside hedge explored by living antennae, of which I was reminded by seeing some stamens, almost red in colour, which seemed to have kept the springtime virulence, the irritant power of stinging insects now transmuted into flowers.
当我转身离开教堂，在祭坛前跪拜时，我再次站起身来，突然感觉一股苦甜的杏仁香味从山楂花里偷偷向我袭来，然后我注意到花上有这种味道。它们本身都是奶油色的小斑点，我想象这种香味一定隐藏在其中，就像杏仁蛋糕的味道隐藏在烧焦的部分，或者米尔的甜味一样。凡特伊的脸颊在雀斑下面。尽管山楂树沉甸甸、一动不动，但这些阵阵芬芳却像强烈生命力的低语一样向我袭来，整个祭坛都在颤抖，就像路边的树篱被活生生的触角探索，我看到一些雄蕊就想起了它。颜色近乎红色，似乎保留了春天的毒力，刺虫的刺激力现在转化为花朵。

Outside the church we would stand talking for a moment with M. Vinteuil, in the porch. Boys would be chevying one another in the Square, and he would interfere, taking the side of the little ones and lecturing the big. If his daughter said, in her thick, comfortable voice, how glad she had been to see us, immediately it would seem as though some elder and more sensitive sister, latent in her, had blushed at this thoughtless, schoolboyish utterance, which had, perhaps, made us think that she was angling for an invitation to the house. Her father would then arrange a cloak over her shoulders, they would clamber into a little dog-cart which she herself drove, and home they would both go to Montjouvain. As for ourselves, the next day being Sunday, with no need to be up and stirring before high mass, if it was a moonlight night and warm, then, instead of taking us home at once, my father, in his thirst for personal distinction, would lead us on a long walk round by the Calvary, which my mother’s utter incapacity for taking her bearings, or even for knowing which road she might be on, made her regard as a triumph of his strategic genius. Sometimes we would go as far as the viaduct, which began to stride on its long legs of stone at the railway station, and to me typified all the wretchedness of exile beyond the last outposts of civilisation, because every year, as we came down from Paris, we would be warned to take special care, when we got to Combray, not to miss the station, to be ready before the train stopped, since it would start again in two minutes and proceed across the viaduct, out of the lands of Christendom, of which Combray, to me, represented the farthest limit. We would return by the Boulevard de la Gare, which contained the most attractive villas in the town. In each of their gardens the moonlight, copying the art of Hubert Robert, had scattered its broken staircases of white marble, its fountains of water and gates temptingly ajar. Its beams had swept away the telegraph office. All that was left of it was a column, half shattered, but preserving the beauty of a ruin which endures for all time. I would by now be dragging my weary limbs, and ready to drop with sleep; the balmy scent of the lime-trees seemed a consolation which I could obtain only at the price of great suffering and exhaustion, and not worthy of the effort. From gates far apart the watchdogs, awakened by our steps in the silence, would set up an antiphonal barking, as I still hear them bark, at times, in the evenings, and it is in their custody (when the public gardens of Combray were constructed on its site) that the Boulevard de la Gare must have taken refuge, for wherever I may be, as soon as they begin their alternate challenge and acceptance, I can see it again with all its lime-trees, and its pavement glistening beneath the moon.
在教堂外面，我们会站在门廊上与万特伊先生交谈一会儿。男孩们会在广场上互相争抢，他会干涉，站在小孩子一边，教训大孩子。如果他的女儿用她浑厚、舒服的声音说，她很高兴见到我们，立刻就会显得她内心潜藏着某个年长、更敏感的姐姐，因为这句轻率、学生气的话语而脸红了，或许，这让我们以为她是在争取邀请去家里做客。然后，她的父亲会给她披上一件斗篷，他们会爬上一辆她自己驾驶的小马车，然后一起回到蒙茹万。至于我们自己，第二天是星期日，没有必要在弥撒前起床，如果那是一个月夜，天气温暖，那么，我的父亲不会立即带我们回家，因为他对个人荣誉的渴望，会带领我们沿着各各他山进行长途步行，我母亲完全无法确定自己的方位，甚至无法知道她可能走哪条路，这使她认为这是他战略天才的胜利。有时我们会一直走到高架桥，它开始在火车站的长长的石腿上大步迈进，对我来说，这代表了文明最后前哨之外的所有流亡的悲惨经历，因为每年，当我们从火车站下来时，巴黎，当我们到达贡布雷时，我们会被警告要特别小心，不要错过车站，要在火车停下来之前做好准备，因为火车将在两分钟内再次启动，并穿过高架桥，离开法国的土地。对我来说，贡布雷代表了基督教世界的最远边界。我们将沿着火车站大道返回，那里有镇上最有吸引力的别墅。 在他们的每个花园里，月光仿照休伯特·罗伯特的艺术，洒满了破碎的白色大理石楼梯、喷泉和半开着的大门。它的光束扫过了电报局。只剩下一根柱子，半毁了，但仍保留着永恒的废墟之美。我现在已经拖着疲惫的四肢，准备入睡了。椴树的芳香似乎是一种安慰，只有以巨大的痛苦和疲惫为代价才能获得这种安慰，而且不值得付出努力。远处的大门外，看门狗在寂静中被我们的脚步声惊醒，会发出对声吠叫，因为我仍然听到它们在晚上有时吠叫，它由他们看守（当贡布雷的公共花园被关闭时）。建在它的工地上），车站大道一定已经避难了，因为无论我在哪里，一旦他们开始交替挑战和接受，我就能再次看到它和它所有的椴树，以及它下面闪闪发光的人行道月亮。

Suddenly my father would bring us to a standstill and ask my mother—‘Where are we?’ Utterly worn out by the walk but still proud of her husband, she would lovingly confess that she had not the least idea. He would shrug his shoulders and laugh. And then, as though it had slipped, with his latchkey, from his waistcoat pocket, he would point out to us, when it stood before our eyes, the back-gate of our own garden, which had come hand-in-hand with the familiar corner of the Rue du Saint-Esprit, to await us, to greet us at the end of our wanderings over paths unknown. My mother would murmur admiringly ‘You really are wonderful!’ And from that instant I had not to take another step; the ground moved forward under my feet in that garden where, for so long, my actions had ceased to require any control, or even attention, from my will. Custom came to take me in her arms, carried me all the way up to my bed, and laid me down there like a little child.
突然，我的父亲会让我们停下来，问我的母亲：“我们在哪里？”她因步行而疲惫不堪，但仍然为她的丈夫感到自豪，她会亲切地承认她一无所知。他会耸耸肩笑起来。然后，仿佛它是用钥匙从背心口袋里滑出来的，当它出现在我们眼前时，他会向我们指出我们自己花园的后门，它与我们的花园齐头并进。圣埃斯普利特街熟悉的角落，等待着我们，在我们在未知的道路上徘徊的尽头迎接我们。我的母亲会钦佩地低声说：“你真是太棒了！”从那一刻起，我就不必再迈出一步了；在那个花园里，我脚下的地面向前移动，长期以来，我的行为不再需要任何控制，甚至不再需要我的意志的关注。习俗过来把我抱在怀里，一直抱到床上，像个小孩子一样把我放在床上。

Although Saturday, by beginning an hour earlier, and by depriving her of the services of Françoise, passed more slowly than other days for my aunt, yet, the moment it was past, and a new week begun, she would look forward with impatience to its return, as something that embodied all the novelty and distraction which her frail and disordered body was still able to endure. This was not to say, however, that she did not long, at times, for some even greater variation, that she did not pass through those abnormal hours in which one thirsts for something different from what one has, when those people who, through lack of energy or imagination, are unable to generate any motive power in themselves, cry out, as the clock strikes or the postman knocks, in their eagerness for news (even if it be bad news), for some emotion (even that of grief); when the heartstrings, which prosperity has silenced, like a harp laid by, yearn to be plucked and sounded again by some hand, even a brutal hand, even if it shall break them; when the will, which has with such difficulty brought itself to subdue its impulse, to renounce its right to abandon itself to its own uncontrolled desires, and consequent sufferings, would fain cast its guiding reins into the hands of circumstances, coercive and, it may be, cruel. Of course, since my aunt’s strength, which was completely drained by the slightest exertion, returned but drop by drop into the pool of her repose, the reservoir was very slow in filling, and months would go by before she reached that surplus which other people use up in their daily activities, but which she had no idea—and could never decide how to employ. And I have no doubt that then—just as a desire to have her potatoes served with béchamel sauce, for a change, would be formed, ultimately, from the pleasure she found in the daily reappearance of those mashed potatoes of which she was never ‘tired’—she would extract from the accumulation of those monotonous days (on which she so much depended) a keen expectation of some domestic cataclysm, instantaneous in its happening, but violent enough to compel her to put into effect, once for all, one of those changes which she knew would be beneficial to her health, but to which she could never make up her mind without some such stimulus. She was genuinely fond of us; she would have enjoyed the long luxury of weeping for our untimely decease; coming at a moment when she felt ‘well’ and was not in a perspiration, the news that the house was being destroyed by a fire, in which all the rest of us had already perished, a fire which, in a little while, would not leave one stone standing upon another, but from which she herself would still have plenty of time to escape without undue haste, provided that she rose at once from her bed, must often have haunted her dreams, as a prospect which combined with the two minor advantages of letting her taste the full savour of her affection for us in long years of mourning, and of causing universal stupefaction in the village when she should sally forth to conduct our obsequies, crushed but courageous, moribund but erect, the paramount and priceless boon of forcing her at the right moment, with no time to be lost, no room for weakening hesitations, to go off and spend the summer at her charming farm of Mirougrain, where there was a waterfall. Inasmuch as nothing of this sort had ever occurred, though indeed she must often have pondered the success of such a manœuvre as she lay alone absorbed in her interminable games of patience (and though it must have plunged her in despair from the first moment of its realisation, from the first of those little unforeseen facts, the first word of calamitous news, whose accents can never afterwards be expunged from the memory, everything that bears upon it the imprint of actual, physical death, so terribly different from the logical abstraction of its possibility) she would fall back from time to time, to add an interest to her life, upon imagining other, minor catastrophes, which she would follow up with passion. She would beguile herself with a sudden suspicion that Françoise had been robbing her, that she had set a trap to make certain, and had caught her betrayer red-handed; and being in the habit, when she made up a game of cards by herself, of playing her own and her adversary’s hands at once, she would first stammer out Françoise’s awkward apologies, and then reply to them with such a fiery indignation that any of us who happened to intrude upon her at one of these moments would find her bathed in perspiration, her eyes blazing, her false hair pushed awry and exposing the baldness of her brows. Françoise must often, from the next room, have heard these mordant sarcasms levelled at herself, the mere framing of which in words would not have relieved my aunt’s feelings sufficiently, had they been allowed to remain in a purely immaterial form, without the degree of substance and reality which she added to them by murmuring them half-aloud. Sometimes, however, even these counterpane dramas would not satisfy my aunt; she must see her work staged. And so, on a Sunday, with all the doors mysteriously closed, she would confide in Eulalie her doubts of Françoise’s integrity and her determination to be rid of her, and on another day she would confide in Françoise her suspicions of the disloyalty of Eulalie, to whom the front-door would very soon be closed for good. A few days more, and, disgusted with her latest confidant, she would again be ‘as thick as thieves’ with the traitor, while, before the next performance, the two would once more have changed their parts. But the suspicions which Eulalie might occasionally breed in her were no more than a fire of straw, which must soon subside for lack of fuel, since Eulalie was not living with her in the house. It was a very different matter when the suspect was Françoise, of whose presence under the same roof as herself my aunt was perpetually conscious, while for fear of catching cold, were she to leave her bed, she would never dare go downstairs to the kitchen to see for herself whether there was, indeed, any foundation for her suspicions. And so on by degrees, until her mind had no other occupation than to attempt, at every hour of the day, to discover what was being done, what was being concealed from her by Françoise. She would detect the most furtive movement of Françoise’s features, something contradictory in what she was saying, some desire which she appeared to be screening. And she would shew her that she was unmasked, by, a single word, which made Françoise turn pale, and which my aunt seemed to find a cruel satisfaction in driving into her unhappy servant’s heart. And the very next Sunday a disclosure by Eulalie—like one of those discoveries which suddenly open up an unsuspected field for exploration to some new science which has hitherto followed only the beaten paths—proved to my aunt that her own worst suspicions fell a long way short of the appalling truth. ‘But Françoise ought to know that,’ said Eulalie, ‘now that you have given her a carriage.’
虽然星期六提早一个小时开始，并且剥夺了弗朗索瓦丝的服务，对我姨妈来说比其他日子过得更慢，然而，当它过去的那一刻，新的一周开始时，她会不耐烦地期待着它的回归，体现了她脆弱而紊乱的身体仍然能够忍受的所有新奇和干扰。然而，这并不是说她有时不渴望一些更大的变化，她没有经历过那些不正常的时刻，在这些时刻，一个人渴望与自己拥有的东西不同的东西，当那些人通过缺乏精力或想象力，无法在自己身上产生任何动力，当钟声敲响或邮递员敲门时，他们渴望得到消息（即使是坏消息），渴望某种情感（甚至是悲伤） ）；当繁荣已经沉寂的心弦，像放在旁边的竖琴一样，渴望被一只手，甚至是一只残酷的手，再次拨动和敲响，即使它会折断它们；当意志艰难地克制住自己的冲动，放弃放任自己不受控制的欲望和随之而来的痛苦的权利时，就会很乐意将其主导权交到环境的手中，环境具有强制性，并且，它可能是，残忍。当然，由于姨妈稍稍用力就耗尽的体力，会一滴一滴地返回到她的休息池中，所以蓄水池的注满速度非常缓慢，要过几个月才能达到其他人所没有的剩余量。在他们的日常活动中使用，但她不知道——而且永远无法决定如何使用。 我毫不怀疑，就像她想要让土豆配贝夏梅尔酱来改变一下一样，最终，她会从每天重复出现那些她从未吃过的土豆泥中找到的乐趣而形成这种愿望。 “累了”——她会从那些单调的日子（她非常依赖这些日子）​​的积累中提取出一种对某种家庭灾难的强烈预期，这种灾难会立即发生，但猛烈到足以迫使她一劳永逸地实施一项计划。她知道这些改变对她的健康有益，但如果没有这样的刺激，她永远无法下定决心。她真的很喜欢我们。她会很享受为我们的英年早逝而哭泣的漫长时光。就在她感觉“很好”、没有出汗的时候，传来了房子被一场大火烧毁的消息，我们其他人都已经在这场大火中丧生，这场大火很快就会消失。不要让一块石头站在另一块石头上，但她自己仍然有足够的时间逃离，而不必过分匆忙，只要她立即从床上站起来，一定经常困扰她的梦，作为与这两者结合在一起的前景让她在多年的哀悼中充分品尝到她对我们的感情的小好处，当她突然出动为我们举行葬礼时，让全村人都惊呆了，被压垮但勇敢，垂死但挺直，至高无上且无价的强迫她在正确的时刻，没有时间可以浪费，没有余地犹豫，去她迷人的米鲁格兰农场度过夏天，那里有一个瀑布，这是一个福音。 因为从来没有发生过这样的事情，尽管事实上，当她独自一人沉浸在无休止的耐心游戏中时，她一定经常思考这样的策略是否成功（尽管它一定从一开始就让她陷入了绝望）从这些不可预见的小事实中的第一个，灾难性新闻的第一个字，其口音之后永远无法从记忆中删除，一切都带有实际的，肉体的死亡的印记，与逻辑抽象的可怕的不同她会不时地退后一步，为自己的生活增添乐趣，想象其他的小灾难，她会热情地跟进这些灾难。她会突然怀疑弗朗索瓦丝在抢劫她，她设置了一个陷阱来确认这一点，并当场抓住了她的背叛者，从而欺骗了自己。她习惯于自己玩牌，同时玩自己的牌和对手的牌，她会先结结巴巴地说出弗朗索瓦丝尴尬的道歉，然后以如此强烈的愤慨来回答他们，以至于任何人都不会生气。我们这些碰巧在这个时刻闯入她的人会发现她浑身是汗，眼睛闪闪发亮，假发披散着，露出了光秃秃的眉毛。弗朗索瓦丝一定经常在隔壁房间听到这些针对她自己的尖酸刻薄的讽刺，如果允许它们以纯粹非物质的形式存在，仅仅用言语来表达，并不能充分缓解我姨妈的感情。她低声低语，给这些话增添了实质和现实。然而，有时候，即使是这些床罩上的戏剧也无法让我姨妈满意。她必须看到她的作品上演。 于是，在周日，所有的门都神秘地关上了，她会向尤拉莉吐露她对弗朗索瓦丝正直的怀疑和除掉她的决心，而在另一天，她会向弗朗索瓦吐露她对尤拉莉不忠的怀疑，前门很快就会永远向他们关闭。再过几天，她对新的知己感到厌恶，又会与叛徒“如贼般亲密”，而在下一场演出之前，两人又会互换角色。但是，尤拉莉偶尔可能在她心里产生的怀疑只不过是稻草之火，由于缺乏燃料，它很快就会平息，因为尤拉莉并不和她住在一起。当嫌疑人是弗朗索瓦丝时，情况就大不相同了，姨妈永远都知道她和她住在同一屋檐下，而她一旦下床，就不敢下楼去厨房，因为害怕着凉。亲眼看看她的怀疑是否确实有根据。如此循序渐进，直到她的头脑无事可做，只能在一天中的每时每刻都试图发现弗朗索瓦丝正在做什么、向她隐瞒了什么。她会察觉到弗朗索瓦丝脸上最隐秘的动作，她所说的有些矛盾，她似乎在掩饰某种欲望。她会向她表明，只要一句话，她就被揭穿了，这句话让弗朗索瓦丝脸色苍白，而我姨妈似乎在刺入她不幸的仆人的心里找到了一种残酷的满足。 就在接下来的周日，尤拉莉的一项披露——就像那些突然为探索某些新科学开辟了一个意想不到的领域的发现之一，而迄今为止，这些新科学一直只遵循人迹罕至的道路——向我姨妈证明，她自己最严重的怀疑已经远远落空了。缺乏令人震惊的事实。 “但是弗朗索瓦丝应该知道这一点，”尤拉莉说，“既然你已经给了她一辆马车。’

‘Now that I have given her a carriage!’ gasped my aunt.
“现在我已经给她一辆马车了！”姨妈喘着气说道。

‘Oh, but I didn’t know; I only thought so; I saw her go by yesterday in her open coach, as proud as Artaban, on her way to Roussainville market. I supposed that it must be Mme. Octave who had given it to her.’
“哦，但我不知道；”我只是这么认为；昨天我看见她乘坐敞篷马车经过，像阿塔班一样骄傲，前往鲁桑维尔市场。我猜想一定是夫人。奥克塔夫把它给了她。

So on by degrees, until Françoise and my aunt, the quarry and the hunter, could never cease from trying to forestall each other’s devices. My mother was afraid lest Françoise should develop a genuine hatred of my aunt, who was doing everything in her power to annoy her. However that might be, Françoise had come, more and more, to pay an infinitely scrupulous attention to my aunt’s least word and gesture. When she had to ask her for anything she would hesitate, first, for a long time, making up her mind how best to begin. And when she had uttered her request, she would watch my aunt covertly, trying to guess from the expression on her face what she thought of it, and how she would reply. And in this way—whereas an artist who had been reading memoirs of the seventeenth century, and wished to bring himself nearer to the great Louis, would consider that he was making progress in that direction when he constructed a pedigree that traced his own descent from some historic family, or when he engaged in correspondence with one of the reigning Sovereigns of Europe, and so would shut his eyes to the mistake he was making in seeking to establish a similarity by an exact and therefore lifeless copy of mere outward forms—a middle-aged lady in a small country town, by doing no more than yield whole-hearted obedience to her own irresistible eccentricities, and to a spirit of mischief engendered by the utter idleness of her existence, could see, without ever having given a thought to Louis XIV, the most trivial occupations of her daily life, her morning toilet, her luncheon, her afternoon nap, assume, by virtue of their despotic singularity, something of the interest that was to be found in what Saint-Simon used to call the ‘machinery’ of life at Versailles; and was able, too, to persuade herself that her silence, a shade of good humour or of arrogance on her features, would provide Françoise with matter for a mental commentary as tense with passion and terror, as did the silence, the good humour or the arrogance of the King when a courtier, or even his greatest nobles, had presented a petition to him, at the turning of an avenue, at Versailles.
就这样渐渐地，直到弗朗索瓦丝和我的姨妈，即采石场和猎人，不断地试图阻止对方的装置。我母亲担心弗朗索瓦丝会对我姨妈产生真正的仇恨，因为她竭尽全力惹恼她。不管怎样，弗朗索瓦丝已经越来越仔细地注意我姨妈最细微的言语和动作。当她必须向她询问任何事情时，她首先会犹豫很长时间，决定如何最好地开始。而当她说出自己的要求时，她就会偷偷地看着我姑姑，从她的表情中猜测她的想法，以及她会如何回答。 通过这种方式，一位一直在阅读 17 世纪回忆录并希望能更接近伟大的路易的艺术家，会认为当他构建了一个追溯自己血统的谱系时，他正在朝这个方向取得进展。某个历史家族，或者当他与欧洲的一位在位君主进行通信时，他就会对自己在寻求通过纯粹的外在形式的精确且因此毫无生气的复制品来建立相似性时所犯的错误视而不见。一个乡村小镇上的中年女士，除了全心全意地服从自己不可抗拒的怪癖，以及由于她的存在完全无所事事而产生的恶作剧精神之外，她不假思索地就看到了这一点。对于路易十四来说，她日常生活中最琐碎的事情，她早上的厕所，她的午餐，她下午的小睡，凭借其专制的独特性，假定了一些有趣的东西，可以在圣西门过去所说的中找到凡尔赛宫生活的“机器”；她也能够说服自己，她的沉默，脸上带着一丝幽默感或傲慢，将为弗朗索瓦丝提供精神评论的素材，就像她的沉默、幽默感或傲慢一样，她的精神评论充满了激情和恐惧。当一位朝臣，甚至是他最伟大的贵族，在凡尔赛宫的一条大道拐角处向国王提出请愿书时，国王表现出了傲慢的态度。

One Sunday, when my aunt had received simultaneous visits from the Curé and from Eulalie, and had been left alone, afterwards, to rest, the whole family went upstairs to bid her good night, and Mamma ventured to condole with her on the unlucky coincidence that always brought both visitors to her door at the same time.
一个星期天，当我的姨妈同时受到本堂神父和尤拉莉的探访，然后独自一人休息时，全家人都上楼向她道晚安，妈妈冒险对她这一不幸的巧合表示哀悼。这总是让两位访客同时来到她家门口。

‘I hear that things went wrong again to-day, Léonie,’ she said kindly, ‘you have had all your friends here at once.’
“我听说今天又出了问题，莱奥妮，”她和蔼地说，“你所有的朋友都在这儿了。”

And my great-aunt interrupted with: ‘Too many good things...’ for, since her daughter’s illness, she felt herself in duty bound to revive her as far as possible by always drawing her attention to the brighter side of things. But my father had begun to speak.
我的姨婆打断道：“太多好东西了……”因为自从她女儿生病以来，她觉得自己有责任让她尽可能地恢复活力，总是让她注意事物光明的一面。但我父亲已经开始说话了。

‘I should like to take advantage,’ he said, ‘of the whole family’s being here together, to tell you a story, so as not to have to begin all over again to each of you separately. I am afraid we are in M. Legrandin’s bad books; he would hardly say ‘How d’ye do’ to me this morning.’
“我想利用全家人都聚在一起的机会，”他说，“给你们讲一个故事，这样就不用分别给你们每个人重新开始了。”恐怕我们已经被勒格朗丹先生列入坏书了；今天早上他几乎不会对我说‘你好吗’。”

I did not wait to hear the end of my father’s story, for I had been with him myself after mass when we had passed M. Legrandin; instead, I went downstairs to the kitchen to ask for the bill of fare for our dinner, which was of fresh interest to me daily, like the news in a paper, and excited me as might the programme of a coming festivity.
我没等到父亲的故事结束，因为弥撒结束后，我们经过勒格朗丹先生时，我自己也在他身边。相反，我下楼到厨房要了晚餐的账单，这对我来说每天都是新的兴趣，就像报纸上的新闻一样，让我兴奋不已，就像即将到来的节日节目一样。

As M. Legrandin had passed close by us on our way from church, walking by the side of a lady, the owner of a country house in the neighbourhood, whom we knew only by sight, my father had saluted him in a manner at once friendly and reserved, without stopping in his walk; M. Legrandin had barely acknowledged the courtesy, and then with an air of surprise, as though he had not recognised us, and with that distant look characteristic of people who do not wish to be agreeable, and who from the suddenly receding depths of their eyes seem to have caught sight of you at the far end of an interminably straight road, and at so great a distance that they content themselves with directing towards you an almost imperceptible movement of the head, in proportion to your doll-like dimensions.
当勒格朗丹先生在我们离开教堂的路上经过我们身边时，他走在一位女士身边，她是附近一栋乡间别墅的主人，我们只见过她一眼，我父亲立即向他致敬友善而矜持，走路时不停歇；勒格朗丹先生几乎没有表示礼貌，然后带着惊讶的神情，好像他没有认出我们一样，并且带着那种不希望和蔼可亲的人特有的疏远神情，他们从他们的内心深处突然退缩。眼睛似乎在一条无边无际的笔直道路的尽头看到了你，距离如此之远，以至于它们满足于将头部几乎难以​​察觉的运动指向你，与你娃娃般的尺寸成比例。

Now, the lady who was walking with Legrandin was a model of virtue, known and highly respected; there could be no question of his being out for amorous adventure, and annoyed at being detected; and my father asked himself how he could possibly have displeased our friend.
现在，与勒格朗丹同行的那位女士是一位美德的典范，广为人知，备受尊敬。毫无疑问，他是在进行一场多情的冒险，并且因为被发现而感到恼火。我父亲问自己，他怎么可能让我们的朋友不高兴。

‘I should be all the more sorry to feel that he was angry with us,’ he said, ‘because among all those people in their Sunday clothes there is something about him, with his little cut-away coat and his soft neckties, so little ‘dressed-up,’ so genuinely simple; an air of innocence, almost, which is really attractive.’
“如果他对我们生气，我会感到更加遗憾，”他说，“因为在所有那些穿着周日服装的人中，他身上有一些关于他的东西，他穿着小外套和柔软的领带，所以小“打扮”，如此简单；几乎是一种天真无邪的气质，这真的很有吸引力。

But the vote of the family council was unanimous, that my father had imagined the whole thing, or that Legrandin, at the moment in question, had been preoccupied in thinking about something else. Anyhow, my father’s fears were dissipated no later than the following evening. As we returned from a long walk we saw, near the Pont-Vieux, Legrandin himself, who, on account of the holidays, was spending a few days more in Combray. He came up to us with outstretched hand: ‘Do you know, master book-lover,’ he asked me, ‘this line of Paul Desjardins?
但家族委员会的投票一致认为，整件事都是我父亲想象出来的，或者说，勒格朗丹此刻正全神贯注地想着别的事情。不管怎样，我父亲的恐惧最晚在第二天晚上就消失了。当我们长途跋涉回来时，我们在老桥附近看到了勒格朗丹本人，由于假期的原因，他在贡布雷又待了几天。他向我们伸出手：“你知道吗，书迷大师，”他问我，“保罗·德贾丁的这句话吗？”

Now are the woods all black, but still the sky is blue.
现在树林全黑了，但天空仍然是蓝色的。

Is not that a fine rendering of a moment like this? Perhaps you have never read Paul Desjardins. Read him, my boy, read him; in these days he is converted, they tell me, into a preaching friar, but he used to have the most charming water-colour touch—
这不正是对这样一个时刻的美好渲染吗？也许你从未读过保罗·德贾丁 (Paul Desjardins) 的书。读读他，我的孩子，读读他；他们告诉我，这些天他已经转变为一名传教修道士，但他曾经拥有最迷人的水彩画风格——

Now are the woods all black, but still the sky is blue.
现在树林全黑了，但天空仍然是蓝色的。

May you always see a blue sky overhead, my young friend; and then, even when the time comes, which is coming now for me, when the woods are all black, when night is fast falling, you will be able to console yourself, as I am doing, by looking up to the sky.’ He took a cigarette from his pocket and stood for a long time, his eyes fixed on the horizon. ‘Goodbye, friends!’ he suddenly exclaimed, and left us.
愿你头顶上永远可见蓝天，我年轻的朋友；然后，即使那个时刻到来了，对我来说，现在就到了，当树林全黑时，当夜幕很快降临时，你也能像我一样，通过仰望天空来安慰自己。他从口袋里掏出一根香烟，站了很长时间，眼睛盯着地平线。 “再见，朋友们！”他突然喊道，然后就离开了我们。

At the hour when I usually went downstairs to find out what there was for dinner, its preparation would already have begun, and Françoise, a colonel with all the forces of nature for her subalterns, as in the fairy-tales where giants hire themselves out as scullions, would be stirring the coals, putting the potatoes to steam, and, at the right moment, finishing over the fire those culinary masterpieces which had been first got ready in some of the great array of vessels, triumphs of the potter’s craft, which ranged from tubs and boilers and cauldrons and fish kettles down to jars for game, moulds for pastry, and tiny pannikins for cream, and included an entire collection of pots and pans of every shape and size. I would stop by the table, where the kitchen-maid had shelled them, to inspect the platoons of peas, drawn up in ranks and numbered, like little green marbles, ready for a game; but what fascinated me would be the asparagus, tinged with ultramarine and rosy pink which ran from their heads, finely stippled in mauve and azure, through a series of imperceptible changes to their white feet, still stained a little by the soil of their garden-bed: a rainbow-loveliness that was not of this world. I felt that these celestial hues indicated the presence of exquisite creatures who had been pleased to assume vegetable form, who, through the disguise which covered their firm and edible flesh, allowed me to discern in this radiance of earliest dawn, these hinted rainbows, these blue evening shades, that precious quality which I should recognise again when, all night long after a dinner at which I had partaken of them, they played (lyrical and coarse in their jesting as the fairies in Shakespeare’s Dream) at transforming my humble chamber into a bower of aromatic perfume.
当我通常下楼去看看晚餐有什么的时候，它的准备工作就已经开始了，而弗朗索瓦丝，一个上校，为她的下属提供了所有自然的力量，就像童话故事里巨人雇佣自己一样作为仆人，他们会搅拌煤炭，将土豆蒸熟，并在适当的时候，在火上完成那些首先在一些伟大的容器中准备好的烹饪杰作，这是陶工手艺的胜利，其中包括从浴缸、锅炉、大锅和鱼水壶到野味罐子、糕点模具和奶油小锅，还包括各种形状和尺寸的锅碗瓢盆。我会在厨房女仆剥豌豆的桌子旁停下来，检查一排排的豌豆，它们排成一排并编号，就像准备比赛的绿色小弹珠一样。但让我着迷的是芦笋，带着群青色和玫瑰粉色，从它们的头上流淌出来，精细地点缀着淡紫色和天蓝色，通过它们白色的脚的一系列难以察觉的变化，仍然被花园里的土壤弄脏了一点——床：彩虹般的可爱，不属于这个世界。我觉得这些天国的色彩表明了精致生物的存在，它们很乐意呈现出植物的形态，它们通过覆盖其坚固且可食用的肉的伪装，使我能够在黎明的光芒中辨别出这些暗示的彩虹，这些蓝色的夜色，当我在晚餐后整晚都在玩耍时，我应该再次认识到这种宝贵的品质（像莎士比亚梦中的仙女一样，抒情而粗俗地开玩笑）将我简陋的房间改造成芬芳香水的凉亭

Poor Giotto’s Charity, as Swann had named her, charged by Françoise with the task of preparing them for the table, would have them lying beside her in a basket; sitting with a mournful air, as though all the sorrows of the world were heaped upon her; and the light crowns of azure which capped the asparagus shoots above their pink jackets would be finely and separately outlined, star by star, as in Giotto’s fresco are the flowers banded about the brows, or patterning the basket of his Virtue at Padua. And, meanwhile, Françoise would be turning on the spit one of those chickens, such as she alone knew how to roast, chickens which had wafted far abroad from Combray the sweet savour of her merits, and which, while she was serving them to us at table, would make the quality of kindness predominate for the moment in my private conception of her character; the aroma of that cooked flesh, which she knew how to make so unctuous and so tender, seeming to me no more than the proper perfume of one of her many virtues.
斯旺给她起了个可怜的乔托慈善机构的名字，弗朗索瓦丝指派她为餐桌准备这些食物，她会把这些食物装在篮子里放在她身边。坐着，神态悲哀，仿佛世间所有的悲伤都堆在她身上。粉红色外套上方芦笋枝上的浅蓝色王冠将被精细而单独地勾勒出来，一颗颗一颗地排列，就像乔托的壁画中眉毛周围的花朵，或者是他在帕多瓦的美德篮子的图案。与此同时，弗朗索瓦丝会打开其中一只鸡的吐司，只有她知道如何烤这些鸡，这些鸡从贡布雷远远地飘到了国外，散发着她的优点的甜味，当她为我们服务时，这些鸡在餐桌上，在我个人对她性格的看法中，善良的品质暂时占主导地位。煮熟的肉的香气，她知道如何使之变得如此油腻和柔软，在我看来，这只不过是她众多美德之一的适当香水。

But the day on which, while my father took counsel with his family upon our strange meeting with Legrandin, I went down to the kitchen, was one of those days when Giotto’s Charity, still very weak and ill after her recent confinement, had been unable to rise from her bed; Françoise, being without assistance, had fallen into arrears. When I went in, I saw her in the back-kitchen which opened on to the courtyard, in process of killing a chicken; by its desperate and quite natural resistance, which Françoise, beside herself with rage as she attempted to slit its throat beneath the ear, accompanied with shrill cries of ‘Filthy creature! Filthy creature!’ it made the saintly kindness and unction of our servant rather less prominent than it would do, next day at dinner, when it made its appearance in a skin gold-embroidered like a chasuble, and its precious juice was poured out drop by drop as from a pyx. When it was dead Françoise mopped up its streaming blood, in which, however, she did not let her rancour drown, for she gave vent to another burst of rage, and, gazing down at the carcass of her enemy, uttered a final ‘Filthy creature!’
但是那天，当我父亲与他的家人就我们与勒格朗丹的奇怪会面进行商议时，我下楼去厨房，那一天是乔托的慈善机构，在她最近被监禁后仍然非常虚弱和生病，无法做到这一点。从床上起来；弗朗索瓦丝由于得不到援助，陷入了欠款状态。当我进去时，我看到她在通向庭院的后厨房里正在杀鸡。弗朗索瓦丝愤怒地试图从耳朵下面割开它的喉咙，同时伴随着“肮脏的生物！”的尖叫声。肮脏的生物！”它使我们仆人的圣洁仁慈和油腻变得不那么突出了，第二天晚餐时，当它出现在像祭祀服一样的金色刺绣的皮肤上时，它珍贵的汁液被倒出来一滴通过从金字塔掉落。当它死后，弗朗索瓦丝擦掉了它流淌的血，然而，她并没有让她的怨恨淹没，因为她又爆发了一阵愤怒，她低头看着敌人的尸体，最后说了一句“肮脏的”。生物！

I crept out of the kitchen and upstairs, trembling all over; I could have prayed, then, for the instant dismissal of Françoise. But who would have baked me such hot rolls, boiled me such fragrant coffee, and even—roasted me such chickens? And, as it happened, everyone else had already had to make the same cowardly reckoning. For my aunt Léonie knew (though I was still in ignorance of this) that Françoise, who, for her own daughter or for her nephews, would have given her life without a murmur, shewed a singular implacability in her dealings with the rest of the world. In spite of which my aunt still retained her, for, while conscious of her cruelty, she could appreciate her services. I began gradually to realise that Françoise’s kindness, her compunction, the sum total of her virtues concealed many of these back-kitchen tragedies, just as history reveals to us that the reigns of the kings and queens who are portrayed as kneeling with clasped hands in the windows of churches, were stained by oppression and bloodshed. I had taken note of the fact that, apart from her own kinsfolk, the sufferings of humanity inspired in her a pity which increased in direct ratio to the distance separating the sufferers from herself. The tears which flowed from her in torrents when she read of the misfortunes of persons unknown to her, in a newspaper, were quickly stemmed once she had been able to form a more accurate mental picture of the victims. One night, shortly after her confinement, the kitchen-maid was seized with the most appalling pains; Mamma heard her groans, and rose and awakened Françoise, who, quite unmoved, declared that all the outcry was mere malingering, that the girl wanted to ‘play the mistress’ in the house. The doctor, who had been afraid of some such attack, had left a marker in a medical dictionary which we had, at the page on which the symptoms were described, and had told us to turn up this passage, where we would find the measures of ‘first aid’ to be adopted. My mother sent Françoise to fetch the book, warning her not to let the marker drop out. An hour elapsed, and Françoise had not returned; my mother, supposing that she had gone back to bed, grew vexed, and told me to go myself to the bookcase and fetch the volume. I did so, and there found Françoise who, in her curiosity to know what the marker indicated, had begun to read the clinical account of these after-pains, and was violently sobbing, now that it was a question of a type of illness with which she was not familiar. At each painful symptom mentioned by the writer she would exclaim: ‘Oh, oh, Holy Virgin, is it possible that God wishes any wretched human creature to suffer so? Oh, the poor girl!’
我蹑手蹑脚地走出厨房，爬上楼，浑身发抖。那么，我本可以祈祷弗朗索瓦丝立即被解雇。但谁会给我烤这么热的面包卷，给我煮这么香的咖啡，甚至——给我烤这样的鸡？而且，正如事情发生的那样，其他人都已经不得不做出同样的懦弱的计算。因为我姨妈莱奥妮知道（尽管我还不知道这一点）弗朗索瓦丝在与其他人打交道时表现出一种奇特的不可调和的态度，为了她自己的女儿或她的侄子，她会毫无怨言地献出自己的生命。世界。尽管如此，我姑姑仍然保留了她，因为虽然意识到她的残忍，但她还是很感激她的服务。我开始逐渐认识到，弗朗索瓦丝的善良、她的悔恨、她的美德的总和掩盖了许多这些后厨房的悲剧，正如历史向我们揭示的那样，那些被描绘成双手合十跪下的国王和王后的统治时期。教堂的窗户因压迫和流血而被玷污。我注意到这样一个事实：除了她自己的亲人之外，人类的苦难也激发了她的怜悯之心，这种怜悯之心与受害者与她之间的距离成正比。当她在报纸上读到一些不认识的人的不幸遭遇时，她的眼泪夺眶而出，但当她能够在心里对受害者有更准确的认识时，她很快就止住了。一天晚上，就在她出世后不久，厨房女仆感到一阵剧烈的疼痛。妈妈听到了她的呻吟声，站起来叫醒了弗朗索瓦丝，弗朗索瓦丝毫不为所动，宣称所有的抗议都只是装病，女孩想在家里“扮演女主人”。 医生担心会发生此类攻击，因此在我们拥有的医学词典中描述症状的页面上留下了记号，并告诉我们打开这段文字，在那里我们可以找到治疗措施的“急救”被采用。我母亲派弗朗索瓦丝去拿书，警告她不要让记号笔掉下来。一个小时过去了，弗朗索瓦丝还没有回来。母亲以为她已经回去睡觉了，就生气了，让我自己去书柜拿书。我这样做了，发现了弗朗索瓦丝，她出于好奇想知道标记所指示的内容，开始阅读这些后痛的临床描述，并且剧烈地抽泣，现在这是一种与疾病相关的问题。她对此并不熟悉。当作者提到每一个痛苦的症状时，她都会惊呼：“哦，哦，圣母，上帝有可能希望任何可怜的人类遭受这样的痛苦吗？”哦，可怜的女孩！’

But when I had called her, and she had returned to the bedside of Giotto’s Charity, her tears at once ceased to flow; she could find no stimulus for that pleasant sensation of tenderness and pity which she very well knew, having been moved to it often enough by the perusal of newspapers; nor any other pleasure of the same kind in her sense of weariness and irritation at being pulled out of bed in the middle of the night for the kitchen-maid; so that at the sight of those very sufferings, the printed account of which had moved her to tears, she had nothing to offer but ill-tempered mutterings, mingled with bitter sarcasm, saying, when she thought that we had gone out of earshot: ‘Well, she need never have done what she must have done to bring all this about! She found that pleasant enough, I dare say! She had better not put on any airs now. All the same, he must have been a god-forsaken young man to go after that. Dear, dear, it’s just as they used to say in my poor mother’s country:
但当我打电话给她，她又回到乔托慈善机构的床边时，她的眼泪立刻就止住了。她找不到任何刺激物来刺激那种令人愉悦的温柔和怜悯的感觉，她非常熟悉这种感觉，因为她经常通过阅读报纸而被感动。半夜被厨房女仆从床上拉起来时，她感到疲倦和恼怒，也没有任何其他类似的快乐；因此，当看到那些让她感动得热泪盈眶的痛苦经历时，她除了脾气暴躁的嘟囔，夹杂着苦涩的讽刺之外，什么也说不出来，当她以为我们已经消失在听不到的地方时，她说：好吧，她根本不需要做她必须做的事情来实现这一切！我敢说，她觉得这足够令人愉快了！她现在最好不要摆架子。尽管如此，他一定是一个被上帝抛弃的年轻人，才去追求那件事。亲爱的，亲爱的，就像我可怜的母亲的国家里人们常说的那样：

Snaps and snails and puppy-dogs’ tails,
啪嗒啪嗒、蜗牛和小狗的尾巴，

 And dirty sluts in plenty,
还有大量肮脏的荡妇，

Smell sweeter than roses in young men’s noses
年轻人鼻子里闻起来比玫瑰还甜

 When the heart is one-and-twenty.’
当心是一又二十的时候。

Although, when her grandson had a slight cold in his head, she would Bet off at night, even if she were ill also, instead of going to bed, to see whether he had everything that he wanted, covering ten miles on foot before daybreak so as to be in time to begin her work, this same love for her own people, and her desire to establish the future greatness of her house on a solid foundation reacted, in her policy with regard to the other servants, in one unvarying maxim, which was never to let any of them set foot in my aunt’s room; indeed she shewed a sort of pride in not allowing anyone else to come near my aunt, preferring, when she herself was ill, to get out of bed and to administer the Vichy water in person, rather than to concede to the kitchen-maid the right of entry into her mistress’s presence. There is a species of hymenoptera, observed by Fabre, the burrowing wasp, which in order to provide a supply of fresh meat for her offspring after her own decease, calls in the science of anatomy to amplify the resources of her instinctive cruelty, and, having made a collection of weevils and spiders, proceeds with marvellous knowledge and skill to pierce the nerve-centre on which their power of locomotion (but none of their other vital functions) depends, so that the paralysed insect, beside which her egg is laid, will furnish the larva, when it is hatched, with a tamed and inoffensive quarry, incapable either of flight or of resistance, but perfectly fresh for the larder: in the same way Françoise had adopted, to minister to her permanent and unfaltering resolution to render the house uninhabitable to any other servant, a series of crafty and pitiless stratagems.
