But while each of these attachments, each of these flirtations had been the realisation, more or less complete, of a dream born of the sight of a face or a form which Swann had spontaneously, and without effort on his part, found charming, it was quite another matter when, one day at the theatre, he was introduced to Odette de Crécy by an old friend of his own, who had spoken of her to him as a ravishing creature with whom he might very possibly come to an understanding; but had made her out to be harder of conquest than she actually was, so as to appear to be conferring a special favour by the introduction. She had struck Swann not, certainly, as being devoid of beauty, but as endowed with a style of beauty which left him indifferent, which aroused in him no desire, which gave him, indeed, a sort of physical repulsion; as one of those women of whom every man can name some, and each will name different examples, who are the converse of the type which our senses demand. To give him any pleasure her profile was too sharp, her skin too delicate, her cheek-bones too prominent, her features too tightly drawn. Her eyes were fine, but so large that they seemed to be bending beneath their own weight, strained the rest of her face and always made her appear unwell or in an ill humour. Some time after this introduction at the theatre she had written to ask Swann whether she might see his collections, which would interest her so much, she, ‘an ignorant woman with a taste for beautiful things,’ saying that she would know him better when once she had seen him in his ‘home,’ where she imagined him to be ‘so comfortable with his tea and his books”; although she had not concealed her surprise at his being in that part of the town, which must be so depressing, and was ‘not nearly smart enough for such a very smart man.’ And when he allowed her to come she had said to him as she left how sorry she was to have stayed so short a time in a house into which she was so glad to have found her way at last, speaking of him as though he had meant something more to her than the rest of the people she knew, and appearing to unite their two selves with a kind of romantic bond which had made him smile. But at the time of life, tinged already with disenchantment, which Swann was approaching, when a man can content himself with being in love for the pleasure of loving without expecting too much in return, this linking of hearts, if it is no longer, as in early youth, the goal towards which love, of necessity, tends, still is bound to love by so strong an association of ideas that it may well become the cause of love if it presents itself first. In his younger days a man dreams of possessing the heart of the woman whom he loves; later, the feeling that he possesses the heart of a woman may be enough to make him fall in love with her. And 50, at an age when it would appear—since one seeks in love before everything else a subjective pleasure—that the taste for feminine beauty must play the larger part in its procreation, love may come into being, love of the most physical order, without any foundation in desire. At this time of life a man has already been wounded more than once by the darts of love; it no longer evolves by itself, obeying its own incomprehensible and fatal laws, before his passive and astonished heart. We come to its aid; we falsify it by memory and by suggestion; recognising one of its symptoms we recall and recreate the rest. Since we possess its hymn, engraved on our hearts in its entirety, there is no need of any woman to repeat the opening lines, potent with the admiration which her beauty inspires, for us to remember all that follows. And if she begin in the middle, where it sings of our existing, henceforward, for one another only, we are well enough attuned to that music to be able to take it up and follow our partner, without hesitation, at the first pause in her voice.
但是，虽然每一次依恋，每一次调情或多或少都是对一个梦想的实现，这个梦想是由斯万自发地、不费吹灰之力地发现的一张脸或一个形状而产生的，他觉得很迷人，但另一回事是，有一天在剧院，他的一位老朋友把他介绍给奥黛特·德·克雷西，这位老友对他说，她是一个令人着迷的女人，他很可能会与她达成谅解；但他的表现却完全不同。但把她表现得比实际情况更难征服，以便通过介绍显得她受到了特殊的照顾。当然，她给斯旺的印象并不是缺乏美感，而是赋予了他一种冷漠的美感，这种美感没有激起他的欲望，事实上，这给了他一种身体上的排斥感。作为那些每个男人都能说出一些名字的女性之一，每个人都会举出不同的例子，她们与我们的感官所要求的类型相反。为了给他带来任何乐趣，她的轮廓太尖锐，她的皮肤太细腻，她的颧骨太突出，她的五官太紧致。她的眼睛很好，但太大了，似乎在自身重量的作用下弯曲，拉紧了她脸上的其他部分，总是让她看起来不舒服或心情不好。 在剧院的介绍之后一段时间，她写信询问斯旺是否可以看看他的收藏品，这会让她非常感兴趣，她，“一个对美丽事物有品味的无知女人”，说当她看到他的作品时，她会更了解他。有一次她在他的“家里”见过他，想象他“对茶和书感到如此自在”；尽管她并没有掩饰对他出现在镇上那个地方的惊讶，那地方一定很令人沮丧，而且“对于这样一个非常聪明的男人来说，他还不够聪明。”当他允许她来时，她对他说当她离开时，她非常遗憾在这座房子里呆了这么短的时间，她很高兴终于找到了自己的路，说起他就好像他对她来说比其他人更重要。他知道，并且似乎以一种浪漫的纽带将他们两个人结合在一起，这让他微笑起来。但在人生的阶段，斯万正在接近这种幻灭的感觉，当一个人可以满足于为了爱的快乐而恋爱，而不期望太多的回报时，这种心灵的联系，如果不再，就像在青年时代一样，爱必然趋向的目标仍然通过如此强烈的观念联系而束缚于爱，以至于如果它首先出现，它很可能成为爱的原因。年轻时，男人梦想着能占有自己所爱女人的心；后来，他拥有一颗女人心的感觉也许就足以让他爱上她了。 50岁，在这个年纪——因为一个人在爱情中首先寻求的是一种主观的快乐——对女性美的品味必须在其生育中发挥更大的作用，爱情可能会出现，最肉体的爱情，没有任何欲望的基础。人在人生的这个阶段，已经不止一次地被爱情的箭刺伤了。在他被动而惊讶的心面前，它不再自行演化，遵循着它自己不可理解的致命法则。我们来帮助它；我们通过记忆和暗示来伪造它；认识到其中一种症状，我们就会回忆并重现其余的症状。既然我们拥有这首赞美诗，将其完整地铭刻在我们的心上，那么就不需要任何女人重复她的美丽所激发的钦佩的开场诗句，让我们记住接下来的一切。如果她从中间开始，唱出我们的存在，从今往后，只为彼此，我们就足够适应这种音乐，能够在第一次停顿时毫不犹豫地拿起它并跟随我们的伴侣。她的声音。

Odette de Crécy came again to see Swann; her visits grew more frequent, and doubtless each visit revived the sense of disappointment which he felt at the sight of a face whose details he had somewhat forgotten in the interval, not remembering it as either so expressive or, in spite of her youth, so faded; he used to regret, while she was talking to him, that her really considerable beauty was not of the kind which he spontaneously admired. It must be remarked that Odette’s face appeared thinner and more prominent than it actually was, because her forehead and the upper part of her cheeks, a single and almost plane surface, were covered by the masses of hair which women wore at that period, drawn forward in a fringe, raised in crimped waves and falling in stray locks over her ears; while as for her figure, and she was admirably built, it was impossible to make out its continuity (on account of the fashion then prevailing, and in spite of her being one of the best-dressed women in Paris) for the corset, jetting forwards in an arch, as though over an imaginary stomach, and ending in a sharp point, beneath which bulged out the balloon of her double skirts, gave a woman, that year, the appearance of being composed of different sections badly fitted together; to such an extent did the frills, the flounces, the inner bodice follow, in complete independence, controlled only by the fancy of their designer or the rigidity of their material, the line which led them to the knots of ribbon, falls of lace, fringes of vertically hanging jet, or carried them along the bust, but nowhere attached themselves to the living creature, who, according as the architecture of their fripperies drew them towards or away from her own, found herself either strait-laced to suffocation or else completely buried.
奥黛特·德·克雷西再次来看望斯万。她的来访变得越来越频繁，毫无疑问，每次来访都会使他再次感到失望，因为他在看到这张脸时所感到的失望感在这段时间里他已经忘记了她的细节，不记得她是如此富有表现力，或者尽管她很年轻，但他却忘记了她的细节。褪色了；当她与他交谈时，他常常感到遗憾，因为她真正的美貌并不是他自发欣赏的那种。 必须指出的是，奥黛特的脸比实际情况显得更瘦、更突出，因为她的前额和脸颊的上部是一个几乎平坦的表面，上面覆盖着当时妇女所留的大量头发，刘海向前，卷曲的波浪卷起，散乱的发绺垂在耳朵上；至于她的身材，她的身材令人赞叹，但由于紧身胸衣的存在，不可能看出其连续性（考虑到当时流行的时尚，尽管她是巴黎穿着最好的女性之一），向前呈拱形，仿佛在想象中的肚子上，最后是一个尖点，在尖点下，双裙子的气球鼓起来，使那一年的女人看起来像是由不同的部分组成的，但很不合适。在这种程度上，褶边、荷叶边、内部紧身胸衣完全独立，仅受设计师的奇思妙想或材料的刚性控制，将它们引向丝带结、蕾丝垂坠的线条，垂直悬挂的黑玉的边缘，或沿着半身像携带它们，但没有任何地方将自己附着在生物上，根据它们的华丽结构将它们吸引到或远离她自己的，发现自己要么被束缚窒息，要么否则完全被掩埋。

But, after Odette had left him, Swann would think with a smile of her telling him how the time would drag until he allowed her to come again; he remembered the anxious, timid way in which she had once begged him that it might not be very long, and the way in which she had looked at him then, fixing upon him her fearful and imploring gaze, which gave her a touching air beneath the bunches of artificial pansies fastened in the front of her round bonnet of white straw, tied with strings of black velvet. ‘And won’t you,’ she had ventured, ‘come just once and take tea with me?’ He had pleaded pressure of work, an essay—which, in reality, he had abandoned years ago—on Vermeer of Delft. ‘I know that I am quite useless,’ she had replied, ‘a little wild thing like me beside a learned great man like you. I should be like the frog in the fable! And yet I should so much like to learn, to know things, to be initiated. What fun it would be to become a regular bookworm, to bury my nose in a lot of old papers!’ she had gone on, with that self-satisfied air which a smart woman adopts when she insists that her one desire is to give herself up, without fear of soiling her fingers, to some unclean task, such as cooking the dinner, with her ‘hands right in the dish itself.’ ‘You will only laugh at me, but this painter who stops you from seeing me,’ she meant Vermeer, ‘I have never even heard of him; is he alive still? Can I see any of his things in Paris, so as to have some idea of what is going on behind that great brow which works so hard, that head which I feel sure is always puzzling away about things; just to be able to say ‘There, that’s what he’s thinking about!’ What a dream it would be to be able to help you with your work.’
但是，在奥黛特离开他之后，斯万会微笑着想起她告诉他，在他允许她再次到来之前，时间会多么漫长；他会告诉他，时间会多么漫长。他记得她曾经焦急而胆怯地恳求他不要待太久，还记得她当时看着他的方式，她用恐惧和恳求的目光注视着他，这让她的气质显得很动人。一束束人造三色堇固定在她白色稻草圆帽的前面，并用黑色天鹅绒绳子系着。 “你不想来一次，和我一起喝茶吗？”她大胆地说，“他以工作压力为借口，写了一篇关于代尔夫特的维米尔的文章——事实上，他几年前就放弃了。” “我知道我很没用，”她回答道，“在像你这样博学的伟人身边，我就是个小野人。”我应该像寓言中的青蛙一样！但我还是非常喜欢学习、了解事物、受到启发。成为一个普通的书虫，把鼻子埋在大量的旧报纸里，该多有趣啊！”她继续说道，带着一种聪明女人在坚称她唯一的愿望就是奉献自己时所表现出的一种自鸣得意的神情。不用担心弄脏她的手指，去做一些不干净的工作，比如做饭，她“双手放在盘子里。”“你只会嘲笑我，但这个画家阻止你看到我，”她指的是维米尔，“我什至从未听说过他；”他还活着吗？我能在巴黎看到他的任何东西吗？以便了解一下他辛勤工作的大额头背后发生的事情，我确信他的头脑总是在思考问题；只是能够说“好了，这就是他正在想的！”能够帮助您完成工作将是多么梦想啊。

He had sought an excuse in his fear of forming new friendships, which he gallantly described as his fear of a hopeless passion. ‘You are afraid of falling in love? How funny that is, when I go about seeking nothing else, and would give my soul just to find a little love somewhere!’ she had said, so naturally and with such an air of conviction that he had been genuinely touched. ‘Some woman must have made you suffer. And you think that the rest are all like her. She can’t have understood you: you are so utterly different from ordinary men. That’s what I liked about you when I first saw you; I felt at once that you weren’t like everybody else.’
他为自己害怕建立新的友谊而寻找借口，他勇敢地将其描述为他对绝望的激情的恐惧。 ‘你害怕坠入爱河吗？这是多么有趣啊，当我四处寻找别的东西，愿意付出我的灵魂，只是为了在某个地方找到一点爱！”她说道，语气如此自然，语气如此坚定，以至于他真的被感动了。 “肯定是某个女人让你受苦了。而你以为其他人都像她一样。她不可能理解你：你和普通男人截然不同。这就是我第一次见到你时就喜欢你的地方；我立刻就觉得你和其他人不一样。

‘And then, besides, there’s yourself——‘ he had continued, ‘I know what women are; you must have a whole heap of things to do, and never any time to spare.’
“此外，还有你自己——”他继续说道，“我知道女人是什么；我知道女人是什么。”你必须有一大堆事情要做，而且没有空闲时间。”

‘I? Why, I have never anything to do. I am always free, and I always will be free if you want me. At whatever hour of the day or night it may suit you to see me, just send for me, and I shall be only too delighted to come. Will you do that? Do you know what I should really like—to introduce you to Mme. Verdurin, where I go every evening. Just fancy my finding you there, and thinking that it was a little for my sake that you had gone.’
'我？为什么，我从来没有什么事可做。我永远是自由的，如果你需要我，我将永远自由。无论白天还是晚上，无论您什么时候想见我，只要派人来找我，我都会很高兴来的。你会这么做吗？你知道我真正喜欢什么吗——把你介绍给夫人。维尔迪兰，我每天晚上都去的地方。想象一下我在那里找到了你，并认为你离开是为了我。

No doubt, in thus remembering their conversations, in thinking about her thus when he was alone, he did no more than call her image into being among those of countless other women in his romantic dreams; but if, thanks to some accidental circumstance (or even perhaps without that assistance, for the circumstance which presents itself at the moment when a mental state, hitherto latent, makes itself felt, may well have had no influence whatsoever upon that state), the image of Odette de Crécy came to absorb the whole of his dreams, if from those dreams the memory of her could no longer be eliminated, then her bodily imperfections would no longer be of the least importance, nor would the conformity of her body, more or less than any other, to the requirements of Swann’s taste; since, having become the body of her whom he loved, it must henceforth be the only one capable of causing him joy or anguish.
毫无疑问，当他独自一人时，他如此回忆起他们的谈话，如此想着她，只不过是在他浪漫的梦中将她的形象融入到无数其他女人的形象中；但是，如果由于某种偶然的情况（或者甚至可能没有这种帮助，因为当一种迄今为止潜在的心理状态被感觉到时，出现的情况很可能对该状态没有任何影响），奥黛特·德·克雷西的形象逐渐吸收了他的全部梦境，如果梦中对她的记忆无法再被消除，那么她身体的缺陷就不再是最不重要的了，她身体的一致性也不再是最重要的了。或低于任何其他，以满足斯旺的品味要求；因为，既然已经成为了他所爱的她的身体，那么从今以后，它必定是唯一能够给他带来快乐或痛苦的身体了。

It so happened that my grandfather had known—which was more than could be said of any other actual acquaintance—the family of these Ver-durins. But he had entirely severed his connection with what he called ‘young Verdurin,’ taking a general view of him as one who had fallen—though without losing hold of his millions—among the riff-raff of Bohemia. One day he received a letter from Swann asking whether my grandfather could put him in touch with the Verdurins. ‘On guard! on guard!’ he exclaimed as he read it, ‘I am not at all surprised; Swann was bound to finish up like this. A nice lot of people! I cannot do what he asks, because, in the first place, I no longer know the gentleman in question. Besides, there must be a woman in it somewhere, and I don’t mix myself up in such matters. Ah, well, we shall see some fun if Swann begins running after the little Verdurins.’
碰巧我的祖父认识——这比任何其他真正的熟人都多——这些维尔迪兰家族的人。但他完全断绝了与他所谓的“年轻维尔迪兰”的联系，普遍认为他是一个堕落到波西米亚的流氓之中的人，尽管他并没有失去数百万美元。有一天，他收到斯旺的一封信，询问我的祖父是否可以让他与维尔迪兰家族取得联系。 '处于戒备！警惕！”他读到这封信时大声说道，“我一点也不感到惊讶；斯旺注定会以这样的结局收场。很多人都很好！我不能按照他的要求去做，因为首先，我不再认识这位先生了。再说了，这里面一定有女人，我不会卷入这种事的。啊，好吧，如果斯旺开始追赶小维尔迪兰，我们会看到一些有趣的事情。

And on my grandfather’s refusal to act as sponsor, it was Odette herself who had taken Swann to the house.
当我祖父拒绝充当担保人时，奥黛特亲自带斯万去了家里。

The Verdurins had had dining with them, on the day when Swann made his first appearance, Dr. and Mme. Cottard, the young pianist and his aunt, and the painter then in favour, while these were joined, in the course of the evening, by several more of the ‘faithful.’
斯万第一次露面的那天，维尔迪兰夫妇与他们一起吃饭。科塔尔、年轻的钢琴家和他的姨妈以及当时的画家都表示支持，而当晚，又有几位“忠实信徒”加入了他们的行列。

Dr. Cottard was never quite certain of the tone in which he ought to reply to any observation, or whether the speaker was jesting or in earnest. And so in any event he would embellish all his facial expressions with the offer of a conditional, a provisional smile whose expectant subtlety would exonerate him from the charge of being a simpleton, if the remark addressed to him should turn out to have been facetious. But as he must also be prepared to face the alternative, he never dared to allow this smile a definite expression on his features, and you would see there a perpetually flickering uncertainty, in which you might decipher the question that he never dared to ask: ‘Do you really mean that?’ He was no more confident of the manner in which he ought to conduct himself in the street, or indeed in life generally, than he was in a drawing-room; and he might be seen greeting passers-by, carriages, and anything that occurred with a malicious smile which absolved his subsequent behaviour of all impropriety, since it proved, if it should turn out unsuited to the occasion, that he was well aware of that, and that if he had assumed a smile, the jest was a secret of his own.
科塔德博士从来不太确定他应该用什么语气来回答任何评论，或者说话者是在开玩笑还是认真的。因此，无论如何，他都会用一个有条件的、临时的微笑来修饰他所有的面部表情，如果对他说的话被证明是开玩笑的话，这个微笑的期待微妙将使他免于被指控为傻瓜。但由于他也必须做好面对另一种选择的准备，所以他从来不敢让这种微笑在他的脸上有明确的表情，你会看到那里永远闪烁着不确定性，你可以在其中解读出他从来不敢问的问题： “你真的是这个意思吗？”他对自己在街上或生活中应该采取的行为方式并不比在客厅里更有信心。人们可能会看到他带着恶意的微笑向路人、马车和任何发生的事情打招呼，这免除了他随后的所有不当行为，因为这证明，如果结果不适合这个场合，他很清楚这一点，如果他假装微笑，那么这个笑话就是他自己的秘密。

On all those points, however, where a plain question appeared to him to be permissible, the Doctor was unsparing in his endeavours to cultivate the wilderness of his ignorance and uncertainty and so to complete his education.
然而，在所有这些问题上，只要博士认为可以提出一个简单的问题，他就会不遗余力地努力培养他的无知和不确定性，从而完成他的教育。

So it was that, following the advice given him by a wise mother on his first coming up to the capital from his provincial home, he would never let pass either a figure of speech or a proper name that was new to him without an effort to secure the fullest information upon it.
所以，在他第一次从乡下来到京城时，按照一位明智母亲的建议，他决不会轻易放过对他来说陌生的修辞手法或专有名词。确保其上有最完整的信息。

As regards figures of speech, he was insatiable in his thirst for knowledge, for often imagining them to have a more definite meaning than was actually the case, he would want to know what, exactly, was intended by those which he most frequently heard used: ‘devilish pretty,’ ‘blue blood,’ ‘a cat and dog life,’ ‘a day of reckoning,’ ‘a queen of fashion, ‘to give a free hand,’ ‘to be at a deadlock,’ and so forth; and in what particular circumstances he himself might make use of them in conversation. Failing these, he would adorn it with puns and other ‘plays upon words’ which he had learned by rote. As for the names of strangers which were uttered in his hearing, he used merely to repeat them to himself in a questioning tone, which, he thought, would suffice to furnish him with explanations for which he would not ostensibly seek.
至于修辞格，他对知识的渴求永无止境，因为他经常想象它们具有比实际情况更明确的含义，他想知道他最常听到的那些修辞格的确切含义是什么。 ：“恶魔般的漂亮”、“贵族血统”、“猫狗生活”、“清算日”、“时尚女王”、“放开手脚”、“陷入僵局”等等向前;以及在什么特定情况下他本人可能会在谈话中使用它们。如果做不到这些，他就会用双关语和其他他死记硬背的“文字游戏”来装饰它。至于在他耳边说出的陌生人的名字，他只是用询问的语气向自己重复一遍，他认为这足以为他提供表面上不会寻求的解释。

As the critical faculty, on the universal application of which he prided himself, was, in reality, completely lacking, that refinement of good breeding which consists in assuring some one whom you are obliging in any way, without expecting to be believed, that it is really yourself that is obliged to him, was wasted on Cottard, who took everything that he heard in its literal sense. However blind she may have been to his faults, Mme. Verdurin was genuinely annoyed, though she still continued to regard him as brilliantly clever, when, after she had invited him to see and hear Sarah Bernhardt from a stage box, and had said politely: ‘It is very good of you to have come, Doctor, especially as I’m sure you must often have heard Sarah Bernhardt; and besides, I’m afraid we’re rather too near the stage,’ the Doctor, who had come into the box with a smile which waited before settling upon or vanishing from his face until some one in authority should enlighten him as to the merits of the spectacle, replied: ‘To be sure, we are far too near the stage, and one is getting sick of Sarah Bernhardt. But you expressed a wish that I should come. For me, your wish is a command. I am only too glad to be able to do you this little service. What would one not do to please you, you are so good.’ And he went on, ‘Sarah Bernhardt; that’s what they call the Voice of God, ain’t it? You see, often, too, that she ‘sets the boards on fire.’ That’s an odd expression, ain’t it?’ in the hope of an enlightening commentary, which, however, was not forthcoming.
他引以为傲的批判能力实际上完全缺乏良好教养的精炼，这种能力在于向你以任何方式提供帮助的人保证，你不希望别人相信你的做法。事实上，你自己对他有恩惠，浪费在科塔尔身上，科塔尔把他听到的一切都按照字面意思理解。不管她对他的错误有多盲目，夫人。维尔迪兰确实很生气，尽管她仍然认为他非常聪明，当她邀请他在舞台包厢里看莎拉·伯恩哈特并听她讲话并礼貌地说：“你能来真是太好了，博士，尤其是我相信您一定经常听说过莎拉·伯恩哈特（Sarah Bernhardt）；此外，我担心我们离舞台太近了。”博士带着微笑走进了包厢，笑容一直在他脸上停留或消失，直到某个权威人士向他阐明这一点。 ” 回答道：“可以肯定的是，我们离舞台太近了，人们已经厌倦了莎拉·伯恩哈特。但你表达了我应该来的愿望。对我来说，你的愿望就是命令。我很高兴能为您提供这项小服务。 “你太棒了。”他接着说道，“莎拉·伯恩哈特；莎拉·伯恩哈特；这就是他们所说的上帝之声，不是吗？你也经常看到她“放火烧木板”。这是一个奇怪的表达方式，不是吗？”希望得到启发性的评论，然而，这一评论并没有出现。

‘D’you know,’ Mme. Verdurin had said to her husband, ‘I believe we are going the wrong way to work when we depreciate anything we offer the Doctor. He is a scientist who lives quite apart from our everyday existence; he knows nothing himself of what things are worth, and he accepts everything that we say as gospel.’
“你知道吗，”夫人。维尔迪兰对她的丈夫说：“我相信，当我们贬低我们为医生提供的任何东西时，我们就走上了错误的工作方式。”他是一位科学家，他的生活与我们的日常生活截然不同。他自己对事物的价值一无所知，他接受我们所说的一切作为福音。

‘I never dared to mention it,’ M. Verdurin had answered, ‘but I’ve noticed the same thing myself.’ And on the following New Year’s Day, instead of sending Dr. Cottard a ruby that cost three thousand francs, and pretending that it was a mere trifle, M. Verdurin bought an artificial stone for three hundred, and let it be understood that it was something almost impossible to match.
“我从来不敢提这件事，”维尔迪兰先生回答道，“但我自己也注意到了同样的事情。”在接下来的元旦，他没有给科塔尔医生寄去一颗价值三千法郎的红宝石，而是维尔迪兰先生假装这只是一件小事，花了三百块钱买了一块人造石，并让人们知道这是几乎不可能比拟的东西。

When Mme. Verdurin had announced that they were to see M. Swann that evening; ‘Swann!’ the Doctor had exclaimed in a tone rendered brutal by his astonishment, for the smallest piece of news would always take utterly unawares this man who imagined himself to be perpetually in readiness for anything. And seeing that no one answered him, ‘Swann! Who on earth is Swann?’ he shouted, in a frenzy of anxiety which subsided as soon as Mme. Verdurin had explained, ‘Why, Odette’s friend, whom she told us about.’
当女士。维尔迪兰宣布，他们要在那天晚上去见斯旺先生。 “斯旺！”博士惊呼道，他的语气因惊讶而变得残酷，因为即使是最小的消息也总是会让这个自以为随时准备应对任何事情的人完全措手不及。看到没有人回答他，“斯旺！” “斯旺到底是谁？”他惊慌失措地喊道，但随着夫人的到来，这种焦虑就平息了。维尔迪兰解释道：“哦，奥黛特的朋友，她向我们提起过。”

‘Ah, good, good; that’s all right, then,’ answered the Doctor, at once mollified. As for the painter, he was overjoyed at the prospect of Swann’s appearing at the Verdurins’, because he supposed him to be in love with Odette, and was always ready to assist at lovers’ meetings. ‘Nothing amuses me more than match-making,’ he confided to Cottard; ‘I have been tremendously successful, even with women!’
‘啊，好，好；那就没关系了，”博士立刻平静下来回答道。至于画家，他对斯旺出现在维尔迪兰家的前景感到欣喜若狂，因为他认为斯旺爱上了奥黛特，并且随时准备在情人聚会上提供协助。 “没有什么比牵线搭桥更让我开心的了，”他向科塔尔吐露道。 “我取得了巨大的成功，即使是在女性方面！”

In telling the Verdurins that Swann was extremely ‘smart,’ Odette had alarmed them with the prospect of another ‘bore.’ When he arrived, however, he made an excellent impression, an indirect cause of which, though they did not know it, was his familiarity with the best society. He had, indeed, one of those advantages which men who have lived and moved in the world enjoy over others, even men of intelligence and refinement, who have never gone into society, namely that they no longer see it transfigured by the longing or repulsion with which it fills the imagination, but regard it as quite unimportant. Their good nature, freed from all taint of snobbishness and from the fear of seeming too friendly, grown independent, in fact, has the ease, the grace of movemsnt of a trained gymnast each of whose supple limbs will carry out precisely the movement that is required without any clumsy participation by the rest of his body. The simple and elementary gestures used by a man of the world when he courteously holds out his hand to the unknown youth who is being introduced to him, and when he bows discreetly before the Ambassador to whom he is being introduced, had gradually pervaded, without his being conscious of it, the whole of Swann’s social deportment, so that in the company of people of a lower grade than his own, such as the Verdurins and their friends, he instinctively shewed an assiduity, and made overtures with which, by their account, any of their ‘bores’ would have dispensed. He chilled, though for a moment only, on meeting Dr. Cottard; for seeing him close one eye with an ambiguous smile, before they had yet spoken to one another (a grimace which Cottard styled ‘letting ‘em all come’), Swann supposed that the Doctor recognised him from having met him already somewhere, probably in some house of ‘ill-fame,’ though these he himself very rarely visited, never having made a habit of indulging in the mercenary sort of love. Regarding such an allusion as in bad taste, especially before Odette, whose opinion of himself it might easily alter for the worse, Swann assumed his most icy manner. But when he learned that the lady next to the Doctor was Mme. Cottard, he decided that so young a husband would not deliberately, in his wife’s hearing, have made any allusion to amusements of that order, and so ceased to interpret the Doctor’s expression in the sense which he had at first suspected. The painter at once invited Swann to visit his studio with Odette, and Swann found him very pleasant. ‘Perhaps you will be more highly favoured than I have been,’ Mme. Verdurin broke in, with mock resentment of the favour, ‘perhaps you will be allowed to see Cottard’s portrait’ (for which she had given the painter a commission). ‘Take care, Master Biche,’ she reminded the painter, whom it was a time-honoured pleasantry to address as ‘Master,’ ‘to catch that nice look in his eyes, that witty little twinkle. You know, what I want to have most of all is his smile; that’s what I’ve asked you to paint—the portrait of his smile.’ And since the phrase struck her as noteworthy, she repeated it very loud, so as to make sure that as many as possible of her guests should hear it, and even made use of some indefinite pretext to draw the circle closer before she uttered it again. Swann begged to be introduced to everyone, even to an old friend of the Verdurins, called Saniette, whose shyness, simplicity and good-nature had deprived him of all the consideration due to his skill in palaeography, his large fortune, and the distinguished family to which he belonged. When he spoke, his words came with a confusion which was delightful to hear because one felt that it indicated not so much a defect in his speech as a quality of his soul, as it were a survival from the age of innocence which he had never wholly outgrown. All the cop-sonants which he did not manage to pronounce seemed like harsh utterances of which his gentle lips were incapable. By asking to be made known to M. Saniette, Swann made M. Verdurin reverse the usual form of introduction (saying, in fact, with emphasis on the distinction: ‘M. Swann, pray let me present to you our friend Saniette’) but he aroused in Saniette himself a warmth of gratitude, which, however, the Verdurins never disclosed to Swann, since Saniette rather annoyed them, and they did not feel bound to provide him with friends. On the other hand the Verdurins were extremely touched by Swann’s next request, for he felt that he must ask to be introduced to the pianist’s aunt. She wore a black dress, as was her invariable custom, for she believed that a woman always looked well in black, and that nothing could be more distinguished; but her face was exceedingly red, as it always was for some time after a meal. She bowed to Swann with deference, but drew herself up again with great dignity. As she was entirely uneducated, and was afraid of making mistakes in grammar and pronunciation, she used purposely to speak in an indistinct and garbling manner, thinking that if she should make a slip it would be so buried in the surrounding confusion that no one could be certain whether she had actually made it or not; with the result that her talk was a sort of continuous, blurred expectoration, out of which would emerge, at rare intervals, those sounds and syllables of which she felt positive. Swann supposed himself entitled to poke a little mild fun at her in conversation with M. Verdurin, who, however, was not at all amused.
奥黛特告诉韦尔迪兰一家，斯万极其“聪明”，这让他们担心另一个“讨厌鬼”的前景。然而，当他到达时，他给人留下了极好的印象，这是一个间接原因，尽管他们不知道这一点，是他对上流社会的熟悉程度。事实上，他拥有那些在这个世界上生活和活动过的人比其他人，甚至是那些从未进入社会的聪明而有教养的人所享有的优势之一，即他们不再看到社会因渴望或排斥而变形。它充满了想象力，但又认为它并不重要。他们善良的天性，没有势利的污点，也没有对显得过于友好的恐惧，变得独立，事实上，拥有训练有素的体操运动员的轻松、优雅的动作，他们的每一个柔软的四肢都会精确地执行所要求的动作。他身体的其他部分不需要任何笨拙的参与。当一个国际人士礼貌地向被介绍给他的陌生青年伸出手时，当他在被介绍给他的大使面前小心地鞠躬时，他所使用的简单而基本的手势已经逐渐普及，而无需担心。他意识到了斯万的整个社会举止，因此，在与比他等级低的人在一起时，例如维尔迪兰夫妇和他们的朋友，他本能地表现出殷勤，并提出了主动表示，通过他们的帐户，他们的任何“无聊”都会被分配。见到博士后，他浑身发冷，尽管只有片刻。 科塔尔；在他们互相交谈之前，看到他闭上一只眼睛，带着一种模棱两可的微笑（科塔尔称之为“让他们都来”的鬼脸），斯旺认为博士认出了他，因为他已经在某个地方见过他了。一些“名声不佳”的房子，尽管他本人很少去这些地方，从来没有养成沉迷于唯利是图的爱情的习惯。斯万认为这样的暗示是低俗的，尤其是在奥黛特面前，因为这很容易使奥黛特对自己的看法变得更糟，斯万表现出他最冷漠的态度。但当他得知医生旁边的那位女士是夫人时。科塔尔先生，​​他认为如此年轻的丈夫不会故意在妻子的耳中提及此类娱乐，因此不再按照他最初怀疑的方式解释医生的表情。画家立即邀请斯万和奥黛特一起参观他的工作室，斯万觉得他很愉快。 “也许你会比我受到更多的青睐，”夫人。维尔迪兰打断道，假装对这种恩惠表示不满，“也许你会被允许看看科塔尔的肖像”（为此她给了这位画家委托）。 “保重，比什大师，”她提醒这位画家，“捕捉他眼中美丽的神情和诙谐的小光芒。”称呼他为“大师”是一种由来已久的乐趣。你知道，我最想要的就是他的笑容；这就是我要你画的——他的微笑肖像。”由于这句话让她觉得值得注意，她大声地重复了一遍，以确保尽可能多的客人听到它，然后甚至还用了一些不确定的借口，将圈子拉近了一些，才再次开口。 斯万恳求把他介绍给每个人，甚至是维尔迪兰家族的一位老朋友，名叫萨尼埃特，由于他的古文字学技巧、巨额财富和显赫的家族，他的害羞、单纯和善良使他失去了所有的关注。他属于其中。当他说话时，他的话语带着一种令人愉悦的困惑，因为人们觉得这与其说表明了他讲话中的缺陷，不如说表明了他灵魂的品质，因为这是他从未经历过的纯真时代的残余。完全超出了。所有他无法发音的辅音似乎都像是他温柔的嘴唇无法发出的刺耳话语。通过要求让萨尼埃特先生认识，斯旺让维尔迪兰先生扭转了通常的介绍形式（事实上，强调了区别：“斯旺先生，请让我向您介绍我们的朋友萨尼埃特”）但他在萨尼埃特身上激起了一种温暖的感激之情，然而，维尔迪兰夫妇从未向斯万透露过，因为萨尼埃特相当惹恼他们，而他们也没有义务为他提供朋友。另一方面，维尔迪兰夫妇对斯万的下一个请求非常感动，因为他觉得他必须要求被介绍给钢琴家的姨妈。她穿着黑色连衣裙，这是她一贯的习惯，因为她相信女人穿黑色总是很好看，没有什么比这更显眼的了。但她的脸却非常红，饭后有一段时间她总是这样。她恭敬地向斯旺鞠了一躬，但又非常庄严地挺直身子。 由于她完全没有受过教育，又怕在语法和发音上犯错误，所以她说话时故意含糊不清、乱码，以为自己说错了就会被埋在周围的混乱之中，没人能听懂。确定她是否真的成功了；结果，她的谈话就像是一种连续的、模糊的咳痰，偶尔会出现一些她感到积极的声音和音节。斯万认为自己有权在与维尔迪兰先生交谈时对她开一点温和的玩笑，然而维尔迪兰先生却一点也不觉得好笑。

‘She is such an excellent woman!’ he rejoined. ‘I grant you that she is not exactly brilliant; but I assure you that she can talk most charmingly when you are alone with her.’
“她是一位非常优秀的女人！”他回答道。 “我承认她并不十分聪明；但她确实很聪明。”但我向你保证，当你单独和她在一起时，她会说得最迷人。”

‘I am sure she can,’ Swann hastened to conciliate him. ‘All I meant was that she hardly struck me as ‘distinguished,’’ he went on, isolating the epithet in the inverted commas of his tone, ‘and, after all, that is something of a compliment.’
“我相信她可以，”斯万赶紧安抚他。 “我的意思是，她几乎没有给我留下‘杰出’的印象，”他继续说道，用他的语气用引号分隔出这个绰号，“毕竟，这是一种恭维。”

‘Wait a moment,’ said M. Verdurin, ‘now, this will surprise you; she writes quite delightfully. You have never heard her nephew play? It is admirable; eh, Doctor? Would you like me to ask him to play something, M. Swann?’
“等一下，”维尔迪兰先生说，“现在，这会让你大吃一惊的；”她写得非常愉快。你从来没有听过她侄子演奏吗？这是令人钦佩的；呃，医生？斯旺先生，你想让我请他演奏一些东西吗？

‘I should count myself most fortunate...’ Swann was beginning, a trifle pompously, when the Doctor broke in derisively. Having once heard it said, and never having forgotten that in general conversation emphasis and the use of formal expressions were out of date, whenever he heard a solemn word used seriously, as the word ‘fortunate’ had been used just now by Swann, he at once assumed that the speaker was being deliberately pedantic. And if, moreover, the same word happened to occur, also, in what he called an old ‘tag’ or ‘saw,’ however common it might still be in current usage, the Doctor jumped to the conclusion that the whole thing was a joke, and interrupted with the remaining words of the quotation, which he seemed to charge the speaker with having intended to introduce at that point, although in reality it had never entered his mind.
“我应该认为自己是最幸运的……”斯万正要开口，有点傲慢，这时博士嘲笑地插话道。他曾经听过这句话，并且永远不会忘记，在一般谈话中强调和使用正式的表达方式已经过时了，每当他听到一个严肃的词被严肃地使用时，就像斯万刚才使用的“幸运”这个词一样，他我立刻就认为说话者是故意迂腐的。此外，如果同一个词也碰巧出现在他所谓的旧“标签”或“锯子”中，无论它在当前的用法中多么常见，博士都会立即得出结论，整个事情是一个他开玩笑地打断了引文的其余部分，他似乎责怪说话者本来打算在这一点上介绍这句话，尽管实际上他从未想到过这一点。

‘Most fortunate for France!’ he recited wickedly, shooting up both arms with great vigour. M. Verdurin could not help laughing.
“法国最幸运！”他邪恶地背诵着，同时用力地举起双臂。维尔迪兰先生忍不住笑了。

‘What are all those good people laughing at over there? There’s no sign of brooding melancholy down in your corner,’ shouted Mme. Verdurin. ‘You don’t suppose I find it very amusing to be stuck up here by myself on the stool of repentance,’ she went on peevishly, like a spoiled child.
‘那边那些好人在笑什么呢？你的角落里没有任何忧郁的迹象。”夫人喊道。韦尔迪兰。 “你以为我一个人被困在悔改的凳子上不会觉得很有趣吗？”她像个被宠坏的孩子一样，脾气暴躁地继续说道。

Mme. Verdurin was sitting upon a high Swedish chair of waxed pine-wood, which a violinist from that country had given her, and which she kept in her drawing-room, although in appearance it suggested a school ‘form,’ and ‘swore,’ as the saying is, at the really good antique furniture which she had besides; but she made a point of keeping on view the presents which her ‘faithful’ were in the habit of making her from time to time, so that the donors might have the pleasure of seeing them there when they came to the house. She tried to persuade them to confine their tributes to flowers and sweets, which had at least the merit of mortality; but she was never successful, and the house was gradually filled with a collection of foot-warmers, cushions, clocks, screens, barometers and vases, a constant repetition and a boundless incongruity of useless but indestructible objects.
女士。维尔迪兰坐在一张瑞典打蜡松木高椅上，这是一位瑞典小提琴家送给她的，她把它放在客厅里，尽管从外观上看，它暗示着一种学校的“形式”，并且“发誓”，俗话说，看她拥有的真正好的古董家具；但她特意保存了她的“忠实信徒”不时为她准备的礼物，以便捐赠者来到家里时可以很高兴看到这些礼物。她试图说服他们只献上鲜花和糖果，因为它们至少具有死亡的价值。但她从未成功，房子里逐渐堆满了暖脚器、垫子、时钟、屏风、气压计和花瓶，这些无用但坚不可摧的物品不断重复和无限不协调。

>From this lofty perch she would take her spirited part in the conversation of the ‘faithful,’ and would revel in all their fun; but, since the accident to her jaw, she had abandoned the effort involved in real hilarity, and had substituted a kind of symbolical dumb-show which signified, without endangering or even fatiguing her in any way, that she was ‘laughing until she cried.’ At the least witticism aimed by any of the circle against a ‘bore,’ or against a former member of the circle who was now relegated to the limbo of ‘bores’—and to the utter despair of M. Verdurin, who had always made out that he was just as easily amused as his wife, but who, since his laughter was the ‘real thing,’ was out of breath in a moment, and so was overtaken and vanquished by her device of a feigned but continuous hilarity—she would utter a shrill cry, shut tight her little bird-like eyes, which were beginning to be clouded over by a cataract, and quickly, as though she had only just time to avoid some indecent sight or to parry a mortal blow, burying her face in her hands, which completely engulfed it, and prevented her from seeing anything at all, she would appear to be struggling to suppress, to eradicate a laugh which, were she to give way to it, must inevitably leave her inanimate. So, stupefied with the gaiety of the ‘faithful,’ drunken with comradeship, scandal and asseveration, Mme. Verdurin, perched on her high seat like a cage-bird whose biscuit has been steeped in mulled wine, would sit aloft and sob with fellow-feeling.
>站在这个崇高的地位上，她会热情地参与“信徒”的谈话，并陶醉在他们所有的乐趣中；但是，自从下巴受伤后，她放弃了真正的欢闹，取而代之的是一种象征性的哑剧，这种哑剧表明她“笑到哭为止”，但不会以任何方式危及甚至使她疲劳。至少，这个圈子里的任何一个人都会针对一个“无聊”的人，或者一个现在被降级到“无聊”边缘的圈子里的前成员，进行一些俏皮话——这让维尔迪兰先生彻底绝望了，他总是表现出他和他妻子一样容易被逗乐，但由于他的笑声是“真实的”，他的妻子立刻就气喘吁吁，因此被她假装但持续的欢闹所超越和征服。 ——她会发出一声尖锐的叫声，紧紧闭上那双小鸟般的眼睛，那双眼睛已经开始被白内障遮住了，然后很快地，仿佛她只有时间来避免一些不雅的景象或招架致命的一击，她把脸埋在双手中，双手完全吞没了脸，根本看不到任何东西，她似乎在努力抑制、消除笑声，如果她屈服于笑声，她必然会变得毫无生气。因此，夫人对“忠实者”的欢乐感到震惊，沉迷于同志情谊、丑闻和主张。维尔迪兰坐在高高的座位上，就像一只笼中鸟，饼干浸在热红酒里，她会坐在高处哭泣，同情心。

Meanwhile M. Verdurin, after first asking Swann’s permission to light his pipe (“No ceremony here, you understand; we’re all pals!’), went and begged the young musician to sit down at the piano.
与此同时，维尔迪兰先生首先请求斯旺允许点燃他的烟斗（“这里没有仪式，你明白；我们都是朋友！”），然后请求这位年轻的音乐家在钢琴前坐下。

‘Leave him alone; don’t bother him; he hasn’t come here to be tormented,’ cried Mme. Verdurin. ‘I won’t have him tormented.’
'留下他一个人;不要打扰他；他来这里不是为了受折磨的，”夫人喊道。韦尔迪兰。 “我不会让他受到折磨。”

‘But why on earth should it bother him?’ rejoined M. Verdurin. ‘I’m sure M. Swann has never heard the sonata in F sharp which we discovered; he is going to play us the pianoforte arrangement.’
“但是这到底为什么要让他烦恼呢？”维尔迪兰先生反问道。 “我确信斯旺先生从未听过我们发现的升F奏鸣曲；他将为我们演奏钢琴改编曲。

‘No, no, no, not my sonata!’ she screamed, ‘I don’t want to be made to cry until I get a cold in the head, and neuralgia all down my face, like last time; thanks very much, I don’t intend to repeat that performance; you are all very kind and considerate; it is easy to see that none of you will have to stay in bed, for a week.’
“不，不，不，这不是我的奏鸣曲！”她尖叫道，“我不想像上次一样，一直哭到头感冒，脸上神经痛；非常感谢，我不打算重复那个表演；你们都非常善良、体贴；很容易看出，你们中的任何一个人都不需要在床上呆一个星期。

This little scene, which was re-enacted as often as the young pianist sat down to play, never failed to delight the audience, as though each of them were witnessing it for the first time, as a proof of the seductive originality of the ‘Mistress’ as she was styled, and of the acute sensitiveness of her musical ‘ear.’ Those nearest to her would attract the attention of the rest, who were smoking or playing cards at the other end of the room, by their cries of ‘Hear, hear!’ which, as in Parliamentary debates, shewed that something worth listening to was being said. And next day they would commiserate with those who had been prevented from coming that evening, and would assure them that the ‘little scene’ had never been so amusingly done.
这个小场景，每当这位年轻的钢琴家坐下来演奏时，都会被重演，总是让观众感到高兴，就好像他们每个人都是第一次目睹它一样，作为“她被称为“情妇”，以及她对音乐“耳朵”的敏锐敏感性。离她最近的人会通过喊叫“”来吸引其他人的注意，他们在房间的另一端抽烟或打牌。听听，听听！”就像在议会辩论中一样，这表明正在说一些值得听的事情。第二天，他们会对那些当晚被阻止来的人表示同情，并向他们保证这个“小场景”从来没有做得这么有趣。

‘Well, all right, then,’ said M. Verdurin, ‘he can play just the andante.’
“好吧，那么，”维尔迪兰先生说，“他只会演奏行板。”

‘Just the andante! How you do go on,’ cried his wife. ‘As if it weren’t ‘just the andante’ that breaks every bone in my body. The ‘Master’ is really too priceless! Just as though, ‘in the Ninth,’ he said ‘we need only have the finale,’ or ‘just the overture’ of the Meistersinger.’
‘只有行板！你怎么继续下去，”他的妻子喊道。 “好像不只是‘行板’折断了我身体里的每一根骨头。” ‘师尊’实在是太无价了！就好像，“在第九交响曲中，”他说，“我们只需要结局”，或者“只是名歌手的序曲”。

The Doctor, however, urged Mme. Verdurin to let the pianist play, not because he supposed her to be malingering when she spoke of the distressing effects that music always had upon her, for he recognised the existence of certain neurasthenic states—but from his habit, common to many doctors, of at once relaxing the strict letter of a prescription as soon as it appeared to jeopardise, what seemed to him far more important, the success of some social gathering at which he was present, and of which the patient whom he had urged for once to forget her dyspepsia or headache formed an essential factor.
然而，医生敦促女士。维尔迪兰让钢琴家演奏，并不是因为当她谈到音乐总是对她产生的痛苦影响时，他认为她在装病，因为他认识到某些神经衰弱状态的存在——而是因为他的习惯，这是许多医生的共同习惯，一旦它似乎危及对他来说更重要的事情，他就立即放松了严格的处方信，他参加了一些社交聚会的成功，而他曾经敦促病人忘记这一点她的消化不良或头痛是一个重要因素。

‘You won’t be ill this time, you’ll find,’ he told her, seeking at the same time to subdue her mind by the magnetism of his gaze. ‘And, if you are ill, we will cure you.’
“你会发现，这次你不会生病了，”他告诉她，同时试图用他目光的磁性来征服她的思想。 “而且，如果你病了，我们会治愈你。”

‘Will you, really?’ Mme. Verdurin spoke as though, with so great a favour in store for her, there was nothing for it but to capitulate. Perhaps, too, by dint of saying that she was going to be ill, she had worked herself into a state in which she forgot, occasionally, that it was all only a ‘little scene,’ and regarded things, quite sincerely, from an invalid’s point of view. For it may often be remarked that invalids grow weary of having the frequency of their attacks depend always on their own prudence in avoiding them, and like to let themselves think that they are free to do everything that they most enjoy doing, although they are always ill after doing it, provided only that they place themselves in the hands of a higher authority which, without putting them to the least inconvenience, can and will, by uttering a word or by administering a tabloid, set them once again upon their feet.
“你真的愿意吗？”维尔迪兰说话的语气就好像她受到了如此大的恩惠，除了投降之外别无他法。或许，由于说自己要生病了，她也让自己陷入了一种状态，有时她会忘记这一切都只是一个“小场景”，并非常真诚地从一个角度看待事情。无效的观点。因为人们常常会说，病人厌倦了他们的攻击频率总是取决于他们自己避免攻击的谨慎性，并且喜欢让自己认为他们可以自由地做他们最喜欢做的一切，尽管他们总是这样做之后，只要他们把自己交给一个更高的权威，这个权威在不给他们带来任何不便的情况下，可以而且愿意，通过说一句话或发布一份小报，让他们重新站起来。

Odette had gone to sit on a tapestry-covered sofa near the piano, saying to Mme. Verdurin, ‘I have my own little corner, haven’t I?’
奥黛特走到钢琴旁一张铺着挂毯的沙发上坐下，对夫人说道。维尔迪兰：“我有自己的小角落，不是吗？”

And Mme. Verdurin, seeing Swann by himself upon a chair, made him get up. ‘You’re not at all comfortable there; go along and sit by Odette; you can make room for M. Swann there, can’t you, Odette?’
还有女士。维尔迪兰看到斯万独自坐在椅子上，便让他站起来。 ‘你在那里一点也不舒服；走过去，坐在奥黛特身边；你可以在那里给斯万先生腾出地方，不是吗，奥黛特？

‘What charming Beauvais!’ said Swann, stopping to admire the sofa before he sat down on it, and wishing to be polite.
“多么迷人的博韦啊！”斯万说道，在坐下之前停下来欣赏沙发，并希望保持礼貌。

‘I am glad you appreciate my sofa,’ replied Mme. Verdurin, ‘and I warn you that if you expect ever to see another like it you may as well abandon the idea at once. They never made any more like it. And these little chairs, too, are perfect marvels. You can look at them in a moment. The emblems in each of the bronze mouldings correspond to the subject of the tapestry on the chair; you know, you combine amusement with instruction when you look at them;—I can promise you a delightful time, I assure you. Just look at the little border around the edges; here, look, the little vine on a red background in this one, the Bear and the Grapes. Isn’t it well drawn? What do you say? I think they knew a thing or two about design! Doesn’t it make your mouth water, this vine? My husband makes out that I am not fond of fruit, because I eat less than he does. But not a bit of it, I am greedier than any of you, but I have no need to fill my mouth with them when I can feed on them with my eyes. What are you all laughing at now, pray? Ask the Doctor; he will tell you that those grapes act on me like a regular purge. Some people go to Fontainebleau for cures; I take my own little Beauvais cure here. But, M. Swann, you mustn’t run away without feeling the little bronze mouldings on the backs. Isn’t it an exquisite surface? No, no, not with your whole hand like that; feel them property!’
“我很高兴你喜欢我的沙发，”夫人回答道。维尔迪兰，“我警告你，如果你希望看到另一个类似的东西，你最好立即放弃这个想法。他们再也没有做过类似的事情。这些小椅子也是完美的奇迹。您稍后可以查看它们。每个青铜饰条上的标志都与椅子上挂毯的主题相对应；你知道，当你看着它们时，你将娱乐与指导结合在一起；——我向你保证，我可以保证你度过一段愉快的时光。只要看看边缘周围的小边框即可；在这里，看，红色背景上的小藤蔓，熊和葡萄。是不是画得很好呢？你怎么说？我认为他们对设计略知一二！这棵藤蔓，是不是让你流口水了？我丈夫认为我不喜欢吃水果，因为我吃的比他少。但不是一点点，我比你们谁都贪婪，但是当我能用眼睛吃它们的时候，我就不需要把它们塞满嘴了。请问你们现在在笑什么？询问医生；他会告诉你那些葡萄对我的作用就像定期的净化一样。有些人去枫丹白露求医；有些人去枫丹白露求医；我在这里服用我自己的博韦小药方。但是，斯旺先生，在没有摸到背面的小青铜饰条之前，你一定不能逃跑。是不是很精致的表面呢？不，不，不能那样用你的整只手；感受它们的财产！

‘If Mme. Verdurin is going to start playing about with her bronzes,’ said the painter, ‘we shan’t get any music to-night.’
“如果女士。维尔迪兰要开始摆弄她的青铜器了，”画家说，“今晚我们不会听到任何音乐。”

‘Be quiet, you wretch! And yet we poor women,’ she went on, ‘are forbidden pleasures far less voluptuous than this. There is no flesh in the world as soft as these. None. When M. Verdurin did me the honour of being madly jealous... come, you might at least be polite. Don’t say that you never have been jealous!’
‘安静点，你这个坏蛋！然而我们这些可怜的女人，”她继续说道，“却是被禁止的快乐，远没有这般令人享受。世界上没有比这些更柔软的肉了。没有任何。当维尔迪兰先生让我有幸感到疯狂嫉妒时……来吧，你至少应该有礼貌。别说你从来没有嫉妒过！

‘But, my dear, I have said absolutely nothing. Look here, Doctor, I call you as a witness; did I utter a word?’
“但是，亲爱的，我什么也没说。听着，医生，我请你作证人；我有说过一句话吗？

Swann had begun, out of politeness, to finger the bronzes, and did not like to stop.
出于礼貌，斯旺开始用手指抚摸那些青铜器，并且不愿意停下来。

‘Come along; you can caress them later; now it is you that are going to be caressed, caressed in the ear; you’ll like that, I think. Here’s the young gentleman who will take charge of that.’
'一起来;你可以稍后再抚摸它们；现在要被爱抚的是你，在耳边被爱抚；我想你会喜欢的。这位年轻的绅士将负责此事。

After the pianist had played, Swann felt and shewed more interest in him than in any of the other guests, for the following reason:
钢琴家演奏后，斯旺对他比对其他客人更感兴趣，原因如下：

The year before, at an evening party, he had heard a piece of music played on the piano and violin. At first he had appreciated only the material quality of the sounds which those instruments secreted. And it had been a source of keen pleasure when, below the narrow ribbon of the violin-part, delicate, unyielding, substantial and governing the whole, he had suddenly perceived, where it was trying to surge upwards in a flowing tide of sound, the mass of the piano-part, multiform, coherent, level, and breaking everywhere in melody like the deep blue tumult of the sea, silvered and charmed into a minor key by the moonlight. But at a given moment, without being able to distinguish any clear outline, or to give a name to what was pleasing him, suddenly enraptured, he had tried to collect, to treasure in his memory the phrase or harmony—he knew not which—that had just been played, and had opened and expanded his soul, just as the fragrance of certain roses, wafted upon the moist air of evening, has the power of dilating our nostrils. Perhaps it was owing to his own ignorance of music that he had been able to receive so confused an impression, one of those that are, notwithstanding, our only purely musical impressions, limited in their extent, entirely original, and irreducible into any other kind. An impression of this order, vanishing in an instant, is, so to speak, an impression sine materia. Presumably the notes which we hear at such moments tend to spread out before our eyes, over surfaces greater or smaller according to their pitch and volume; to trace arabesque designs, to give us the sensation of breath or tenuity, stability or caprice. But the notes themselves have vanished before these sensations have developed sufficiently to escape submersion under those which the following, or even simultaneous notes have already begun to awaken in us. And this indefinite perception would continue to smother in its molten liquidity the motifs which now and then emerge, barely discernible, to plunge again and disappear and drown; recognised only by the particular kind of pleasure which they instil, impossible to describe, to recollect, to name; ineffable;—if our memory, like a labourer who toils at the laying down of firm foundations beneath the tumult of the waves, did not, by fashioning for us facsimiles of those fugitive phrases, enable us to compare and to contrast them with those that follow. And so, hardly had the delicious sensation, which Swann had experienced, died away, before his memory had furnished him with an immediate transcript, summary, it is true, and provisional, but one on which he had kept his eyes fixed while the playing continued, so effectively that, when the same impression suddenly returned, it was no longer uncapturable. He was able to picture to himself its extent, its symmetrical arrangement, its notation, the strength of its expression; he had before him that definite object which was no longer pure music, but rather design, architecture, thought, and which allowed the actual music to be recalled. This time he had distinguished, quite clearly, a phrase which emerged for a few moments from the waves of sound. It had at once held out to him an invitation to partake of intimate pleasures, of whose existence, before hearing it, he had never dreamed, into which he felt that nothing but this phrase could initiate him; and he had been filled with love for it, as with a new and strange desire.
前一年，在一次晚会上，他听到一首钢琴和小提琴演奏的音乐。起初，他只欣赏这些乐器发出的声音的物质品质。当他突然察觉到，在小提琴部件的狭窄丝带之下，精致、不屈、坚固、支配着整个乐器，它试图在流动的声音浪潮中向上涌动时，这是一种强烈的快乐的源泉，钢琴声部的整体，形式多样，连贯，水平，旋律中到处都是断裂的，就像深蓝色的大海的骚动，在月光的照射下变成了银色的小调。但在某个特定的时刻，由于无法辨别出任何清晰的轮廓，也无法给令他高兴的东西命名，他突然欣喜若狂，试图收集、珍藏在记忆中的短语或和谐——他不知道是哪一个——刚刚演奏的那首曲子，打开了他的灵魂，扩展了他的灵魂，就像某些玫瑰的香味，在夜晚潮湿的空气中飘荡，具有扩张我们鼻孔的力量。也许正是由于他自己对音乐的无知，他才能够收到如此混乱的印象，尽管如此，其中之一是我们唯一的纯粹音乐印象，其范围有限，完全原创，并且不能还原为任何其他类型。 。这种秩序的印象，在瞬间消失，可以说是一种正弦印象。想必我们在这种时刻听到的音符往往会在我们眼前展开，根据音调和音量在更大或更小的表面上传播。追踪阿拉伯式花纹设计，给我们呼吸或纤细、稳定或任性的感觉。 但在这些感觉发展到足以逃脱淹没在随后的、甚至同时发生的音符已经开始唤醒我们的感觉之下之前，音符本身就已经消失了。这种不确定的感知将继续在其熔化的流动性中窒息那些时不时出现的、几乎难以辨别的主题，然后再次陷入、消失和淹没；只能通过他们灌输的特殊快乐来识别，无法描述，回忆，命名；难以言喻；——如果我们的记忆，就像一个在波涛汹涌的波浪下辛勤打下坚实基础的劳动者，没有通过为我们塑造那些转瞬即逝的短语的复制品，使我们能够将它们与那些难以描述的短语进行比较和对比。跟随。因此，斯万经历过的美妙感觉刚刚消失，他的记忆就立即为他提供了一份记录，总结，这是真的，而且是临时的，但他在演奏时一直盯着它。继续，如此有效，以至于当同样的印象突然出现时，它不再是无法捕捉的。他能够自己想象它的范围、它的对称排列、它的符号、它的表达的强度；他面前有一个明确的目标，它不再是纯粹的音乐，而是设计、建筑、思想，并允许人们回忆起真正的音乐。这次他非常清楚地辨别出了从声波中出现了一会儿的短语。它立即向他发出了分享亲密快乐的邀请，在听到它之前，他从未梦想过这种快乐的存在，他觉得除了这句话之外没有什么可以让他开始；他对它充满了热爱，就像一种新奇的渴望。

With a slow and rhythmical movement it led him here, there, everywhere, towards a state of happiness noble, unintelligible, yet clearly indicated. And then, suddenly having reached a certain point from which he was prepared to follow it, after pausing for a moment, abruptly it changed its direction, and in a fresh movement, more rapid, multiform, melancholy, incessant, sweet, it bore him off with it towards a vista of joys unknown. Then it vanished. He hoped, with a passionate longing, that he might find it again, a third time. And reappear it did, though without speaking to him more clearly, bringing him, indeed, a pleasure less profound. But when he was once more at home he needed it, he was like a man into whose life a woman, whom he has seen for a moment passing by, has brought a new form of beauty, which strengthens and enlarges his own power of perception, without his knowing even whether he is ever to see her again whom he loves already, although he knows nothing of her, not even her name.
它以一种缓慢而有节奏的动作，带领他这里、那里、无处不在，走向一种高贵、难以理解、但却清晰可见的幸福状态。然后，突然到达了他准备跟随它的某个点，停顿了一会儿之后，它突然改变了方向，以一种新的运动，更加迅速，形式多样，忧郁，不断，甜蜜，它带着他带着它走向未知的欢乐景象。然后它就消失了。他怀着强烈的渴望，希望能够再次找到它，第三次。它确实重新出现了，虽然没有更清楚地对他说话，但确实给他带来了一种不那么深刻的快乐。但当他再次回到家时，他需要它，他就像一个男人，他短暂地看到一个女人进入他的生活，给他带来了一种新形式的美，这增强和扩大了他自己的感知能力，他甚至不知道是否还能再见到他已经爱着的她，尽管他对她一无所知，甚至不知道她的名字。

Indeed this passion for a phrase of music seemed, in the first few months, to be bringing into Swann’s life the possibility of a sort of re— juvenation. He had so long since ceased to direct his course towards any ideal goal, and had confined himself to the pursuit of ephemeral satisfactions, that he had come to believe, though without ever formally stating his belief even to himself, that he would remain all his life in that condition, which death alone could alter. More than this, since his mind no longer entertained any lofty ideals, he had ceased to believe in (although he could not have expressly denied) their reality. He had grown also into the habit of taking refuge in trivial considerations, which allowed him to set on one side matters of fundamental importance. Just as he had never stopped to ask himself whether he would not have done better by not going into society, knowing very well that if he had accepted an invitation he must put in an appearance, and that afterwards, if he did not actually call, he must at least leave cards upon his hostess; so in his conversation he took care never to express with any warmth a personal opinion about a thing, but instead would supply facts and details which had a value of a sort in themselves, and excused him from shewing how much he really knew. He would be extremely precise about the recipe for a dish, the dates of a painter’s birth and death, and the titles of his works. Sometimes, in spite of himself, he would let himself go so far as to utter a criticism of a work of art, or of some one’s interpretation of life, but then he would cloak his words in a tone of irony, as though he did not altogether associate himself with what he was saying. But now, like a confirmed invalid whom, all of a sudden, a change of air and surroundings, or a new course of treatment, or, as sometimes happens, an organic change in himself, spontaneous and unaccountable, seems to have so far recovered from his malady that he begins to envisage the possibility, hitherto beyond all hope, of starting to lead—and better late than never—a wholly different life, Swann found in himself, in the memory of the phrase that he had heard, in certain other sonatas which he had made people play over to him, to see whether he might not, perhaps, discover his phrase among them, the presence of one of those invisible realities in which he had ceased to believe, but to which, as though the music had had upon the moral barrenness from which he was suffering a sort of recreative influence, he was conscious once again of a desire, almost, indeed, of the power to consecrate his life. But, never having managed to find out whose work it was that he had heard played that evening, he had been unable to procure a copy, and finally had forgotten the quest. He had indeed, in the course of the next few days, encountered several of the people who had been at the party with him, and had questioned them; but most of them had either arrived after or left before the piece was played; some had indeed been in the house, but had gone into another room to talk, and those who had stayed to listen had no clearer impression than the rest. As for his hosts, they knew that it was a recently published work which the musicians whom they had engaged for the evening had asked to be allowed to play; but, as these last were now on tour somewhere, Swann could learn nothing further. He had, of course, a number of musical friends, but, vividly as he could recall the exquisite and inexpressible pleasure which the little phrase had given him, and could see, still, before his eyes the forms that it had traced in outline, he was quite incapable of humming over to them the air. And so, at last, he ceased to think of it.
事实上，在最初的几个月里，这种对音乐片段的热情似乎给斯旺的生活带来了某种复兴的可能性。他早已不再将自己的道路引向任何理想的目标，而是将自己局限于追求短暂的满足，以至于他开始相信，尽管甚至没有正式向自己表明他的信念，他仍然会保持自己的全部。在这种情况下的生活，只有死亡才能改变。不仅如此，由于他的心中不再有任何崇高的理想，他不再相信（尽管他不能明确否认）它们的现实。他还养成了逃避琐事的习惯，这使他能够把最重要的事情放在一边。正如他从未停下来问自己，如果不走进社会，他是否会做得更好，他很清楚，如果他接受了邀请，他就必须露面，而之后，如果他没有真正打电话，他至少得给女主人留下名片；因此，在谈话中，他小心翼翼地从不热情地表达对某件事的个人看法，而是提供本身具有某种价值的事实和细节，并原谅他没有表明他真正知道多少。他对菜肴的配方、画家的出生和死亡日期以及他的作品的标题都非常精确。有时，他会不由自主地对一件艺术作品或某人对生活的解释提出批评，但随后他会用讽刺的语气掩盖自己的话，就好像他确实不完全同意他所说的话。 但现在，就像一个确诊的病人一样，突然之间，空气和环境的变化，或者新的治疗过程，或者有时会发生的，他自己的有机变化，自发的和不负责任的，似乎已经康复了从他的疾病中，他开始设想一种可能性，迄今为止，这是不可能的，开始过一种完全不同的生活——迟到总比不好——斯旺在自己身上发现，在他听到的那句话的记忆中，在某些方面他让人们给他演奏其他奏鸣曲，看看他是否可能在其中发现他的乐句，那些看不见的现实之一的存在，他不再相信这些现实，但对它来说，仿佛音乐对他所遭受的道德贫瘠产生了一种创造性的影响，他再次意识到了一种渴望，几乎确实是一种奉献自己生命的力量。但是，他一直没能查出那天晚上听到的是谁的作品，也无法买到一份副本，最终忘记了这个任务。在接下来的几天里，他确实遇到了几个和他一起参加聚会的人，并向他们询问过；但他们中的大多数人要么在乐曲演奏之后到达，要么在乐曲演奏之前离开；有些人确实在屋子里，但去了另一个房间说话，留下来听的人并不比其他人有更清晰的印象。至于他的主人，他们知道这是一首最近出版的作品，他们晚上聘请的音乐家要求允许演奏这首作品；但是，由于最后这些现在正在某个地方巡回演出，斯旺无法了解更多信息。 当然，他有很多音乐朋友，但是，他清楚地记得这短短的乐句给他带来的精致而难以言喻的快乐，并且仍然可以在他眼前看到它所描绘的轮廓，他根本无法在空中对着他们哼哼。于是，他终于不再去想这件事了。

But to-night, at Mme. Verdurin’s, scarcely had the little pianist begun to play when, suddenly, after a high note held on through two whole bars, Swann saw it approaching, stealing forth from underneath that resonance, which was prolonged and stretched out over it, like a curtain of sound, to veil the mystery of its birth—and recognised, secret, whispering, articulate, the airy and fragrant phrase that he had loved. And it was so peculiarly itself, it had so personal a charm, which nothing else could have replaced, that Swann felt as though he had met, in a friend’s drawing-room, a woman whom he had seen and admired, once, in the street, and had despaired of ever seeing her again. Finally the phrase withdrew and vanished, pointing, directing, diligent among the wandering currents of its fragrance, leaving upon Swann’s features a reflection of its smile. But now, at last, he could ask the name of his fair unknown (and was told that it was the andante movement of Vinteuil’s sonata for the piano and violin), he held it safe, could have it again to himself, at home, as often as he would, could study its language and acquire its secret.
但今晚，在夫人那里。维尔迪兰的钢琴家刚刚开始演奏，突然间，在一个高音持续了两个小节之后，斯万看到它正在接近，从共鸣下面偷偷地走出来，共鸣被延长并伸展在它上面，就像一道帘子一样。声音，掩盖了它诞生的神秘——并认出了他所喜爱的、秘密的、低语的、清晰的、轻快而芬芳的短语。它本身是如此奇特，它具有如此个人化的魅力，这是任何其他东西都无法替代的，以至于斯万感觉自己好像在朋友的客厅里遇到了一个他曾经在家里见过并钦佩的女人。街上，我已经绝望地再也见不到她了。最后，这句话撤回了，消失了，在它飘荡的香气中辛勤地指着、指挥着，在斯旺的脸上留下了微笑的倒影。但现在，他终于可以问到那个不知名的人的名字了（并被告知这是万特伊钢琴和小提琴奏鸣曲的行板乐章），他把它安全地保管着，可以在家里再次拥有它，只要他愿意，就可以研究它的语言并获取它的秘密。

And so, when the pianist had finished, Swann crossed the room and thanked him with a vivacity which delighted Mme. Verdurin.
因此，当钢琴家演奏完毕后，斯旺穿过房间，热情地向他表示感谢，这让夫人很高兴。韦尔迪兰。

‘Isn’t he charming?’ she asked Swann, ‘doesn’t he just understand it, his sonata, the little wretch? You never dreamed, did you, that a piano could be made to express all that? Upon my word, there’s everything in it except the piano! I’m caught out every time I hear it; I think I’m listening to an orchestra. Though it’s better, really, than an orchestra, more complete.’
“他不是很迷人吗？”她问斯万，“他的奏鸣曲，这个小坏蛋，他难道不明白吗？您从未梦想过，可以用一架钢琴来表达这一切，对吗？老实说，除了钢琴之外，里面什么都有！每次我听到它，我都会被抓住；我想我正在听管弦乐队的演奏。虽然它实际上比管弦乐队更好，更完整。”

The young pianist bent over her as he answered, smiling and underlining each of his words as though he were making an epigram: ‘You are most generous to me.’
年轻的钢琴家在回答时俯身在她身上，微笑着并在每个词下面强调，就像在写警句：“你对我是最慷慨的。”

And while Mme. Verdurin was saying to her husband, ‘Run and fetch him a glass of orangeade; it’s well earned!’ Swann began to tell Odette how he had fallen in love with that little phrase. When their hostess, who was a little way off, called out, ‘Well! It looks to me as though some one was saying nice things to you, Odette!’ she replied, ‘Yes, very nice,’ and he found her simplicity delightful. Then he asked for some information about this Vinteuil; what else he had done, and at what period in his life he had composed the sonata;—what meaning the little phrase could have had for him, that was what Swann wanted most to know.
而女士。维尔迪兰对她的丈夫说：“跑去给他拿一杯橙水来；” “这是你应得的！”斯旺开始告诉奥黛特他是如何爱上这句话的。就在离他们不远的地方，女主人喊道：‘好啦！在我看来，好像有人在对你说好话，奥黛特！”她回答道，“是的，非常好。”他发现她的单纯令人愉快。然后他询问了一些关于这个Vinteuil的信息；他还做了什么，在他生命中的什么时期创作了这首奏鸣曲；——这个小乐句对他来说有什么意义，这是斯万最想知道的。

But none of these people who professed to admire this musician (when Swann had said that the sonata was really charming Mme. Verdurin had exclaimed, ‘I quite believe it! Charming, indeed! But you don’t dare to confess that you don’t know Vinteuil’s sonata; you have no right not to know it!’—and the painter had gone on with, ‘Ah, yes, it’s a very fine bit of work, isn’t it? Not, of course, if you want something ‘obvious,’ something ‘popular,’ but, I mean to say, it makes a very great impression on us artists.’), none of them seemed ever to have asked himself these questions, for none of them was able to reply.
但这些自称钦佩这位音乐家的人中没有一个人（当斯旺说这首奏鸣曲真的很迷人时，维尔迪兰夫人惊呼道：“我完全相信！确实很迷人！但你不敢承认你不喜欢”） “你不知道凡特伊的奏鸣曲；你没有权利不知道它！”——画家继续说道，“啊，是的，这是一件非常好的作品，不是吗？当然不是，如果你愿意的话一些“显而易见”的东西，一些“流行”的东西，但是，我的意思是说，它给我们艺术家留下了非常深刻的印象。”），他们似乎都没有问过自己这些问题，因为他们都无法回答。

Even to one or two particular remarks made by Swann on his favourite phrase, ‘D’you know, that’s a funny thing; I had never noticed it; I may as well tell you that I don’t much care about peering at things through a microscope, and pricking myself on pin-points of difference; no; we don’t waste time splitting hairs in this house; why not? well, it’s not a habit of ours, that’s all,’ Mme. Verdurin replied, while Dr. Cottard gazed at her with open-mouthed admiration, and yearned to be able to follow her as she skipped lightly from one stepping-stone to another of her stock of ready-made phrases. Both he, however, and Mme. Cottard, with a kind of common sense which is shared by many people of humble origin, would always take care not to express an opinion, or to pretend to admire a piece of music which they would confess to each other, once they were safely at home, that they no more understood than they could understand the art of ‘Master’ Biche. Inasmuch as the public cannot recognise the charm, the beauty, even the outlines of nature save in the stereotyped impressions of an art which they have gradually assimilated, while an original artist starts by rejecting those impressions, so M. and Mme. Cottard, typical, in this respect, of the public, were incapable of finding, either in Vinteuil’s sonata or in Biche’s portraits, what constituted harmony, for them, in music or beauty in painting. It appeared to them, when the pianist played his sonata, as though he were striking haphazard from the piano a medley of notes which bore no relation to the musical forms to which they themselves were accustomed, and that the painter simply flung the colours haphazard upon his canvas. When, on one of these, they were able to distinguish a human form, they always found it coarsened and vulgarised (that is to say lacking all the elegance of the school of painting through whose spectacles they themselves were in the habit of seeing the people—real, living people, who passed them in the streets) and devoid of truth, as though M. Biche had not known how the human shoulder was constructed, or that a woman’s hair was not, ordinarily, purple.
即使是斯旺对他最喜欢的短语发表的一两句话，“你知道吗，这是一件有趣的事情；”我从来没有注意到这一点；我不妨告诉你，我不太关心通过显微镜观察事物，并在细微的差异上刺痛自己；不;我们不会在这所房子里浪费时间吹毛求疵；为什么不？好吧，这不是我们的习惯，仅此而已，”夫人。维尔迪兰回答道，而科塔德医生张大嘴巴，钦佩地看着她，渴望能够跟随她，看着她轻轻地从一个踏脚石跳到另一个现成的短语。然而，他和夫人。科塔尔具有许多出身卑微的人所共有的常识，他总是小心翼翼地不发表意见，或者假装欣赏一首音乐，一旦他们安全地到达了，他们就会互相承认。家，他们对比什“大师”的艺术的理解并不多。由于公众无法认识到艺术的魅力、美丽，甚至自然的轮廓，除非他们已经逐渐吸收了艺术的刻板印象，而原创艺术家则从拒绝这些印象开始，所以M.和Mme。在这方面，科塔尔是公众的典型，无论是在万特伊的奏鸣曲中还是在比什的肖像画中，他都无法找到对他们来说音乐或绘画之美的和谐是什么。在他们看来，当钢琴家演奏他的奏鸣曲时，他仿佛从钢琴上随意弹奏出与他们自己习惯的音乐形式毫无关系的混合音符，而画家只是随意地把颜色扔到了上面。他的画布。 当他们能够在其中一幅作品上辨别出人形时，他们总是发现它变得粗糙和庸俗（也就是说，缺乏绘画流派的所有优雅，他们自己习惯于通过其眼镜来看待人们） ——真实的、活生生的人，在街上经过他们），缺乏真相，好像比什先生不知道人类的肩膀是如何构造的，或者女人的头发通常不是紫色的。

And yet, when the ‘faithful’ were scattered out of earshot, the Doctor felt that the opportunity was too good to be missed, and so (while Mme. Verdurin was adding a final word of commendation of Vinteuil’s sonata) like a would-be swimmer who jumps into the water, so as to learn, but chooses a moment when there are not too many people looking on: ‘Yes, indeed; he’s what they call a musician di primo cartello!’ he exclaimed, with a sudden determination.
然而，当“信徒”们分散到听不到的地方时，博士觉得这个机会太好了，不容错过，因此（当维尔迪兰夫人最后对万特伊的奏鸣曲表示赞扬时）就像一个潜在的游泳者跳入水中学习，但选择了没有太多人观看的时刻：“是的，确实如此；”他就是人们所说的音乐家迪·普里莫·卡泰罗！”他突然下定决心，大声喊道。

Swann discovered no more than that the recent publication of Vinteuil’s sonata had caused a great stir among the most advanced school of musicians, but that it was still unknown to the general public.
斯万发现的只不过是最近出版的凡特伊奏鸣曲在最先进的音乐家流派中引起了巨大轰动，但它仍然不为公众所知。

‘I know some one, quite well, called Vinteuil,’ said Swann, thinking of the old music-master at Combray who had taught my grandmother’s sisters.
“我很熟悉一个人，名叫万特伊，”斯旺说道，他想起了贡布雷的一位老音乐大师，他曾经教过我祖母的姐妹们。

‘Perhaps that’s the man!’ cried Mme. Verdurin.
“也许就是那个男人！”夫人喊道。韦尔迪兰。

‘Oh, no!’ Swann burst out laughing. ‘If you had ever seen him for a moment you wouldn’t put the question.’
“哦，不！”斯旺大笑起来。 “如果你见过他一会儿，你就不会提出这个问题。”

‘Then to put the question is to solve the problem?’ the Doctor suggested.
“那么提出问题就是解决问题吗？”博士建议道。

‘But it may well be some relative,’ Swann went on. ‘That would be bad enough; but, after all, there is no reason why a genius shouldn’t have a cousin who is a silly old fool. And if that should be so, I swear there’s no known or unknown form of torture I wouldn’t undergo to get the old fool to introduce me to the man who composed the sonata; starting with the torture of the old fool’s company, which would be ghastly.’
“但很可能是某个亲戚，”斯旺继续说道。 ‘那就够糟糕了；但毕竟，天才没有理由不拥有一个愚蠢的老傻瓜的表弟。如果真是这样，我发誓，为了让这个老傻瓜把我介绍给创作这首奏鸣曲的人，我不会经历任何已知或未知的折磨；首先是对老傻瓜公司的折磨，这将是可怕的。

The painter understood that Vinteuil was seriously ill at the moment, and that Dr. Potain despaired of his life.
画家明白万特伊此刻病得很重，波坦医生对他的生活感到绝望。

‘What!’ cried Mme. Verdurin, ‘Do people still call in Potain?’
“什么！”夫人叫道。维尔迪兰：“人们还在波坦打电话吗？”

‘Ah! Mme. Verdurin,’ Cottard simpered, ‘you forget that you are speaking of one of my colleagues—I should say, one of my masters.’
'啊！女士。维尔迪兰，”科塔尔笑着说，“你忘了你说的是我的一位同事——我应该说，我的一位老师。”

The painter had heard, somewhere, that Vinteuil was threatened with the loss of his reason. And he insisted that signs of this could be detected in certain passages in the sonata. This remark did not strike Swann as ridiculous; rather, it puzzled him. For, since a purely musical work contains none of those logical sequences, the interruption or confusion of which, in spoken or written language, is a proof of insanity, so insanity diagnosed in a sonata seemed to him as mysterious a thing as the insanity of a dog or a horse, although instances may be observed of these.
画家在某处听说凡特伊受到失去理智的威胁。他坚持认为，在奏鸣曲的某些段落中可以发现这种迹象。斯万并不觉得这句话可笑；相反，他认为这句话很荒谬。相反，这让他感到困惑。因为，由于一部纯粹的音乐作品不包含任何逻辑顺序，而这些逻辑顺序的中断或混乱，无论是口头还是书面语言，都是精神错乱的证明，所以在奏鸣曲中诊断出的精神错乱对他来说就像是一个神秘的事情，就像在奏鸣曲中诊断出精神错乱一样神秘。狗或马，尽管可以观察到这些例子。

‘Don’t speak to me about ‘your masters’; you know ten times as much as he does!’ Mme. Verdurin answered Dr. Cottard, in the tone of a woman who has the courage of her convictions, and is quite ready to stand up to anyone who disagrees with her. ‘Anyhow, you don’t kill your patients!’
“别跟我说‘你的主人’；你知道的东西比他多十倍！’女士。维尔迪兰以一位有勇气坚持自己的信念并随时准备与任何不同意她的人对抗的女性的语气回答了科塔尔博士。 “无论如何，你不能杀死你的病人！”

‘But, Madame, he is in the Academy.’ The Doctor smiled with bitter irony. ‘If a sick person prefers to die at the hands of one of the Princes of Science... It is far more smart to be able to say, ‘Yes, I have Potain.’’
“但是，夫人，他在学院里。”博士讽刺地笑了笑。 “如果一个病人宁愿死在科学王子之一的手中……能够说‘是的，我有波坦’要明智得多。”

‘Oh, indeed! More smart, is it?’ said Mme. Verdurin. ‘So there are fashions, nowadays, in illness, are there? I didn’t know that.... Oh, you do make me laugh!’ she screamed, suddenly, burying her face in her hands. ‘And here was I, poor thing, talking quite seriously, and never seeing that you were pulling my leg.’
‘噢，确实如此！更聪明了，是吗？”夫人说。韦尔迪兰。 “所以现在疾病也有时尚，不是吗？我不知道……哦，你真让我笑了！”她突然尖叫起来，把脸埋在手里。 “而我，可怜的东西，却很认真地说话，却没有发现你在开我的玩笑。”

As for M. Verdurin, finding it rather a strain to start laughing again over so small a matter, he was content with puffing out a cloud of smoke from his pipe, while he reflected sadly that he could never again hope to keep pace with his wife in her Atalanta-flights across the field of mirth.
至于维尔迪兰先生，他觉得为这么一件小事再次开怀大笑实在是太费力了，他满足于从烟斗里喷出一团烟雾，同时他悲伤地反思，他再也不能希望跟上他的步伐了。妻子在她的亚特兰大航班上穿越欢乐的田野。

‘D’you know; we like your friend so very much,’ said Mme. Verdurin, later, when Odette was bidding her good night. ‘He is so unaffected, quite charming. If they’re all like that, the friends you want to bring here, by all means bring them.’
‘你知道吗？我们非常喜欢你的朋友，”女士说。后来，当奥黛特向维尔迪兰道晚安时。 ‘他是如此的不受影响，非常有魅力。如果他们都是这样的话，你想带来这里的朋友一定要带他们来。

M. Verdurin remarked that Swann had failed, all the same, to appreciate the pianist’s aunt.
维尔迪兰先生评论说，斯旺仍然未能欣赏这位钢琴家的姨妈。

‘I dare say he felt a little strange, poor man,’ suggested Mme. Verdurin. ‘You can’t expect him to catch the tone of the house the first time he comes; like Cottard, who has been one of our little ‘clan’ now for years. The first time doesn’t count; it’s just for looking round and finding out things. Odette, he understands all right, he’s to join us to-morrow at the Châtelet. Perhaps you might call for him and bring him.’ ‘No, he doesn’t want that.’
“我敢说他感觉有点奇怪，可怜的人，”夫人建议道。韦尔迪兰。 “你不能指望他第一次来就能够听懂这所房子的基调；就像科塔尔一样，他多年来一直是我们这个小“家族”的一员。第一次不算；只是为了环顾四周并找出东西。奥黛特，他明白了，他明天就要到夏特莱来和我们会合。 “不，他不想这样。”

‘Oh, very well; just as you like. Provided he doesn’t fail us at the last moment.’
'哦，很好;就如你所愿。前提是他没有在最后一刻让我们失望。”

Greatly to Mme. Verdurin’s surprise, he never failed them. He would go to meet them, no matter where, at restaurants outside Paris (not that they went there much at first, for the season had not yet begun), and more frequently at the play, in which Mme. Verdurin delighted. One evening, when they were dining at home, he heard her complain that she had not one of those permits which would save her the trouble of waiting at doors and standing in crowds, and say how useful it would be to them at first-nights, and gala performances at the Opera, and what a nuisance it had been, not having one, on the day of Gambetta’s funeral. Swann never spoke of his distinguished friends, but only of such as might be regarded as detrimental, whom, therefore, he thought it snobbish, and in not very good taste to conceal; while he frequented the Faubourg Saint-Germain he had come to include, in the latter class, all his friends in the official world of the Third Republic, and so broke in, without thinking: ‘I’ll see to that, all right. You shall have it in time for the Danicheff revival. I shall be lunching with the Prefect of Police to-morrow, as it happens, at the Elysée.’
非常感谢女士。令维尔迪兰惊讶的是，他从来没有让他们失望过。他会去见他们，无论在哪里，在巴黎郊外的餐馆（并不是说他们一开始经常去那里，因为季节还没有开始），而且更频繁的是在戏剧中，Mme.维尔迪兰很高兴。一天晚上，当他们在家吃饭时，他听到她抱怨说她没有这些许可证，这样她就可以省去在门口等候和站在人群中的麻烦，并说这对他们在第一晚有多么有用。以及歌剧院的盛大演出，甘贝塔葬礼当天却没有演出，真是一件令人烦恼的事情。斯旺从不谈论他的杰出朋友，而只谈论那些可能被认为有害的朋友，因此，他认为隐瞒这些朋友是势利的，而且不太有品味。当他经常光顾圣日耳曼郊区时，他已经将第三共和国官方世界中的所有朋友都纳入了后者，因此不假思索地闯入：“我会处理的，好吧。”你会在丹尼切夫复兴时及时得到它。明天我将在爱丽舍宫与警察局长共进午餐。

‘What’s that? The Elysée?’ Dr. Cottard roared in a voice of thunder.
'那是什么？爱丽舍宫？”科塔尔博士雷霆般地吼道。

‘Yes, at M. Grévy’s,’ replied Swann, feeling a little awkward at the effect which his announcement had produced.
“是的，在格雷维先生家。”斯万回答道，他对自己的声明所产生的效果感到有点尴尬。

‘Are you often taken like that?’ the painter asked Cottard, with mock-seriousness.
“你经常被这样对待吗？”画家假装严肃地问科塔尔。

As a rule, once an explanation had been given, Cottard would say: ‘Ah, good, good; that’s all right, then,’ after which he would shew not the least trace of emotion. But this time Swann’s last words, instead of the usual calming effect, had that of heating, instantly, to boiling-point his astonishment at the discovery that a man with whom he himself was actually sitting at table, a man who had no official position, no honours or distinction of any sort, was on visiting terms with the Head of the State.
通常，一旦给出解释，科塔尔就会说：“啊，好，好；”那就好吧。”说完，他就没有表现出丝毫的情绪。但这一次，斯旺的最后一句话没有像往常那样起到镇静作用，而是立即变得激动起来，他惊讶地发现，实际上和他一起坐在桌旁的是一个没有任何正式职位的人。 ，没有任何形式的荣誉或荣誉，与国家元首保持着访问关系。

‘What’s that you say? M. Grévy? Do you know M. Grévy?’ he demanded of Swann, in the stupid and incredulous tone of a constable on duty at the palace, when a stranger has come up and asked to see the President of the Republic; until, guessing from his words and manner what, as the newspapers say, ‘it is a case of,’ he assures the poor lunatic that he will be admitted at once, and points the way to the reception ward of the police infirmary.
‘你说什么？格雷维先生？ “你认识格雷维先生吗？”当一个陌生人走过来要求见共和国总统时，他用宫殿里值班警察的愚蠢和难以置信的语气向斯旺问道；直到，正如报纸上所说的，他从他的言语和态度中猜测出“这是一个案件”，他向这个可怜的疯子保证他将立即入院，并指出了通往警察医务室接待病房的路。

‘I know him slightly; we have some friends in common’ (Swann dared not add that one of these friends was the Prince of Wales). ‘Anyhow, he is very free with his invitations, and, I assure you, his luncheon-parties are not the least bit amusing; they’re very simple affairs, too, you know; never more than eight at table,’ he went on, trying desperately to cut out everything that seemed to shew off his relations with the President in a light too dazzling for the Doctor’s eyes.
“我对他有一点了解；我们有一些共同的朋友”（斯旺不敢补充其中一位朋友是威尔士亲王）。 “不管怎样，他对邀请非常随意，而且，我向你保证，他的午餐会一点也不有趣；你知道，它们也是非常简单的事情；餐桌上的人永远不会超过八人。”他继续说道，拼命地试图删掉一切似乎表明他与总统关系的东西，这些东西对于博士的眼睛来说太耀眼了。

Whereupon Cottard, at once conforming in his mind to the literal interpretation of what Swann was saying, decided that invitations from M. Grévy were very little sought after, were sent out, in fact, into the highways and hedge-rows. And from that moment he never seemed at all surprised to hear that Swann, or anyone else, was ‘always at the Elysée’; he even felt a little sorry for a man who had to go to luncheon-parties which, he himself admitted, were a bore.
科塔尔立即在心里接受了斯旺所说的话的字面解释，认为格雷维先生的邀请很少受到欢迎，事实上，它们被发送到了高速公路和树篱上。从那一刻起，当他听到斯旺或其他任何人“总是在爱丽舍宫”时，他似乎一点也不感到惊讶。他甚至为一个不得不参加午餐会的人感到有点遗憾，他自己也承认，午餐会很无聊。

‘Ah, good, good; that’s quite all right then,’ he said, in the tone of a customs official who has been suspicious up to now, but, after hearing your explanations, stamps your passport and lets you proceed on your journey without troubling to examine your luggage.
‘啊，好，好；那就没什么问题了，”他用迄今为止一直持怀疑态度的海关官员的语气说道，但在听完你的解释后，他在你的护照上盖了章，让你继续旅程，而不必费心检查你的行李。

‘I can well believe you don’t find them amusing, those parties; indeed, it’s very good of you to go to them!’ said Mme. Verdurin, who regarded the President of the Republic only as a ‘bore’ to be especially dreaded, since he had at his disposal means of seduction, and even of compulsion, which, if employed to captivate her ‘faithful,’ might easily make them ‘fail.’ ‘It seems, he’s as deaf as a post; and eats with his fingers.’
“我完全相信你不会觉得这些聚会很有趣；确实，你能去拜访他们真是太好了！”维尔迪兰认为共和国总统只是一个特别令人畏惧的“讨厌鬼”，因为他拥有诱惑手段，甚至强迫手段，如果用来迷惑她的“忠诚”，很容易使他们“失败了。”“看来，他聋得像个柱子一样；”并用手指吃饭。

‘Upon my word! Then it can’t be much fun for you, going there.’ A note of pity sounded in the Doctor’s voice; and then struck by the number—only eight at table—‘Are these luncheons what you would describe as ‘intimate’?’ he inquired briskly, not so much out of idle curiosity as in his linguistic zeal.
‘我保证！ “那么去那里对你来说就没有什么乐趣了。”博士的声音里带着一丝怜悯。然后他被这个数字震惊了——餐桌上只有八个人——“这些午餐是你所说的‘亲密’吗？”他轻快地问道，与其说是出于无聊的好奇心，不如说是出于他的语言热情。

But so great and glorious a figure was the President of the French Republic in the eyes of Dr. Cottard that neither the modesty of Swann nor the spite of Mme. Verdurin could ever wholly efface that first impression, and he never sat down to dinner with the Verdurins without asking anxiously, ‘D’you think we shall see M. Swann here this evening? He is a personal friend of M. Grévy’s. I suppose that means he’s what you’d call a ‘gentleman’?’ He even went to the length of offering Swann a card of invitation to the Dental Exhibition.
但在科塔尔博士眼中，法兰西共和国总统是如此伟大和光荣，以至于斯万的谦虚和夫人的恶意都没有。维尔迪兰永远无法完全消除这种第一印象，每次与维尔迪兰一家共进晚餐时，他都会焦急地问：“你认为今晚我们会在这里见到斯万先生吗？”他是格雷维先生的私人朋友。我想这意味着他就是你所说的‘绅士’？”他甚至还给斯旺一张牙科展览会的邀请卡。

‘This will let you in, and anyone you take with you,’ he explained, ‘but dogs are not admitted. I’m just warning you, you understand, because some friends of mine went there once, who hadn’t been told, and there was the devil to pay.’
他解释说：“这可以让你和你随身携带的任何人进去，但狗不允许进入。”我只是警告你，你明白，因为我的一些朋友去过那里一次，但没有被告知，而且要付出惨重的代价。

As for M. Verdurin, he did not fail to observe the distressing effect upon his wife of the discovery that Swann had influential friends of whom he had never spoken.
至于维尔迪兰先生，他也注意到，斯万有一些颇有影响力的朋友，但他从未提及过这些朋友，这给他的妻子带来了痛苦的影响。

If no arrangement had been made to ‘go anywhere,’ it was at the Verdurins’ that Swann would find the ‘little nucleus’ assembled, but he never appeared there except in the evenings, and would hardly ever accept their invitations to dinner, in spite of Odette’s entreaties.
如果没有安排“去任何地方”，斯万就会在维尔迪兰家发现“小核心”聚集在一起，但除了晚上他从来不会出现在那里，而且几乎不会接受他们的晚餐邀请。尽管奥黛特一再恳求。

‘I could dine with you alone somewhere, if you’d rather,’ she suggested.
“如果你愿意的话，我可以和你单独在某个地方吃饭，”她建议道。

‘But what about Mme. Verdurin?’
“但是夫人呢？”维尔迪兰？

‘Oh, that’s quite simple. I need only say that my dress wasn’t ready, or that my cab came late. There is always some excuse.’
‘哦，这很简单。我只需说我的衣服还没准备好，或者我的出租车来晚了。总有一些借口。

‘How charming of you.’
“你真迷人。”

But Swann said to himself that, if he could make Odette feel (by consenting to meet her only after dinner) that there were other pleasures which he preferred to that of her company, then the desire that she felt for his would be all the longer in reaching the point of satiety. Besides, as he infinitely preferred to Odette’s style of beauty that of a little working girl, as fresh and plump as a rose, with whom he happened to be simultaneously in love, he preferred to spend the first part of the evening with her, knowing that he was sure to see Odette later on. For the same reason, he would never allow Odette to call for him at his house, to take him on to the Verdurins’. The little girl used to wait, not far from his door, at a street corner; Rémi, his coachman, knew where to stop; she would jump in beside him, and hold him in her arms until the carriage drew up at the Verdurins’. He would enter the drawing-room; and there, while Mme. Verdurin, pointing to the roses which he had sent her that morning, said: ‘I am furious with you!’ and sent him to the place kept for him, by the side of Odette, the pianist would play to them—for their two selves, and for no one else—that little phrase by Vinteuil which was, so to speak, the national anthem of their love. He began, always, with a sustained tremolo from the violin part, which, for several bars, was unaccompanied, and filled all the foreground; until suddenly it seemed to be drawn aside, and—just as in those interiors by Pieter de Hooch, where the subject is set back a long way through the narrow framework of a half-opened door—infinitely remote, in colour quite different, velvety with the radiance of some intervening light, the little phrase appeared, dancing, pastoral, interpolated, episodic, belonging to another world. It passed, with simple and immortal movements, scattering on every side the bounties of its grace, smiling ineffably still; but Swann thought that he could now discern in it some disenchantment. It seemed to be aware how vain, how hollow was the happiness to which it shewed the way. In its airy grace there was, indeed, something definitely achieved, and complete in itself, like the mood of philosophic detachment which follows an outburst of vain regret. But little did that matter to him; he looked upon the sonata less in its own light—as what it might express, had, in fact, expressed to a certain musician, ignorant that any Swann or Odette, anywhere in the world, existed, when he composed it, and would express to all those who should hear it played in centuries to come—than as a pledge, a token of his love, which made even the Verdurins and their little pianist think of Odette and, at the same time, of himself—which bound her to him by a lasting tie; and at that point he had (whimsically entreated by Odette) abandoned the idea of getting some ‘professional’ to play over to him the whole sonata, of which he still knew no more than this one passage. ‘Why do you want the rest?’ she had asked him. ‘Our little bit; that’s all we need.’ He went farther; agonised by the reflection, at the moment when it passed by him, so near and yet so infinitely remote, that, while it was addressed to their ears, it knew them not, he would regret, almost, that it had a meaning of its own, an intrinsic and unalterable beauty, foreign to themselves, just as in the jewels given to us, or even in the letters written to us by a woman with whom we are in love, we find fault with the ‘water’ of a stone, or with the words of a sentence because they are not fashioned exclusively from the spirit of a fleeting intimacy and of a ‘lass unparalleled.’
但斯万对自己说，如果他能让奥黛特感觉到（通过同意只在晚饭后见到她）他更喜欢其他的快乐而不是她的陪伴，那么她对他的渴望就会更加长久。达到饱足感的程度。此外，由于他极其喜欢奥黛特那种小职业女孩的美貌，像玫瑰一样清新丰润，而他又恰巧同时爱上了她，所以他更愿意和她一起度过傍晚的第一部分，因为他知道他确信稍后会见到奥黛特。出于同样的原因，他永远不会允许奥黛特去他家叫他，带他去维尔迪兰家。小女孩常常在离他家门不远的街角等他。他的车夫雷米知道该停在哪里。她会跳到他身边，把他抱在怀里，直到马车停在维尔迪兰家。他会走进客厅；在那里，而夫人。维尔迪兰指着那天早上送给她的玫瑰花说：“我对你很生气！”然后把他送到为他保留的地方，在奥黛特旁边，钢琴家会为他们两个演奏。只为自己，不为任何人——万特伊的这句小词可以说是他们爱情的国歌。他总是以小提琴部分的持续颤音开始，其中有几个小节没有伴奏，并充满了整个前景。直到突然之间，它似乎被拉到一边，而且——就像彼得·德·霍赫（Pieter de Hooch）的那些室内设计一样，主题在半开的门的狭窄框架中退后很远——无限遥远，颜色截然不同，柔软伴随着一些介入光的光芒，这个小短语出现了，舞蹈，田园，插入，情节，属于另一个世界。 它以简单而不朽的动作走过，将其恩典的恩惠撒向四面八方，仍然微笑着，难以言表；但斯万认为他现在可以从中看出一些失望。它似乎意识到自己所引领的幸福是多么虚荣、多么空虚。在它空灵的优雅中，确实有某种明确的成就，并且本身是完整的，就像在徒劳的遗憾爆发后产生的哲学超然情绪。但这对他来说并不重要。他不太从奏鸣曲本身的角度来看待它——因为它可能表达的内容，实际上是向某个音乐家表达的，不知道任何斯旺或奥黛特，在世界任何地方，当他创作它时，都存在，并且会表达对于所有在未来几个世纪里应该听到这首曲子的人来说，而不是作为一种誓言，一种他的爱的象征，这甚至使维尔迪兰夫妇和他们的小钢琴家想到了奥黛特，同时也想到了他自己——这将她束缚在他有一条持久的领带；那时，他（奥黛特异想天开地恳求）放弃了让一些“专业人士”为他演奏整首奏鸣曲的想法，而他对奏鸣曲的了解除了这一段之外。 “你为什么想要剩下的？”她问他。 ‘我们的一点点；这就是我们所需要的。’他走得更远；当它从他身边经过的那一刻，他对倒影感到痛苦，如此接近，却又如此无限遥远，虽然它是对着他们的耳朵说的，但它不认识他们，他几乎会后悔，它有它的意义一种内在的、不可改变的美，对它们来说是陌生的，就像在送给我们的珠宝中，甚至在我们所爱的女人写给我们的信中，我们对石头的“水”挑剔，或用一句话来形容，因为它们并非完全是由转瞬即逝的亲密关系和“无与伦比的少女”的精神构成的。’

It would happen, as often as not, that he had stayed so long outside, with his little girl, before going to the Verdurins’ that, as soon as the little phrase had been rendered by the pianist, Swann would discover that it was almost time for Odette to go home. He used to take her back as far as the door of her little house in the Rue La Pérouse, behind the Arc de Triomphe. And it was perhaps on this account, and so as not to demand the monopoly of her favours, that he sacrificed the pleasure (not so essential to his well-being) of seeing her earlier in the evening, of arriving with her at the Verdurins’, to the exercise of this other privilege, for which she was grateful, of their leaving together; a privilege which he valued all the more because, thanks to it, he had the feeling that no one else would see her, no one would thrust himself between them, no one could prevent him from remaining with her in spirit, after he had left her for the night.
常常会发生这样的情况：在去维尔迪兰家之前，他和他的小女儿在外面呆了很长时间，钢琴家一演奏出这首小乐句，斯旺就会发现它几乎已经是奥黛特该回家了。他常常把她带回她位于凯旋门后面的拉佩鲁斯街的小房子门口。也许正是因为这个原因，为了不要求独占她的恩惠，他牺牲了晚上早些时候见到她、和她一起到达韦尔迪兰的快乐（这对他的幸福来说并不是那么重要）。 ”，行使他们一起离开的另一项特权，她对此表示感激；他更加珍惜这种特权，因为有了它，他有一种感觉，在他离开之后，没有人会看到她，没有人会把自己插在他们中间，没有人可以阻止他在精神上与她在一起。她过夜。
